 Book is about extraordinary women throughout human history whose lives were shaped less by having been born women, as Simone de Beauvoir put it in her revolutionary book The Second Sex, than by having to be made into women by their cultures .
 Each of the women featured in A to Z of Women in World History is considered within the particular cultural and historical milieu of which she was a part . Each of these women was considered within a particular cultural milieu .
 The intertwining of three contemporary subfields of history forms the intellectual web underlying the research and writing of this book . World history, women’s history, and gender history is a key part of the book .
 Each chapter represents a category of human achievement from business to art to science . Taking cultural interaction as the key force in shaping world history, each chapter o{ A to Z of Women in World History . Each chapter takes a look at the achievements of women in world history .
 Nineteenth-century Chinese revolutionary Qiu Jin, for example, modeled her life on the 15th-century French Christian martyr Joan of Arc .
 Many entries include cross-references to help readers understand such cultural borrowing within and across chapters . Many entries in the book include references to cultural borrowing .
 There is also an alphabetical list of entries in the book’s front matter for easy reference .
 As men have traditionally dominated each of the categories of human achievement, nearly all these women faced formidable obstacles . Women faced obstacles in the form of gender, religious, class, and/or racial discrimination .
 Gender inequality tends to increase across cultures as economic, political, and social institutions become more complex . As world historian Peter N Stears noted in Gender and World History, gender inequality tended to increase in cultures .
 Men, he wrote, attempted to reduce women’s roles in society to a dependent domesticity . Men also tried to reduce the role of women to dependent domesticdomdomdom, he said .
 The women whose lives have been written about in this book amply illustrate that those rigid gender roles were much more permeable than they—or we—had been led to believe . The lives of these women illustrate that gender roles are much less rigid than they were led to .

 The cold war is a term used to describe the intense antagonism and rivalry between the U.S. and western Europe, on one side, and eastern Europe on the other side .
 At times, such as during the Korean War, the cold war “heated up,” and a military conflict occurred . The cold war is often referred to as the Cold War . At times it heated up, and a conflict occurred during the cold .
 At other times, the rivalry between the two parts of the world took the form of cultural fights . At times, it also took the forms of cultural clashes .
 Athletic contests such as figure skating competitions took on political dimensions . Judges and spectators viewed skating styles as representing cultural differences between democracy and communism .
 Judges on both sides of the Iron Curtain were accused of nationalistic biases . Winston Churchill coined the phrase to mean the division between the communists in the East and democracies in the West .

 Lifts are moves in which the male partner hoists the female above his head . Lifts is moves that the man hoists his partner above his own head .
 Both skaters should achieve full extension of their arms and legs . They should keep moving on the ice, not slowing down to perform the lift .

 In a throw, the male partner throws the female as she jumps, allowing her to increase momentum and achieve a higher jump . The male partner is also throwing the female to increase her momentum .

 Cuba’s economy prospered largely because of its sugar trade with the U.S. Cuba's sugar trade was largely tied to its sugar exports to the United States . Cuba's economy thrived largely due to the sugar trade .
 Socialist Castro stirred up popular discontent into a two-year guerrilla war against dictator Fulgencio Batista . Castro won in 1958 with the help of Che Guevara .
 Castro became Cuba’s premier; Guevara became Cuba's minister of industry . Castro was Cuba's premier . Gueevara directed much of the government's economic planning . Castro became the Cuban president in 1959 .
 Castro initiated extensive economic and social reforms along socialist principles . The reforms included the nationalization of banking and industry, many owned by the United States . The U.S. broke off diplomatic ties with Castro's government .
 Later, she worked as a translator for the Ministry of Education, the Cuban Institute of Friendship with the Peoples, and the Federation of Cuban Women .
 Her ultimate goal, however, was to learn about the Cuban Revolution and export it elsewhere in Latin America . She said she wanted to export it to Latin America, but her ultimate goal is to learn more about it .
 By 1962, she had grown restless at her translating job, and she commented that this was not the kind of revolutionary work to which she had aspired .
 Since 1957, Bunke had taken up marksmanship and military training with the idea of ultimately participating in a revolution . Bunke was inspired by the idea that he wanted to be involved in the revolution .
 She trained in the German Democratic Republic Association for Sports and Skills, which included mastery of defense sports, sending Morse Code messages, and operating radio equipment .

 She learned how to write invisibly, obtain data and check data undercover, and how to identify counterintelligence . She learned to write in secret to avoid detection .

 Guevara told her that she would be sent to Bolivia to make contacts with the Bolivian government and armed forces . She will travel through the interior to study the situation of miners, peasants and workers .
 Laura Guitierez Bauer is an ethnologist studying Bolivian folklore . She flew to La Paz, Bolivia, as Laura Guitez Bauer .
 She married a Bolivian man and then divorced him after obtaining citizenship . She now has a daughter of Bolivians .
 In May 1966, Bunke took on a new identity, Tania, in communicating with revolutionaries in Guba, who were now prepared to ignite the revolution in Bolivia . Bunke was a member of the Bolivian revolutionary movement .
 Ghe Guevara and his followers decided to go ahead with their plans . Lacking sufficient recruits among the Bolivian people, they decided to carry out the attack .
 Tamara Bunke marched next-to-last in a line of guerrilla troops crossing the cold waters of the Vado del Yeso River . Bunke was the last member of the guerrilla army to cross the river in 1967 .
 Bolivian soldiers waiting in ambush across the river suddenly fired a volley of shots, killing all eight soldiers . Bolivians were waiting in an ambush across a river across the border . The soldiers were killed in the ambush, which is believed to be the first of its kind .
 Bunke’s badly decomposed body was found seven days later and was flown to Vallegrande, Bolivia . Bunke was found in a shallow grave in the country's capital, San Diego .

 DARLING, GRACE (Grace Horsely Darling) British heroine Go, tell the wide world over What English pluck can do; And sing of brave Grace Darling Who nobly saved the crew .
 The lyrics to “The Grace Darling Song’ recite the sole act for which the British people ennobled their heroine Grace Darling . The lyrics recite the only act for the act that made her famous .
 She helped her father, William Darling, rescue the shipwrecked passengers and crew of the steamer Forfashirem 1838 .
 Grace Darling was in some ways the forerunner of another British icon, opera star Jenny LIND . She was one of the first celebrities in modern history .
 Grace Darling shunned the attention her deed provoked . Unlike Jenny Lind, she shunned attention .
 Grace Darling was born on November 24, 1815, to the lighthouse keeper William Darling . She spent all of her short life living in lighthouses on the rocky shores of the islands off the British mainland .
 Lighthouses had been in use as navigational aids for mariners for thousands of years . Lighthouseouses were used to provide navigational aid to mariners around the world .
 In the 19th century, lighthouses helped sailors determine their position, informed them that land was near, and warned of dangerous rocks and reefs .
 There are only about 1,400 lighthouses currently in use worldwide, due to increases in electronic navigational devices .
 Grace was born on the island of Brownsman, but moved to Northumberland when she was 11 . She was born in Brownsman and moved to Longstone, Northumberlands, when she turned 11 . Grace is the youngest ever to be born in the UK .
 Grace was the sixth of seven children born to the Darlings, and her father and her mother, Thomasin Horsely Darling, were the only three occupants of the lighthouse in 1838 .
 The Forfashire was one of the first luxury steamers in British maritime history . It carried 60 passengers and crew members as it made its way from Hull, north of London, to Dundee, Scotland .
 A powerful gust dashed the ship upon rocky cliffs near Big Hawker Rock on the Fame Islands, Northumberland .
 Eight crew members and one male passenger escaped with the ship’s lifeboat . The ship's lifeboat is believed to have been the last of the ship's .
 A passing sloop picked the sodden sailors up and dropped them in nearby North Shields . The sailors were picked up by a passing ship and taken to North Shields.
 William Darling’s 20-year-old daughter Grace shook the sleep from him at seven o’clock in the morning . William Darling's daughter Grace is 20 years old .
 She saw figures moving about on Big Hawker Rock, she told him, about three-quarters of a mile from Longstone lighthouse . She said figures were moving about about three miles from the lighthouse .
 William and Grace launched their coble -- a short, flat-bottomed rowboat -- with the help of Thomasin Darling . Thomasin is the wife of William's first wife, Grace, who was born in New York .
 Grace rowed as close as she could so that her father could jump ashore . When they reached the rock, Grace rowbed as close to the rock as possible . Grace's father jumped ashore .
 When he did, she continued to navigate the coble away from the rock to prevent the current and the wind from smashing the boat on the rock .
 She labored to keep the boat afloat, until her father beckoned her back to the rock to pick up him and his weary passengers . Her father and his passengers were picked up by her father .
 Grace and her mother nursed the injured and exhausted back to health . Grace's mother says she is proud of her daughter's bravery . Grace is a proud member of the family .
 At the same time, the press investigated the accident, especially the events surrounding the lifeboat escape of the eight 41 AMAZONS, HEROINES, AND MILITARY LEADERS crew members, who did nothing, reporters charged .
 William and Grace Darling were the subject of numerous portraits by several English artists . As a result of all the publicity, they became the subjects of numerous paintings by several artists .
 Grace Darling died of consumption on October 20, 1842 at the age of 26 .
 Much of the story of the Forfashire disaster comes from William Darling’s lighthouse journal which he kept at his bedside . William Darling kept the lighthouse journal at the bedside of his dying bed .
 A printed version of the journal is now housed at the Grace Darling Museum in the village of Hamburgh, on the British mainland .
 William Darling’s entry on the night of September 7, 1838, in which he recounts the rescue, does not mention his daughter at all . William Darling did not mention the rescue .

 Deborah functioned as a judge of the Hebrews, as well as their political and military adviser . Deborah served as an adviser to the Jewish community . She was also a judge and military advisor to the Israelites .
 When she became aware of the cruel treatment her people suffered under Canaanite rule, she outlined a plan of action . She outlined the plan to help her people .
 She instructed General Barak to raise an army of 10,000 troops and lead them into battle against their oppressors . She instructed him to raise the army, which she said would be the largest in the Arab world .
 The verbal exchange between General Barak and Deborah is recorded in the Hebrew Bible, in the book of Judges 4:8-9 . Deborah and Barak are recorded in Judges 4-9 in Judges .

 Abraham became the patriarch of the people who came to be called Hebrews, or Israelites . Abraham was the son of Abraham, Abraham and the father of the Hebrews . Abraham became Abraham's son and father of Abraham's descendants, Abraham, and Abraham himself .
 The Pentateuch consists of the creation story found in Genesis and the books that explain the laws that became the basis of Judaism . It is based on the creation of the Bible .
 The Writings include the poetry of the Psalms and the Song of Solomon and wisdom books such as Job .
 The Prophet books recount stories of the Hebrew prophets, whose function was to warn the Hebrew people of the consequences of sin and to exort them to renew their religious faith .
 Judges in Hebrew culture were not judges in the modern sense; that is, they did not render legal decisions or determine punishments for crimes committed . Judges were not Judges in modern sense, but they were not legal in the sense of the modern era .
 They were those whom God had called to lead the tribe of Israel during critical times . They were not only those who had been called to do so, they were those who were called by God .
 Several judges, including Debo42, were also military leaders who advised the tribes where and when they should go into battle .
 Judges tells the history of the Israelites’ conquest of Canaan, later known as Palestine . Chapters 1-3 of Judges tell the history . of the Canaan conquest .
 The second section of the book of Judges, chapters 4-16, records the stories of various judges at the time . Deborah, Gideon, and Samson are among the judges in the book .
 The Canaanites, according to the Hebrew Bible, were under the command of Jabon, their king . The Canaanite were under Jabon's command .
 For 20 years Jabon had oppressed the children of Israel by destroying their vineyards, dishonoring their women, and murdering their children . Jabon was responsible for destroying the children's vineyards .
 Canaanites planned on conquering Israelites by severing connections between the Israelites in Galilee and those in the central hill country of Ephraim and Manasseh .
 In the face of impending doom, many Israelites had turned to the worship of idols . The Israelite had turned their worship to idol worship .
 Deborah felt a call to rise up against such fear and complacency, for she carried in her heart a fervent hope that God would come to her people’s rescue, provided that they honor him, she says . Deborah felt the call .
 Deborah directed him to go toward Mount Tabor and take 3,000 men of the children of Zebulun, according to Judges 4:6 . Deborah told him to take the men from Zebula and Tabor .
 She convinced Barak that the Lord would deliver the Canaanite General Sisera and his chariots into their hands . She convinced him that the General's chariots would be delivered to the hands of Barak .

 American patriot Molly Pitcher’s heroism during the Revolutionary War at the battle of Monmouth has been celebrated by American patriots ever since . Pitcher's heroism in the 17th century at Monmouth is celebrated by Americans ever since.
 Pitcher fought valiantly for seven years in the Pennsylvania State Regiment of Artillery . Pitcher served in the Army during his early years .
 She served as second in command at her husband’s artillery post . She swabbed the cannon's bore between shots, swabbing it between shots . Her husband died in 1918 .
 Mary Ludwig Hays, better known as Molly Pitcher, was the first American woman to receive a military pension from a state government . Her nickname is "Molly Pitcher," which most people know is her nickname .
 Last name may have been Ludwig, though this is in dispute, and derives from her carrying water in pitchers to thirsty soldiers during the Monmouth battle .
 In recognition of her services during the war, the Pennsylvania state legislature in 1822 awarded her payment of $40 immediately, with the same sum to be paid annually until her death .
 Her place of burial is recorded as Carlisle, Pennsylvania, Pennsylvania . Some claim she lies in the graveyard at West Point . Her burial place is unknown .
 Pitcher was born probably on October 3, 1754, near Trenton, New Jersey . She was possibly the daughter of John George Ludwig . Pitcher died in 1754 .
 Ludwig had immigrated from the German state of Palatinate in 1749 and had settled in Mercer County, New Jersey, where he and his family operated a dairy farm . Ludwig had moved to New Jersey from Germany and lived there with his family .
 Pitcher left home as a teenager to become a domestic servant at the home of Dr. Dr. David Pitcher . Pitcher was a domestic worker at the time of his marriage to Dr. James Pitcher. Pitcher died at the age of 92 .
 She met and married John Caspar Hays, the local barber, with whom she had one son, John L Hays . She had a son with him, John Hays; he died in 2007 .
 The American Revolution determined that the future of Great Britain’s 13 colonies, located on the Adantic seaboard of North America, would be as an independent nation, the United States . The United States was established in 17th century .
 Golonists demanding independence from Great Britain argued that humans have the right to seek liberty when oppressed . Thomas Jefferson and Thomas Paine were among those who argued for independence .

 Chinese revolutionary and poet Qiu Jin was one of the first women to protest traditional Chinese customs and advocate freedom for men and women .
 She incited women’s rebellion against social pressures in China . In a more radical position, she advocated and planned an uprising against the Manchu government .
 When government officials captured and beheaded her in 1907, she became a martyr in the revolutionary cause . She was captured by government officials and executed in 1907 .
 The Manchu dynasty (sometimes called the Ch’ing or Qing dynasty) took power in 1644 and ruled until 1911 . The Qing dynasty ruled China from 1644 to 1911 .
 Under Manchu rule, China became one of the greatest powers in the world, as well as richest and most sophisticated .
 The Manchus were nomadic warriors from Manchuria, but once they conquered China, they adopted Chinese culture to consolidate their rule . The Chinese people adopted Manchu culture in order to consolidate the rule .
 China grew prosperous under the Manchu dynasty, developing trade networks and a sophisticated, urban population . China's economic boom was largely due to the rise of modern urbanization .
 Agriculture became far more productive than it had ever been, and population growth began in earnest . Population growth began to grow in earnest in the early 1900s .
 By the 19th century, population growth began to exceed productivity, resulting in a large impoverished peasant population . The population of China's peasant population grew rapidly in the late 1800s and early 1900s .
 This segment of society began to rebel, and China was forced to make trade concessions with foreign nations . China has made concessions to foreign nations, forcing them to make concessions . China's economy has been hit hard by anti-government protests .
 Opium War or the Anglo-Chinese War had as its cause upper-class Chinese dependence on opium . The underlying issue was British access to Chinese markets, which the Manchu rulers resisted .
 The war resulted in a humiliating defeat by the British, leaving China at the mercy of European incursions . The war ended in a crushing defeat by China .

 The idea behind the table de remuage was to bring the sediment that formed at the bottom of the bottle to the top of the cork . The sediment formed in the sediment collected in the bottle, so that it could collect in a bottle .
 The bottle was then returned to its upright position, uncorked, emptied of sediment, and then recorked without losing any of its bubbly effervescence . Gradually, the bottle was returned .

 She submitted a plan to protect the legal rights of women and their children living in purdah . The practice of seclusion for women was inaugurated by Muslims and adopted by many Hindus in India .
 Purdah is a Persian word meaning curtain or curtain separating the secluded female quarters from the rest of the house . The curtain is a curtain separating women from the other parts of the home .
 Purdah also refers to the veil worn to cover the face, or the upper end of the Hindu sari that is drawn over to cover it . The veil is worn to keep women from public view .
 In some places, especially northern India, women ride in compartments in trains and buses separately from men . Women ride in different compartments of trains, buses and trains in some places .
 Even a subtle gesture, such as a woman lowering her eyes to avoid a man’s glance, is considered appropriate behavior in cultures that practice purdah .
 Evidence suggests purdah already existed in India before the Muslim invasion of India in the 1500s . Many Hindu authors contend that Purdah came to India by way of the Muslim Mogul conquest of India .
 During British rule of India in the 19th and 20th centuries, strict adherence to the practice of purdah was the norm . Purdah is still a popular name in India today .
 Muslims claim that the practice protects women from being seen as sex objects . Western feminists decry the practice as keeping women out of public life and “in their place” Muslims say it protects women .

 Sarah Walker was born Sarah Breedlove on December 23, 1867, in Delta, Louisiana . She was born to Owen and Minerva Breedlove, two emancipated slaves . Walker died in 1867 at the hands of freed slaves .
 The couple worked as sharecroppers on a cotton plantation in rural Louisiana . The couple's first marriage was a sharecropper . They later married and raised their own children .
 In 1878, the cotton crop failed, and a yellow fever epidemic spread over the delta country . The epidemic was the result of a cotton crop failure that led to the spread of yellow fever .
 Sarah fled from the sickness and joined her older sister in Vicksburg, Mississippi, where she earned a living as a domestic servant . Sarah's sister died of the sickness . Sarah was one of 80 business leaders and lawyers in the world .
 Moses McWilliams proposed to Sarah McWilliams at age 14 . She accepted his proposal as an escape from her overbearing brother-in-law .
 When the girl turned two, McWilliams suddenly died, possibly the victim of a lynching . McWilliams died when she was 2, possibly a victim of lynching.
 Sarah McWilliams vowed to give her daughter an education that she herself had never received . She vowed to help her daughter with an education she never received herself . Sarah's daughter was diagnosed with cancer at the age of 13 .
 Sarah worked as a laundress and domestic servant in St. Louis, Missouri, for the next 18 years . Sarah was a domestic servant and laundress for the rest of her life .
 In 1905, Lelia McWilliams graduated from Knoxville College; her mother was barely literate . McWilliams was born in Knoxville, Tennessee .
 As a washerwoman, Sarah spent hours leaning over a steaming washtub filled with hot water and chemical cleaning agents .
 She became convinced that the hair loss she began to notice was a result of her working conditions . The hair loss was caused by working conditions, she says .
 At home, she experimented with various chemicals that she hoped would restore hair growth . At home she experimented on various chemicals she hoped to use .
 Sometime between 1900 and 1905, she formulated a new product that she planned to market to black women . Many of whom were also domestics in St. Louis, she intended to market the new product .
 She kept the formula a secret, but most people assumed that the ingredient in it was sulphur . She kept it a secret .
 In 1906, Sarah moved to Denver, Colorado, where she married Charles Walker, a newspaperman . Sarah married Charles J Walker in 1906, and he died in 1953 .
 Walker's paper began to advertise Sarah’s product, and the advertisements offered a tonic that would improve hair growth boosted sales of the paper . Walker‘s paper started to advertise the tonic .
 Sarah realized that if such a comb could be made with a stronger material, it could be used to help the kinky hair of African Americans to look straighten . Walker combined the two products and dreamed up a marketing strategy, combining the tonic with the combs .
 When her business flourished in Denver, Walker realized that in a more populated area, it could expand even more . Walker moved to Indianapolis, Indiana, in order to expand her business even further .
 She recruited what she called “agent-operators, or specially trained salespeople, to accompany her as she pitched her products to black schools, churches, and clubs . She recruited them to pitch her products at black churches, schools, clubs .
 Segregation, Walker came to find out, benefited her business because it made it easier to hit customers where they lived . Segregation helped her business, Walker says .
 Walker began combining her business with philanthropic work after her divorce from Charles Walker in 1912 . Walker died in 1918 .
 Her agent-operators formed what were called Walker Clubs . The clubs competed with one another for prizes that Walker awarded to those who did the most charitable work .
 Walker handed $50 to each agent that had supported local churches or missionary societies . Walker handed out $50 for each agent who had supported missions .
 She had been a member of the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People since living in Indianapolis . She had lived in Indianapolis, Indiana .
 She purchased an opulent estate called Villa Lewaro on the banks of the Hudson River . The estate is located in New York City .
 Three years later, on May 25, 1919, she died, the black female equivalent of the rags-to-riches, pull-yourself-up-by-your-bootstraps self-made American success story . She died three years later .
 Oprah Winfrey is the first woman to produce and own her own television talk show . Winfrey made television history when her company, HARPO Productions, Incorporated, began producing The Oprah Show .
 The Oprah Winfrey Show spawned the talk show craze in the late 1980s and 1990s on American radio and television . Winfrey was voted one of the most influential people in the world in 1996 .
 In addition to her business career, Winfrey is an accomplished actress . Winfrey has been married to Oprah Winfrey for more than 20 years .
 Orpah Winfrey was born January 29, 1954, to unwed teenagers Vernita Lee and Vernon Winfrey . She was raised on her grandmother’s pig farm in Kosciusko, Mississippi . Oprah was raised by her grandmother on the farm .
 Oprah's grandmother taught Oprah to read and write . Oprah began recitations of sermons in the area’s black churches when she was just three years old . Oprah was just 3 when she began reading sermons at her grandmother's house .
 From the age of six to 13, Winfrey lived in Milwaukee with her mother, where she suffered abuse and sexual molestation from her mother’s male friends and relatives . Winfrey was molested by her mother's male friends, relatives, she says .
 At 13, Winfrey ran away from home to escape the abuse of her childhood home . Winfrey gave birth to a premature baby that died at 13, after having given birth to the child .
 Authorities arranged for Winfrey to live with her father in Nashville, Tennessee . There were no beds left in the center, authorities arranged for her to live in a hotel room .
 Discipline at the home of Vernon Winfrey and his wife Zelma helped Oprah develop her potential in school . Oprah Winfrey was disciplined at home by her father and mother .
 After graduating in 1976, she moved to Baltimore, where she first coanchored WJZ-TV’s news and then hosted a television talk show .
 The show’s ratings skyrocketed, and Winfrey knew she had found her niche . Winfrey's show's ratings soared, and she knew it was her niche.
 In less than a year, the show became that city’s most-watched local program . Chicago. Chicago .
 The station increased the program to one hour and changed the name to The Oprah Winfrey Show . The show was later renamed The Oprah Show .
 In 1986, the show went into syndication; in 1987, it won three Daytime Emmy Awards . The show won three Emmy Awards in 1987; in 1986, it was syndicated .

 In 1988, Winfrey organized HARPO Productions, Incorporated, which gained ownership of The Oprah Winfrey Show from ABC television . Winfrey is a multi-millionaire philanthropist .
 Besides the television show, HARPO also produced a highly rated TV miniseries, Gloria Naylor’s The Women of Brewster Place, in which Winfrey also starred .

 As a victim of the crime herself, her pleas have a particular poignancy . Her plea comes from the victim of a crime herself .

 The act established a national registry of child abusers to help employers, child-care providers, and schools by screening out abusers . The act was established in 2007 .
 She lives in Chicago, where she contributes to local schools and battered women’s shelters .
 The life of Victoria Woodhull offers historians an opportunity to look at the evolution of the women’s movement in the late 19th and early 20th centuries . Victoria Claflin was a businesswoman, publisher, and feminist activist .
 She and her sister, Tennessee Celeste Claflin, proselylytized their feminist message in their magazine, Woodhull and Claflins Weekly . She and sister wrote the magazine and weekly magazine .
 Claflin and Woodhull also became the first professional women stockbrokers . Claflins and Woodlull were the first women to become a professional stockbroker .
 Victoria Woodhull was, by any measure, one of the most talked-about women of the 19th century . She was one of Britain's most famous women in the early years of the century . Her story will be told in a new documentary on her life on BBC Radio 4
 Perhaps her biggest success was her ability to enliven the debate over feminism . She was a pioneer of feminism in the 1970s and 1980s .
 Victoria Woodhull was the seventh child of Reuben ‘Buck’ Claflin and Roxanna ‘Roxanna’s parents . She was born in Homer, Ohio, on September 23, 1838 .
 Buck Claflin, an alcoholic, operated a mill in Homer, but he and his family were run out of town . Officials suspected he had set fire to his own business for the insurance money .
 The Claflin family traveled around the south and midwest with their medicine and fortune-telling show .
 Victoria and Tennessee's performances were central to the family’s business . The two girls demonstrated their telepathic and clairvoyant abilities . The girls performed for the family .
 Audiences paid to have their fortunes told and to have the girls resurrect the spirits of their departed loved ones through a seance, or spiritualist sitting . Audiences also paid for the girls to resurrect their deceased loved ones .
 At 15 Victoria married an alcoholic physician named Canning Woodhull, by whom she had a son and a daughter . At 15 she married Canning, a physician, and had two children .
 Tennessee Claflin concocted a ‘healing elixir’ that she sold on the side of her career .
 The traveling medicine and fortune-telling show thrived on the sisters’ performances . The family began appearing in larger midwestern cities such as Cincinnati and Chicago .
 Two years later, the sisters devised a new moneymaking scheme . It was an outgrowth of their careers in quackery .
 Victoria Woodhull was the first American woman to run for president . Cornelius Vanderbilt solicited her help in the campaign . She was a millionaire businessman .
 Cornelius Vanderbilt invested in Woodhull, Claflin & Company in September 1869 . Victoria and Tennessee opened the brokerage firm in 1869.
 After investing to the extent of several thousand shares in some of our principal stocks and selling others, they departed, the observed of all observers . They left the Wall Street in the early hours of Sunday morning .
 The Herald clearly did not expect women to know anything about the stock market, or to have any of their own money to invest .
 She meant for her financial endeavors to provide the backing for her political ambition, she said . She said she meant for the financial endeavor to provide for her ambition .
 Woodhull and Andrews preached communal child rearing and “free love,” the right of men and women to have as many sexual partners as they choose . In addition to women’s rights, they preached communal re-parenting and free love .
 In late 1870s, she moved briefly to Washington, D.C., where she lobbied for woman suffrage .
 She succeeded where Susan B ANTHONY and Elizabeth Cady STANTON had failed . She succeeded . Susan BANTHONY succeeded where she succeeded .
 On January 11, 1871, Woodhull addressed the House Judiciary Committee on the subject of woman suffrage . He articulates a radical means of implementing women’s rights .
 The suffrage movement, believing that it must retain respectability in order to be successful, distanced itself from Woodhull . The suffragist movement believed that it would be successful if it was successful .
 When Cornelius Vanderbilt remarried in 1870, he withdrew his support from her, and her brokerage floundered . Vanderbilt's widow died in 1881 .
 She began turning against Wall Street financiers by publishing Karl Marx’s Communist Manifesto in her newspaper Woodhull and Claflins Weekly .
 She was financially supporting her ill parents and former husband, Canning Woodhull . She was also financially supporting herself and her former husband .
 Just when her fortunes seemed at their lowest, however, Woodhull came up with another new scheme . Just when she was at her lowest, she decided to start a new scheme to help her family .
 She resurrected Woodhull and Claflins Weekly, which had stopped publication in 1872, in order to expose the love affair between Reverend Henry Ward Beecher and his partner, Elizabeth Tilton, both married to others .
 As word of the indiscretion spread, copies of Woodhull and Claflins skyrocketed . Copy sales skyrocketed after the scandal broke out .
 She demanded his admission of the affair and condemned him for refusing to condone free love . Instead, she demanded he admit to the affair .
 Woodhull claimed to have learned of the Beecher-Tilton affair through her own lover, none other than Elizabeth Tilton’s husband, Theodore. Theodore .
 Woodhull was arrested twice during the incident for publishing indecent material . He was later arrested for publishing the material .
 In 1877 Woodhull moved to England, where she married a prosperous banker, John Biddulph Martin, in 1881 . In 1881 she moved to London and married a wealthy banker .
 The Many Lives of Victoria Woodhull was published by Bridgehampton, N.Y.: Bridge Works Publishers, 1995 . She died of a heart attack in 1994 .
 Women’s historians have traditionally focused on political issues, such as woman suffrage . Historians in general tend to view the nation's politics as a nation's story . Women's historians have focused on issues such as women's rights and women's suffrage in the past .
 Beginning in the 1970s, many women's historians shifted the focus to social changes that affected women’s lives as much as politics .

 In 1849, Amelia Bloomer founded her own temperance periodical called the Lily . The Lily was a temperance magazine .
 The temperance movement began in the 19 th century and culminated with passage of the 1918 Volstead Act, which prohibited the sale of alcoholic beverages . Temperance laws were passed in 1918 .
 In the antebellum period, convention held that it was improper for women to speak in public . Convention held that women were not allowed to speak .

 Amelia Bloomer considered woman suffrage to be secondary to temperance . She considered women suffrage a secondary issue for temperance and women's rights . Bloomer herself considered the issue to be more important than temperance to women .
 In 1851, Bloomer donned the radical dress that would ultimately bear her name when she lectured on temperance . Bloomer wore the dress to lecture about temperance in 1851 .
 Elizabeth Smith Miller, daughter of Elizabeth Cady Stanton’s cousin Gerrit Smith, designed the costume . It consisted of a pair of Turkish-style full-legged trousers, topped with a short skirt .
 The Lily promoted the pants as a comfortable garment that would increase women’s mobility . The Lily promotes the pants to be comfortable .
 Bloomer became a celebrity, and circulation of her journal increased eightfold . Bloomer's journal became famous and her journal became a sensation .
 Bloomer grew cautious in the face of the sensation caused by the costume, and she stopped wearing it . Bloomer, however, grew cautious and stopped wearing the costume .

 Gabrielle Bonheur Chanel was born in Saumur, Maine-et-Loire, in central France, on August 19, 1883 . Her mother died when she was young, and her father disappeared after he deposited his daughters at an orphanage .
 While at the orphanage, Chanel learned to sew, and she spent weekends watching her aunt Julia decorate hats . Chanel's aunt Julia taught Chanel to sew .
 During her teenage years, Chanel worked in Deauville, France, on the north coast, at a hat factory . Chanel also worked at the factory during her time at the age of 16 .
 She attracted the attention of a young officer, Etienne Balsan, and soon became his mistress . She attracted her attention to the young officer and soon was his mistress. She was married to a young French officer .
 He helped her open her own millinery (an old-fashioned term for a ladies’ hat shop) in Compiegne, France .
 In 1919, after the war, Chanel founded a couture house on the rue Cambon, again with Balsan’s backing . The house was founded with the backing of the French couturist .
 Chanel invented and borrowed what would come to be known as the classic Chanel look .
 The credit for ridding the world of the corset belongs to a rival French designer, Paul Poiret . He abolished it in 1906 and cut his models’ hair in 1908 . The corset was abolished by a rival designer in 1906 .
 Chanel made these styles popular among ordinary women, not just Paris fashion models . The styles were made popular among women not only Paris models, but also ordinary women .
 She borrowed from men's fashions to enhance the new independence women were gaining throughout the world . And she borrowed from the men’s fashion .
 It seemed that in order to gain equality in a man’s world, women were going to have to start looking like them . It seemed to be that women would have to look like men .
 During the 1920s, with Chanel’s help, women shed the hourglass figure and exchanged it for no figure at all . Chanel's help, with the help of Chanel, helped women shed hourglass figures .
 From her English nephew she borrowed the man’s blazer, adopting the cuffed shirt and cuff links as well .
 In addition to the blazer, Chanel’s other fashion items imitated military clothing . The blazer was Chanel's first attempt at fashion .
 She adopted a pair of sailors’ pants, their pea jackets, striped maillots, and sailor hats . The 90-year-old has adopted a set of sailor hats for herself .
 The actress borrowed the essence of military clothing for everyday use . She adopted the fashions for women’s wear .
 Easy-care fabrics, previously considered ‘cheap, but ideal for the military, became fashionable among working women . The fabrics are now fashionable among women in the military .
 Gone were the stuffy Victorian dresses with the prudishness they implied . Gone, then, were the dresses with a thingy Victorian dress .
 After the war, during the “Jazz Age’s 1920s, and beyond, women were enjoying themselves, and their fashions exemplified this fact . After the anxieties of the war .
 Chanel popularized the suntan during the Victorian era . Chanel used to use parasols to shield their white skin from the sun .
 Chanel’s empire expanded from one couture house on the rue Cambon to eight houses . Chanel's empire expanded to eight couture houses in Paris .
 At her peak, in the 1950s, she was dressing the world, not only from the sales from her own lines, but by virtue of imitations, of which there were many . At the height of her career, she became a global fashion icon .
 Chanel did not object; it is, as she noted, it is a visible sign of success to be copied . Chanel says it is "a visible symbol of success" for success .
 By the 1930s, hemlines dropped again, and the worldwide economic depression meant that fewer and fewer women could buy Chanel’s fashions .
 When World War II broke out in 1939, Chanel spent the war years holed up in her Paris apartment .
 People were ready to cast off the sadness of the war years, and attention turned to casual fashions . Again, people were ready .
 Julia Child embarked on an extended tour to promote her new book The Way to Cook in 1989 . The 77-year-old food expert was an energetic, spunky bundle of delight . Julia Child is a celebrity chef and author .

 In the 19th century, the Victorian ‘separate sphere’ ideology held that women presided over the domestic sphere, including the kitchen, while men shaped the public realm .

 Most “better” restaurants hired professional male chefs who had been schooled in the culinary arts . Yet while women continued cooking in the home, most restaurants hired male chefs .

 Endo Hatsuko contributed to the westernization of Japan, particularly in the areas of fashion and wedding customs . Hatsuko was a fashion consultant, businesswoman and fashion consultant .
 Endo also departed from Japanese convention by becoming a businesswoman on her own, apart from either her father or her husband . Endo was born in Tokyo, Japan, in 1945 .
 She gradually commercialized the practice of purchasing bridal costumes and makeup for the wedding ceremony . She gradually became more commercialized in the 1930s .
 Endo offered makeup for Japanese women in general; next, she specialized in wedding wear and makeup . Endo is known for her work as a makeup artist .
 Brides-to-be can buy bridal apparel, booking services for the ceremony and reception, and decorations for the entire event . Finally, she began offering brides-for-be a full line of apparel and booking services .
 Endo’s bridal wear empire began during the Meiji Restoration , a period characterized as the beginning of the modern era in Japanese history . Endo founded the bridalwear empire in Japan .
 Japan began working toward instituting a modern, industrial state in 1868 . In 1868 the feudal system, controlled by the samurai warriors, was abolished . The samurai had ruled Japan since the 12th century .
 Finance Minister Masayoshi Matsukata established the Bank of Japan and took other measures to stimulate economic growth . Finance Minister established the bank of Japan in 1981 .

 In the early 1900s, she opened a beauty salon in the newly established Ginza district in Ginza .
 Ginza is the main shopping, commercial, and entertainment area of Tokyo . The Ginza area is located near the Imperial Palace . It is located in Ginza, Japan's main shopping area .
 The mint was closed by the government in 1868 . Linked to fraudulent practices, however, it was closed due to a lack of transparency .
 Ginza became the first westernized district in all of Japan after the Meiji Restoration . It features wide, tree-lined streets and imported goods from Europe and the U.S.
 Endo Hatsuko introduced Western makeup for women in her ‘grooming parlor’ as her business was called . Hatsuko's business was known as a "grooming parlor for women .
 Makeup was first brought to Japan by the Chinese and Koreans in the sixth century . Makeup is an important part of Japanese culture, first brought in by Koreans and Chinese .
 Traditionally, aristocratic women wore heavy white face makeup, red rouge on the lips, and painted their eyebrows .
 Until the 18th century, they also blackened their teeth after they married . The 18th-century blackened teeth after the marriage .
 Smiling was literally frowned upon, since a wide-mouthed grin revealed white teeth that tended to look yellowish next to the whitened skin . Smiling is frowned upon in the United States .
 By the 20th century, most Japanese women no longer wore white face makeup or kimonos every day . By the 1950s, most women were no longer wearing the same face makeup .
 Geisha are Japanese women entertainers known for their dancing and musical skills . Geisha is a Japanese woman entertainer known for her dancing and singing skills .
 First officially recognized as an occupation in the 18th century, geisha entertained men and their courtesans in ‘pleasure districts” in larger Japanese cities . Geisha entertain men and women in "pleasure areas" in larger cities .
 They were not prostitutes, although they were usually involved with their patrons . They were usually sexually involved with the patrons .
 Young girls were sometimes indentured to a geisha house, where they acted as maids and then as apprenticed geisha . Young girls acted as servants, maids or apprentices geisha.
 During the 19th century, geisha were acknowledged as trendsetters, acting as fashion weather vanes for the rest of Japanese society . Geisha were accepted as trendsettingters in Japan, and acted as trend-setters .
 They dressed in opulent kimonos and wore heavy makeup of the upper class . The upper class wore heavy make-up and wore opulent clothing .
 Today, they have become the upholders of Japanese traditions, rather than the trendsetters . They have become an upholder of traditional Japanese traditions .
 Before Endo started her business, geisha and other women made the white makeup by combining white rice bran with lead, later discovered to be toxic . Endo's business is based in Tokyo, Japan .
 Endo began offering her services as a wedding consultant in addition to her grooming parlor business . Endo is now offering her wedding consultant services for clients .
 In later years, her business developed into a full bridal service shop . Customers could shop for their wedding kimonos, purchase makeup, have their hair done, and make arrangements for the ceremony .
 Most Japanese men and women meet each other and form relationships without outside help . But during the ceremony many couples still designate a go-between, or nakodo, for the sake of tradition .
 A majority of Japanese are married in a Shinto ceremony, though Buddhist and Christian ceremonies are also common . A majority are done in Shinto ceremonies .
 At a Shinto ceremony, the bride and groom kneel before an altar as a priest purifies them, and then they drink from three cups of sake three times . The ceremony is held in Japan .

 Japanese fashion designer Kawakubo Rei’s fashions may seem distorted, misshapen, and even anarchical in their refusal to follow Western ideals of feminine beauty .
 To the Japanese eye, her clothing reflects the search for shibusa, or the ultimate beauty found in nature . Her clothing reflects a search for beauty, or beauty, in Japan .
 Kawakubo’s worn and torn clothing reflects the Japanese word sabi, the way natural objects fade with time . The worn and worn clothes reflect the Japanese term sabi .
 Sabi connotes the repose or state of decline when, for example, blossoms reach their full bloom and then begin to curl, dropping their petals . Sabi is the name of a species of flower that is declining in the wild .
 Mimicking nature, Kawakubo deconstructs fabric and then remakes it into a fashionable garment . Kawakuubo's work is inspired by nature and the process of fashion .

 Finnish designer and businesswoman Armi Ratia based her design empire on the notion that a nation’s landscape and cultural heritage could be recreated on a bolt of fabric .
 Ratias focus on Finland was due, in part, to the history of her homeland Karelia, an area of contention between Finland and the Soviet Union . Ratias' focus was due to her homeland's history with the Soviet-Finland border .
 She started her design firm, Marimekko, after World War II when Scandinavian design and architecture gained worldwide fame . Her modernist, entrepreneurial creativity seemed to mock its communist neighbor to the east .
 Finnish-born Eero Saarinen and Alvar Aalto created and popularized a Finnish design aesthetic . Together, architects and designers like Alvar and Eero were influential architects .
 Karelia is a rural, sparsely populated farming republic located in northwestern Russia . It is bordered by Finland to the west, Russia to the east, the White Sea to the north, and Lake Ladoga to the south .
 Eastern Karelia became part of Russia in 1323; Russian Czar Peter the Great wrested it from Sweden in 1721 . Peter the Czar of Russia wrested Western Karelia from Sweden in 1721; Eastern Kelaiya was part

 Following the Russo-Finnish war of 1939-40, Western Karelia again passed into Soviet hands . However, following the Soviet victory in the Russo-finnish war, Western Karelia was taken back into Russian hands .
 Four million Finnish refugees fled the Soviet Union in 1947 . Armi Ratia and her husband, Viljo Ratia, were among the refugees .

 The first American woman professional interior decorator, de Wolfe, encouraged millions of American home owners to junk their overstuffed, heavy Victorian furniture and impractical knickknacks .
 De Wolfe linked her new, airy interiors to the emancipated female, making interior design an acceptable profession for independent-minded career women .
 As a teenager, de Wolfe learned how to socialize with the upper crust . Her customers would later form her primary customers .

 Like many Americans in the 1920s, she obsessed over new machines, and the technology that went in to building them . She was fascinated by machines and technology .
 Bourke-White went on to develop what biographer Theodore M Brown called the Machine Aesthetic, a new way of portraying machines as objects of art .

 During World War II Bourke-White was the first woman photographer accredited with the U.S. Air Force . She was also the only photojournalist in Moscow during the German bombing of the city .
 She took perhaps her best-known photographs of the liberation of the Nazi concentration camp Buchenwald in 1945 . She was one of the most famous photographers of the day .
 After the war, Bourke-White used her camera to imprint the image of India’s liberator Mahatma Gandhi hours before he was assassinated, as well as the labor strife in the diamond mines of South Africa .
 In 1952, as a United Nations correspondent during the Korean War, she photographed the conflict from the Korean citizens’ perspective, rather than the American soldier .
 Bourke-White experienced her share of reproach during her adventurous career . Bourke White was one of the world's most famous female celebrities .
 She and Caldwell defended themselves against the charge that they made up the captions to their photos of sharecroppers in You Have Seen Their Faces . Caldwell: "You have seen their faces"
 The FBI believed Bourke-White to be a Communist sympathizer during the 'red' scare of the 1950s . The FBI monitored her activities and searched her luggage during the ‘red’ scare .
 As Bourke-White battled Parkinson’s disease for the last 19 years of her life, she had her colleague Alfred Eisenstaedt photograph her experimental brain surgery and recovery .
 The 1989 film Double Exposure recounts her experiences with the disease . The film was released in 1989 and was made into Double Exposure .
 Byzantine princess and historian Anna Comnena wrote a history of her father Alexius I Comnenus and his Byzantine Empire called the Alexiad . She was a princess with lofty but thwarted ambitions .
 Comnena’s high position at court allowed her to access key information that would otherwise have gone unnoticed, court officials said . Comnene’�s position allowed her access to key information, the court said .
 The princess masterfully synthesized vast amounts of complex detail in a lively and engaging narrative history . The film is set in New York City, New York .
 Throughout the Alexiad, readers are treated to the glories and shortcomings of the Byzantine Empire and its culture . The book is published in New York, New York and London .
 The Byzantine Empire was the eastern half of the Roman Empire . It included eastern Europe, parts of southern Europe, northern Africa, and the Middle East . It was also known as the Byzantine Empire .
 Rome's eastern realm differed from Rome in its Grecian and Middle Eastern influences . The eastern realm was ruled by Rome in the early Roman times .
 Constantinople was more commercialized and claimed a greater degree of wealth . Constantinople was the Byzantine counterpart to Rome, the Byzantine equivalent to Rome .
 Byzantine emperors considered themselves the rightful heirs of Rome . They harbored dreams of subduing the “barbarian” populations to the west and creating a Byzantine lake .
 Byzantine Empire faced threats from its northern and eastern enemies, including the Normans and the Seljuk Turks . Their ambitions went unrealized, however, as the Byzantine empire faced threats .
 Comnena’s father, Alexius I, vowed to conquer the Seljuk Turks of Asia Minor who had defeated the Empire in 1071 and gained control of Jerusalem . The Empire was defeated by the Turks in the 1071-1072 .
 Urban II gathered a Christian army in 1095 and over the next two years the soldiers drilled in Constantinople and its envirals to prepare for the march across Asia Minor . The soldiers drilled for the two years in the city and envirations of the city to prepare .
 First Crusaders slaughtered the Muslim and Jewish inhabitants of Jerusalem in 1099 . They descended into Jerusalem on July 15, 1099, where they slaughtered the Muslims and Jews . The Crusaders massacred the Muslim, Jewish inhabitants .
 Anna Comnena, heir to the throne as the daughter of Alexius I and Irene Ducas, received a thorough education in the Bible and in the Roman and Greek classics .
 She also wrote a treatise on gout, a painful disease of the joints . She also studied medicine and later wrote a book about gout .
 At the age of 14, Constantine Ducas, son of Michael VII and cousin in her mother’s family, asked her to be his bride . Her mother died in 2011 at age of 92 .
 When Ducas died unexpectedly later that year, she married Nicephorus Bryennius, a soldier who had participated in the First Crusade . She was later married to a soldier from the First Crusades .
 Comnena’s parents had given birth to a son, John, who, as the only male heir of Alexius I, was favored to ascend the throne . In 1088, John was the only son favored to be the heir to Alexius II .
 Comnena never got over this cruel turn of fate, and she ruthlessly conspired with her mother to thwart her younger brother’s fortune . The pair conspired to thwart their younger brother's fortune .
 Nicephorus Bryennius’s unwillingness to be party to her scheme secured its failure and uncovered the attempt . Nicephius Bryennus was not part of the scheme .
 Comnena appeared prostrate before her brother, whose clemency spared her life . John II forced her to rescind her inheritance, though John II made her rescind the inheritance .
 The humble preface to the work tells readers that her purpose in writing was to save the past from oblivion, and that it is “God above” who has given her the ability to write her tome .
 Fifteen books cover the period 1067 to 1118, including the 12 years prior to her father’s reign . Fifteen of the books are published by the Queen of England .
 Comnena plundered the state archives to uncover diplomatic correspondences and imperial decrees to write her history . The queen's history was revealed in a series of letters and letters to the Spanish queen .

 Arabella Jenkinson was born in Hoxton, a district of London, to Richard and Eleanor Deane Jenkinson . The diarist died in 1947 at the age of 31 .
 Arabella Jenkinson struggled to live a pious, or devoted and conscientiously religious, life . Following her ninth year, Arabella struggled with her religious beliefs .
 What was considered ‘lively’ in 18th-century England was quite different from today’s interpretation today. What was “lively,’ was very different from our interpretation today .
 Activities that we might consider entertaining and fun today were considered to be of little value to the religious then . Since earthly life was seen as a preparation for eternal life, activities that we consider today were seen as little value .
 She loved to read novels, a new type of literature in the 18th century . She enjoyed satires; neither of which would be religious in nature .
 Happy endings usually resulted when the knight saved the heroine by sweeping her away into a safe marriage . Happy endings were usually happy endings when the heroine was saved by a knight .
 Satires, such as the play Rape of the Lock Ytmten by Alexander Pope a few decades prior to Arabella’s birth, poked fun at human vice or folly by using wit and irony . Satires such as Alexander Pope used wit to poke fun at vice by using
 Most satires were not meant to reflect religious or spiritual morals . Like novels, most satires are not intended to reflect moral morals .
 Arabella Jenkinson loved to dress up in fine clothes, and walk about the streets of London, displaying her finery .
 This was considered to be an earthly activity that took time away from religious contemplation . This, too, was considered a time off religious contemplation.
 At the age of 21, Arabella Jenkinson married Edward Davies, a widower with four children . The couple had four children together . Arabella married Davies at 21 .
 Edward helped his wife’s efforts to pursue a more religious life, as he was a preacher . Edward was also a preacher, helping his wife's efforts to become more religious .
 Arabella was constantly either pregnant or nursing her children, and caring for her stepchildren . Arabella became pregnant and nursed her children for the rest of her life .
 Before cures for childhood illnesses became available in the early 20th century, many parents knew the heart-wrenching experience of helplessly watching their own children die .
 Most parents now do not assume that having a child will result in losing the mother’s life . Although dying from childbirth is not a completely unheard-of experience in our own time, most parents now don’t assume it will happen .
 For women of the 18th century, death at childbirth was a real fear . For women, it was not easy to deal with death at birth .
 Complications at childbirth, such as loss of blood, could not be rectified, as midwives had no knowledge or means of blood transfusions .
 Conditions under which women birthed babies were not sterile, and infections frequently killed mothers . Conditions under conditions under which babies were born were often not sterile . Infections were frequently killed by infections .
 There was little birth control available and what was available was considered taboo or sinful . At the same time, if a woman married, childbirth was virtually inevitable . Birth control was virtually impossible, as there was little .
 Birth control devices, such as condoms, were linked with prostitution and, therefore, with immorality and sin . Condoms were linked to prostitution and therefore, as a form of sin .
 Arabella Jenkinson knew that her life was in danger when she married . Arabella's life was literally in danger after she got married to Arabella .
 As women were economically dependent upon men, most felt that they had little choice but to marry . And yet, as women felt economically dependent on men, they felt that there was no choice . Most women felt they were forced to marry in order to survive .
 Infant mortality was part of the everyday life of parents of young children born before the 20th century . Infants were part of daily life for parents of children born around the world before the first century .
 It is fair to say, however, that death in general was much more part of everyday life then than it is now . It was also more common in the 1930s and '50s than in the '60s, but it's not now as common as now .
 In the 20th century, modern medicine began to prolong the lives of people, and to make long life generally healthier . Modern medicine has made long life longer and generally healthier for people .

 Egeria was a traveler and diarist who wrote sometime in the fifth century . She may not have expected what she recorded in her diary would be useful someday .
 In 1884, an Italian archaeologist found Egeria’s journal in the library of the Brotherhood of Mary, a Catholic monastery, in Italy .
 He believed that what he found in the diary would be important to scholars of history, so he had the diary translated into other languages .
 Most of the content of her diary related information about the lands through which she traveled and about the religious ceremonies and rituals performed by the Christian church .
 She also wrote about the status of women and the roles that women played within the different churches she visited .
 Given its age (the diary is approximately 1,500 years old), Egeria’s work is in remarkably good shape . The diary is estimated to be in remarkably excellent condition .
 The end of the end of it has not been found, and even part of the middle is lost .
 The parts of the diary that we do have do not give us very much information about the woman who wrote it . It is not known who the diary was written by .
 Scholars are unsure exactly when Egeria lived and when she wrote her diary . Scholars are even uncertain exactly when she lived, and when her diary began .
 Historians who have studied Egerias diary have made several assumptions about the author based upon the content of her work . Historians have made assumptions about Egeria's work based on her diary .
 This process of conjecture is not foolproof, but it is the best that historians can do until more information may come to light . More information may be revealed in the future .
 Travel in the fifth century was only possible for those who had money . From other sources, such as ecclesiastical documents and histories, we know that travel in the . fifth century . We know that . travel .
 Egeria came from a wealthy family, which in turn meant that her family had high social status . It is likely, then, that she was likely to have come from a rich family . Her family is likely to be wealthy, which means that she had a high status .
 Egeria described the deference with which she was received, and she did not question it . Historians also make this conjecture based upon the diary .
 We can assume that Egeria was well educated for a woman of her time . Obviously she was literate and well versed in the scriptures of the Christian church, particularly the Bible .
 Egeria seems to have written her diary to other women of the Christian church, who lived together as a community within the church and according to church rules . Such women were known as canonesses, known as Canonesses .
 These women oversaw sacraments such as baptisms and funerals . These women took care of the rituals of the church .

 Many Christians view the Hebrew Bible as simply part of the Christian Bible . This is unusual, because Hebrews do not use the word saint in the Bible .
 The length of the church services and the rigors practiced are excessive compared to more recent times, the church says . The length and rigoriness of church services are excessive, the priest says .
 Diaries and other writings of early Christians enabled the church to become familiar with, and therefore more united within, their religious faith community, regardless of the distances separating them . Early Christians were familiar with each other, and were united within their faith community .
 There is no record of the circumstances under which Egerias died, or even whether she ever returned from her journey .

 In a time in which pregnancy was fairly dangerous and threatened women’s lives, becoming a canoness may have seemed attractive alternative to many .

 She began to perceive writing as speaking, and she crafted the written stories that were based on interviews much more like actual person-to-person conversations than sterile reports .

 Anne Frank was born on June 12, 1929, to Otto and Edith Hollander Frank, upper-middle-class German Jews living in Frankfurt, Germany . Anne Frank is the daughter of Otto Frank, a German Jew living in Germany .
 Otto Frank’s family had lost their fortune in the poor economy of the 1920s . But he managed to establish himself in Frankfurt's business world as a banker . Otto Frank was a banker in the 1930s .
 When Adolf Hitler became chancellor of Germany in 1933, Nazi intentions soon became clear . Hitler's plans for the Nazi state of Germany were soon to be overtaken .

 The Franks could not escape Nazism, however, when the German army invaded the Netherlands in 1940 .

 Deportation of Jews to concentration camps, especially Auschwitz, began in 1942 . Auschwitz was one of the most notorious concentration camps in Nazi Germany .
 Otto and Edith Frank had prepared their two daughters for this eventuality by securing a hiding place in the warehouse where he worked . Otto Frank had been working at the time of his death . Edith and Otto Frank's two daughters had secured their hiding place .

 Martha Gellhorn, American journalist, reported on 20th-century wars from Spain in the 1930s to Panama in the 1980s . Martha reported on wars in Spain, Spain, Panama, Panama and Spain .
 Kennedy's writing style attracted six decades of intellectually oriented American readers in magazines such as The New Statesman and The Atlantic Monthly .
 In 1989, at the age of 81, Gellhorn again found her way to another war front, when the U.S. invaded Panama . The war veteran was in Panama when the United States invaded Panama in 1989 .
 She had been invited to report on the 1992 war in Bosnia, but decided to stay home . Concerned that she was no longer as nimble as she used to be, she stayed home .
 To professional journalists, Gellhorn’s combination of objective reporting and personal writing style may seem inappropriate . But as a war correspondent she blends the two forms of writing to adequately represent the suffering of ordinary people on one hand and scrutinize the political upheavals that cause the wars
 The author is able to examine the horrors of combat, analyze the political background, and denounce the injustices inherent in all wars, in a personal manner .
 As a fiction writer, Gellhorn drops all objectivity and creates characters that grapple with the same issues she uncovered as a reporter .
 Gellhorn was born in a St. Louis, Missouri, family steeped in a tradition of service and reform . She believed her own contribution to improving society lay in her pen . She was born into a family of reformers .
 Her maternal grandmother spoke out in favor of the eight-hour day for servants . She organized a school for training domestics using scientific methodology . The school was set up by her grandmother .
 Her mother, Edna Fischel, advocated woman suffrage and organized a local League of Women Voters chapter . George Gellhorn, her father, was a medical doctor, and her mother was a suffragist .
 In 1937, during the Spanish Givil War, Gellhorn began her career as a journalist by covering the conflict for Colliers Weekly . She arrived in Madrid carrying only a backpack and fifty dollars in cash .
 She quickly met two other American reporters, Robert Capa and Ernest Hemingway . Her lifelong friend and lifelong friend is Robert Capo . She met Capa in New York City .
 The two seasoned men taught the young cub reporter the tricks of wartime journalism . They taught him how to distinguish between various kinds of gunfire, how to know when danger is imminent .
 Gellhorn’s articles on the Spanish Civil War inaugurated a long relationship between the magazine and its reporter . Colliers' coverage of the war in Spain began in the 1930s .
 When the war ended, Gellhorn continued traveling through Europe, covering the advancement of fascism in Germany and Italy . He continued to travel until the end of the war .
 She was the first correspondent to arrive in Finland after the Russians invaded the nation without formally declaring war in 1939 in 1939 .
 In 1939, she created her first work of fiction based on her experiences as a reporter . Her first novel was published in 1939 .
 A Stricken Field is set in Prague, Prague, on the eve of Hitler’s control of Sudetenland . The film was set in the Czech capital, Prague . It is based on the story of World War II in the early 1930s .
 Gellhorn’s novels during the early 1940s, including The Heart of Another {\9A\) and Liana, received only polite nods by critics . Her journalism won high praise .
 In 1948, Gellhorn applied the best of her talents as a journalist and combined that with well-developed fictional characters . The Wine of Astonishment was published in 1948 and sold for £16.99 .
 The battle took place between December 1944 and January 1945 as an unsuccessful attempt on the part of the German army to drive a wedge into the Allied forces’ defensive line .

 During the 1950s and 1960s, Gellhorn continued reporting on armed conflicts throughout the world . During the 1960s and 1950s, he continued reporting .

 In “Eichmann and the Private Gonscience”, Gellhorn raises the question of the nature of morality and the human conscience . Gellorn raises the questions of morality, morality and conscience .
 Gellhorn has reported on events in Europe, Vietnam, Israel, El Salvador, and Nicaragua for such publications as Colliers, The Guardian, and The New Statesman . She made her home wherever she worked .
 Divorced from Hemingway in 1945, she married Thomas Matthews in 1954, a union that ended in divorce 10 years later . She had a second marriage to Thomas Matthews, who died in 1954 .

 Bessie Amelia Emery was born in Pietermaritzburg, South Africa, July 6, 1937 . She was born to an upperclass white Scottish mother and a black African father . She is one of the world's most famous women .
 When Bessie Emery was seven months pregnant and could no longer hide her affair with a black man, her family had incarcerated her . Emery's affair with the black man led to her being incarcerated .
 Zulu man worked in the family stables in Zulu . He was a Zulu worker in his family's stables .
 Bessie Emery’s family rejected their granddaughter, sending her to be raised by a mixed-race woman, Nellie Heathcote, and her husband George . Emery's family rejected her and she was sent to live with Heathcotes and George .
 When she was 13, the Heathcotes sent her to a missionary orphanage and school for colored girls in Durban . She was 13 when she was sent to an orphanage . She is now a successful lawyer and lawyer .
 School officials said her mother had been in the mental hospital because she was insane, not because of racial prejudices . School officials told her that her mother was in the hospital because of a mental illness .
 The orphanage allowed Bessie to read her mother's files, where she discovered her mother’s affection for her and the fact that she had left money for her education . Later, she discovered that her mother had left her money to pay for education .
 She completed her teaching certificate in 1957 and took a job teaching primary school at Clairwood Coloured School in Clairwood .
 Through an influential friend, Margaret Cadmore, she had had a short story published in a children's literature anthology in 1951 .
 In 1958, she began her career as a journalist, working for the Golden City Post, a Cape Town, South Africa, weekly tabloid with a black readership . She is best known for her work in Cape Town .
 The paper carefully avoided major issues of racial unrest that would offend the government . But on minor issues it cried out against racism and enforced segregation .

 She wrote for a literary and political magazine called Drum and later The New African . Soon after, she moved to Johannesburg, where she wrote for the magazine Drum . She later moved to the city to write for a monthly journal .
 The editors and writers of both publications, including Head, were nationalists who supported the African National Congress . Head was a member of the organization devoted to ridding the nation of white supremacists .
 The ANC had been banned in South Africa in 1960, following the state of emergency declared in response to the ANC’s national campaign against the South African government . The ANC was banned in the country in 1960 .
 The security police confiscated two issues of The New African, charging it under the Obscene Publications Act . Security police confiscated the two issues under Obscene Publication Act .
 She returned to Cape Town in 1960, where she started her own political broadsheet . She returned in 1960 to start a political newspaper .
 Great Britain rejected South African participation in the British Commonwealth (due to its apartheid policies) and the nation became a republic in 1961 .
 Now, the former European colony was on its own, but its racial policies of segregation and discrimination became more onerous . Now, it is now a nation of African Americans .
 Bessie met and married journalist Harold Head that year . The two began writing for The New African and a Ugandan publication Transition .
 Bessie also left South Africa with a one-way visa to take a teaching job at Tshekedi Memorial School in Serowe, Bechuanaland .
 Bechuanaland was a British protectorate at the time; however, it too gained independence from Great Britain in 1966 and was renamed Botswana . Botswana gained independence in 1966 .
 Eking out a sparse existence, Head lived in a house that lacked electricity, and she typed by candlelight . Head was forced to live in a home that had no electricity . Head typed by candles and used a typewriter .
 She and other political refugees formed a farm cooperative, through which she marketed her homegrown fruits and vegetables . She and others form a farm co-opetition to sell their produce .
 During this period, she began the second phase of her career, writing and publishing novels and short stories .
 She also suffered from mental depression, made worse by the prospect that the government of Botswana might be persuaded to deport her back to South Africa .
 She was admitted to a psychiatric institution on a couple of occasions in the late 1960s and early 1970s . Eventually, she was admitted in a psychiatric hospital .
 In Botswana, she met people full of greed and ambition . In South Africa, where blacks were oppressed, she saw no such traits . Head wrote to the editor of The New African, Randolph Vigne, in a letter .
