 Her masterpiece, A Question of Power, is a semiautobiographical account of a woman’s mental illness and breakdown . Her masterpiece is A Question Of Power . Her work is published in New York, New York .
 Noni Jabavu grew up in a mixed culture of Xhosa (pronounced “Kussa”) tribal traditions and English Christian colonialism .
 Jabavu became the first black person and first woman editor of The New Strand, a British journal, in the 1950s . She was editor of the journal in the 1960s and became a British journalist .
 Noni Jabavu's grandfather was the first black African to own and edit a Xhosa-English newspaper . He was one of the few black politicians to be associated with white leaders in South Africa’s Parliament, before apartheid was introduced .
 Noni Jabavu was born in Cape Province in 1919 or 1921 . She left South Africa as a teenager to obtain an education at a Quaker school in England .
 She studied violin at the Royal Academy of Music until WWII interrupted her studies . World War II interrupted her violin studies .
 Jabavu was a welder in a machine factory during the Second World War . She worked in war-era factories in England and Wales . She was the first woman to work in the war .
 She married a pilot in the Royal Air Force, but he died in combat soon after . She married another pilot, who was killed in combat in Afghanistan .
 Jabavu raised their daughter alone, studied journalism, and worked her way up into the position of editor at The New Strand . She raised her daughter alone and studied journalism at the university .
 Under apartheid, marriage between people of different races was not allowed in South Africa . She married a British film director, Michael Cadbury Crosfield, but the mixed-race couple could not return to South Africa.
 Jabavu began writing her memoirs because of her interracial and international background . It is largely due to her international background that she began writing the memoir .
 An English friend encouraged her to stop reminiscing about her African heritage and to start writing it down .
 As Jabavu reached the middle years of her life, important changes occurred in South Africa that affected her writing .
 In 1961, the country gained independence from Great Britain, as European colonial holdings were separating from their European colonizers all over the African continent .
 South Africa withdrew from the British Commonwealth because of Britain’s criticisms of its racial policies . South Africa withdraws from the Commonwealth due to criticism of its policies .
 The African National Congress was banned by the government in 1960 . It was formed to fight for black rights (blacks form the majority of the population)
 ANC and other groups formed guerrilla campaigns against the South African government . In response to the government's crackdown, the ANC and others have formed guerrilla groups .
 Mandela became president of South Africa in 1994 . Three decades later, apartheid was abolished and Mandela was president of the country . Mandela was elected to power in 1994 and became South African president .
 Jabavu’s memoirs are less about her own life and more about the life and culture of the Xhosa people . In some ways, she's less about herself than about her life and her culture . The memoirs will be published in the UK and Australia .
 She begins with her journey back home for her brother’s funeral in 1955 . As a way of introducing her audience, both books were published in London .
 Gangsters in Johannesburg, South Africa, had murdered her brother, Tengo Jabavu . Gangsters had murdered him in South Africa's capital, Johannesburg .
 Tengo Jabavu describes the funeral service as spontaneous outbursts of grief, dismay at the circumstances under which he was murdered, and prayers . One mourner blamed his death on slum conditions in black townships for his death .
 Noni Jabavu describes the funeral as a mixture of Christian and pagan ritual . The funeral was held in the same way as a pagan ceremony . Noni says the funeral was a mixture between Christian and Christian beliefs .
 After the Christian service, the family adhered to the traditional Xhosa practice of killing and eating an ox, a cleansing ritual, and remaining secluded from others for a period of time . Jabavu accepted her brother’s death .
 Nowhere in her memoirs does Jabavu heighten or even focus on racial tensions . Her memoirs do not mention racial tensions in them .
 Jabavu’s tone toward the mixture of races is one of gratitude, not hostility . While conflict does exist, there is no conflict between the two sides . The tone of the character's tone is that of gratitude and not hostility.
 She fondly describes cordial interactions between her family and white families . She views the policy of apartheid as simply a transitory phase that South Africans have to live through .

 With Tengo Jabavu’s death, there were no more descendants of Noni Jabavus’ family in South Africa . The Jabavutu line died out; there are no more than a few descendants .
 Children in traditional and Christian Xhosa communities teach children to humble themselves for the sake of collective sharing within the family and community .
 According to Xhosa culture, individuals are not thought of as individuals but rather as representatives of the family . An individual’s aspirations are subordinate to family goals, according to the culture .
 The book recounts her life as a slave; the seven years she spent hidden away from her master in an attic . It recounts her escape to the North and her odyssey as a fugitive slave . The book also details her incredible escape from the North .

 Jacobs broke taboos against women discussing their sexual lives and engaging in illicit sexual relations . Jacobs redefined the word freedom in feminist terms, as a single woman and a mother . Jacobs was a single mother and single mother .
 At the end of Incidents, she tells us, “Reader, my story ends with freedom; not in the usual way, with marriage.” She tells us that her story ended with freedom .
 Jacobs begins her story with her childhood in Edenton, North Carolina, spent in slavery . Jacobs tells the story of her life in slavery in the state of North Carolina .
 Her first owner, Margaret Horniblow, who taught her to read and sew when she was little, died willed her to her baby niece, Mary Matilda Norcom .
 James Norcom began sexually pursuing Jacobs as soon as she reached puberty . Norcom, Norcom says Jacobs was sexually pursued by Norcom . Jacobs says Norcom started sexually pursuing her when she was at puberty .
 If she refused to become his concubine, Norcom threatened to send her to his plantation to work as a field hand . She refused to work for Norcom and was sent to work on his plantation . Norcom sent her to the plantation to be a field worker .
 In her teens, Jacobs began having an affair with Samuel Tredwell Sawyer, an attorney, legislator, and neighbor of Norcom’s . Norcom was Norcom's neighbor, Jacobs' neighbor, Norcom said .
 Norcom sent Jacobs to his plantation and threatened to send her children there as well . When she gave birth to two children, Louisa and Joseph, she was sent to the plantation . Norcom also threatened her with sending her children to the plantations .
 Jacobs then took a gamble, hoping to save her children from a life of hard labor . Jacobs then decided to take a gamble and take her children to live a better life . Jacobs: "I want to save my children from hard labor. I want to keep them alive"
 She resolved that if she went into hiding, Norcom would soon tire of the children and sell them to Sawyer, who promised to free them . She resolved to go into hiding; Sawyer promised her the children .
 Her grandmother Molly Horniblow, a free woman once owned by Margaret, worked as a baker . Margaret's grandmother Molly was a baker and worked for free women in the 1800s .
 Her house had a tiny crawl space above a storeroom, where Jacobs remained in hiding for seven years . Jacobs spent her time reading the Bible, sewing and reading Bible .
 Sawyer did indeed buy the children, allowing them to live with their greatgrandmother . Sawyer bought the children and they now live in the care of their grandmother .
 Joseph escaped and joined Jacobs’s brother William on the abolitionist speakers’ circuit . Later he took Louisa to a free state, but he never freed them .
 Jacobs fled north on a vessel that sailed to Philadelphia in 1842 . Jacobs fled on the same vessel to Philadelphia, Philadelphia . Jacobs died in 1841 .
 In 1850, the nature of slavery and abolitionism changed with the passage of the Fugitive Slave Act . The act was the first act of the abolition of slavery in America .
 Thenceforth, northerners were required to aid in the capture of fugitive slaves . Northerners faced punishment if they assisted escaped slaves .
 Previously, northerners could ignore slavery as a southern “peculiar institution,” they were now required to participate in it . Northerners were required to take part in slavery .
 For Jacobs, the law meant that her former captors could once again pursue her . Jacobs, who was held captive for more than a decade, says she is safe now .
 Jacobs was purchased by Cornelia Grinnell Willis and Nathaniel Parker Willis for three hundred dollars in 1852 . Her employers arranged for the American Colonization Society (an organization dedicated to relocating freed slaves far from United States territory)
 Jacobs felt disappointment at having to act as a commodity one last time . Thrilled to be finally free, Jacobs said he was disappointed at being a commodity again . Jacobs: "I'm happy to be free, but I'm disappointed at not being able to be a commodity"
 Slave narratives had already been used as weapons in the fight against slavery in the U.S. when Jacobs began writing hers . Jacobs' slave narratives were used as a weapon against slavery .
 Douglass’s Narrative of the Life of Frederick Douglass, an American Slave, established the significance of the genre within the abolitionist movement . The book was published in the early 1900s . Douglass was a leader of the American Slavery Movement .
 Douglass depicted the horrors of slavery, the immorality of the institution . He relied upon the respectability lent to the narrative by Douglass’s editors, white abolitionists, to make his arguments .
 Jacobs, too, worked with the abolitionist editor Lydia Maria Child in producing her work . Jacobs and Child were abolitionists and abolitionists .

 Catharine Sawbridge Macaulay broke every rule in the book of how women should conduct themselves in society . The independent scholar, historian, and political pamphleteer, was a British historian and pamphletier .

 Catharine Sawbridge was born on April 2, 1731, in Kent, England, to John Sawbridge, a wealthy landowner, and Elizabeth Wanley Sawbridge .
 Catharine's mother died during childbirth when she was two, and her father gave Catharine and her brother full use of his extensive library . Catharine died in childbirth during childbirth at the age of two . Her father gave her and her older brother use his library .
 John Sawbridge had many books on the ancient Romans, and the Romans’ libertarian and republican ideals inspired Catharine . Catharine's mother Catharine was inspired by the Romans' libertarian ideals .
 In 1760, she married a Scottish physician, George Macaulay, who encouraged her literary talents . She died of her injuries in 1760 .
 Macaulay died in 1776, leaving Catharine with a healthy inheritance and their young daughter . Catharine was left with a young daughter by her husband .
 In other words, Catharine Macaulay wrote with passion because she felt strongly about her subject . That passion would keep her going, no matter what the cost .
 Macaulay wrote History of England under her own name . Unlike other women writers, she thought her work would more likely achieve acclaim if she wrote it without her feminine first name .
 Macaulay’s History of England praises the republican form of government in England . The Long Parliament was championed by the Long Parliament during the mid-1600s .
 Parliament is the governmental body that represents English citizens and balances the power of the monarch . In England, the Parliament is a governmental body representing English citizens . Parliament is in charge of the government and the government of England .
 Macaulay condemns monarchical government as corrupt and ant-ibertarian . The monarch is a dangerous view to hold in England, he says .
 Her male counterpart, philosopher David Hume, wrote his History of England in 1754 . His book defends the monarchy and argues that the crown would best sustain English principles of freedom and liberty .
 Macaulay’s History of England sold well and was translated into French, though it never received the acclaim that Hume’�s history did . The history of England was published in 17th century .
 After finishing the last of the eight-volume history, published in 1783, Macaulay began working on a series of pamphlets, which were designed to persuade readers to her political views .
 Many of them were responses to pamphlets written by other political thinkers . Many of the pamphlets were written in response to other political ideas .
 She wrote a pamphlet on copyright law in 1774; on the American crisis in 1775; and on the French Revolution, in response to Edmund Burke’s views .
 Perhaps her most influential piece, “Letters on Education,” written in 1790, advocates the same sports and studies for girls and boys . She also advocates for the same studies and sports for both genders .
 This too was controversial, as most people thought that the only education girls needed was in keeping house and raising children . Most people still believed that girls needed to learn to keep house and raise children . This was controversial .
 Macaulay, who was educated in the same way as her brother, believed that women’s secondclass status in society arose from the notion that their only value lay in pleasing men .
 Both the American and French revolutions excited Macaulay a great deal . She saw in these nations the possibility of real political and social freedom taking root .
 She visited America in 1784, as the guest of George Washington at his Mount Vernon home in Mount Vernon . She died in 1881, but her husband died in 1918 .

 Shaw married at the age of 50, past childbearing years; she clearly felt that traditional roles for women were fundamental . On the other hand, she once commented that any woman who had not borne a child was a failure and her life not worth recording .

 She used two different forms of writing to express her ideas . First, she wrote novels that had underlying messages about human freedom .
 She wrote nonfiction books in which she communicated her ideas about the role individuals played in politics and society . She also wrote non-fiction books about individuals' role in society .
 Her corpus of work includes novels, plays, memoirs, criticism and criticism . Her works include works of historical and sociological observations .
 Madame de Stael also influenced French intellectual life through her salon . Her salon was a French salon .
 In France, it was common for upper-class women to operate salons, or public rooms where intellectuals met to discuss politics and philosophy . The salon was a public room for intellectuals to meet in France .
 On the surface, these women appeared to be hostesses, serving drinks and food for their customers . The women were also known as hostesses at the time .
 In reality, they participated as much in the intellectual life of their salons as did their male patrons . But in reality, the men were involved in their own salons, says the author .
 Madame de Stael is perhaps best known as a forerunner of the Romantic movement in Europe . She is best known for her trenchant comparative analyses of European culture . Her trenchant analysis of the world's cultural differences is often overlooked .
 Romanticism flourished in Europe between the 18th and mid-19th centuries . Romanticism is an attitude or intellectual orientation that privileged emotion over rational thinking .
 In Germany, a culture de Stael admired, Romanticism was marked by a preoccupation with the mystical, the subconscious, and the supernatural . De Stael's work is based in Germany, where he was inspired by the culture he admired .

 Anna Magdalena Bach is best known for her work on music . She was the recipient of two volumes of the Anna Magdalena Notebook, dated 1722 and 1725 .
 The notebooks are compilations of keyboard pieces and songs, many of which were composed by Johann Sebastian Bach . Many of the keyboard pieces are composed by the composer .
 Anna Magdalena was born on September 22, 1701 . She was the youngest daughter of Johann Caspar Wulken, a court trumpeter, and Margaretha Elisabeth Liebe .

 Venezuela’s volatile political situation pushed the Garreno family to relocate in the U.S. in 1862 . The Garrenos lived in the United States for more than 150 years . Venezuela's political situation in the 1860s was a source of instability .
 Garreno returned 23 years later, but her circumstances caused her aristocratic audiences to shun her talents . She returned to the stage in 18th century .
 After her death in 1917, amends were made between her countrymen and the memory of her disposition . Carreno’s remains were interred with honor at the National Pantheon in Caracas, Venezuela .
 Her mother, Clorinda Garda de Sena y Toro, belonged to an ancient aristocratic family of Spanish descent . She was born into a family of aristocratic Spanish descent.

 Sauret abandoned his family after she had given birth to two children . After she had had two children, she abandoned her family .

 Her husband had scheduled several performances with his opera company in Venezuela, but ticket sales were poor and the company went into debt . The opera company was in debt .
 The conductor stormed out of a rehearsal and disappeared, leaving the stage . The conductor then stormed out and disappeared from the scene .

 Martha Graham is to modern dance as Pablo Picasso is to the modern art school of cubism . Martha Graham has been married to Martha Graham for more than 20 years . She is a modern dance teacher and choreographer who has been credited with modern dance .
 Martha Graham is synonymous with modern dance . Martha Graham has been married to Martha Graham for more than 30 years .
 She developed innovations in structure, style, technique, costuming, and training of choreographers and dancers that defined the movement .
 She rejected the traditional view of women dancers as beautiful, lithe, and graceful . Instead, she viewed female dancers as powerful and intense .
 Her colleagues have described her long career as an American archetype, because with only a few exceptions, only Graham herself—or her company—ever performed her compositions . Graham was one of the most individualistic dance artists of the 20th century .
 Born on May 11,1894, in Allegheny, Pennsylvania, and raised in Santa Barbara, California . Graham began her formal training at Denishawn School of Dance, a Los Angeles dance academy .
 Graham’s varied and evolving career can be divided into four overlapping phases . Graham's varied career has been divided into a series of overlapping phases of his career . Graham: "I’m not going to give up on me. I’ve got a lot of respect
 Graham choreographed short solos and group works for all-women companies . In the first stage, which began after her debut, began after she made her debut . Graham is choreographer for an all-female company .
 Most of these compositions were based on historical figures and styles of art . Most of the compositions were made of historical figures .
 Her debut, for example, included two pieces called From a XII Century Century Tapestry and Maid with the Flaxen Hair .
 Lamentation featured a tube-shaped piece of cloth that encased Graham from her neck to her feet . Graham was encased in the cloth from neck to feet . The tube-like cloth was used to cover Graham's neck and feet .
 She remained seated throughout the dance, in which she struggled to rid herself of the tube .
 Critics have compared the dance to Kathe KOLLWITZ s drawings of grieving women . Critics say the dance is a form of art form .
 The second phase of Graham’s career coincided with her growing interest in the theater, with the drama of American history, and with the formation of her own dance company . Graham's dance company is based in New York City .
 Two male dancers, Erick Hawkins and Merce Cunningham, joined her troupe in the 1930s . She also choreographed for men .
 During the Great Depression in the United States, some of President Franklin Roosevelt’s New Deal programs focused on the arts in American culture . President Roosevelt's New Deal program focused on American culture during the Depression .
 Graham did not participate directly, her dances from this period reflected the focus on American history as worthy of artistic recording and celebrating .
 Her Appalachian Spring, for example, depicted the pioneer experience in American history . She also depicted the Appalachian Spring .
 Most of the characters she focused on were women . Often, her dances had a feminist twist .
 Graham portrays female character Jocaste, in Sophocles’ play Oedipus, as the victim, rather than the victim . Graham portrays the female character in Night Journey . Graham also portrays the character in the play Night Journey as a victim, not a victim .
 In the fourth and final phase of Graham’s career, she returned to the abstract themes of her earlier period . In the last phase of her career, Graham returned to her earlier themes .
 These dances are not attached to any particular historical figure or to a plot . These dances do not attach to historical figures or to plots .
 The spiral movements were movements in which Graham tended to view the human body as “collapsible,” and the stage on which she performed as part of the dance, not a surface merely there to be danced upon . The spiral movement were movements .
 Unlike traditional choreography, her spiral movements involved fall sequences in which she emphasized the recovery from the fall, not the descent to the ground . The choreographer's spiral movements involve fall sequences .
 The stage often seemed as though it was a taut drum off of which Graham and her dancers would bounce . The stage, then, often seemed like it was an off-the-stage drum .
 Graham choreographed dances in which she used her corps onstage as though they were architecture . Furthermore, Graham used her dancers as if they were architects .
 She would use a row of dancers, rather than a stage setting, to build a wall that moved when the scene changed . For example, she would use dancers rather than stage settings to build the wall .
 Martha Graham gave birth to modern dance, in the sense that she changed people’s minds about what dancers could do . Martha Graham changed people's minds, especially women, about what they could do, she says .
 Graham de-sentimentalized the female body by emphasizing its power, intensity, and, in her fall sequences, its recovery from defeat .

 Three years later, though, her voice had already been strained to the point of exhaustion . Three years after, she still has a voice to spare .

 This form of Japanese art and entertainment arose in the period of imperialism, when European nations began their earliest explorations and excursions overseas, mostly for trading purposes . The art form of entertainment arose during the period when European countries began exploring overseas .
 Japan turned its back on most European nations, determined to modernize and escape exploitation by foreign powers . Unlike many of the places that initially welcomed the European explorers, Japan turned back on them .
 Kabuki entertainment differed from Western forms of theater, helping cultural historians better understand the contrasts between Eastern and Western cultures . The art form of theater in Kabuki theater is similar to that of Western theater .
 It was the first significant theater in Japan established for popular audiences . It was also the first major theater in the country established for audiences .
 Just prior to her birth, Japan had experienced a period called the warring states, when daimyo, or territorial governors, fought among themselves .
 One daimyo, Tokugawa leyasu, achieved military hegemony in Japan . After a long period of consolidation, one daimyasas achieved military dominance .
 He became the shogun, or military ruler, to whom all other daimyo pledged allegiance . He was the head of Japan's shogun . He is now Japan's most powerful ruler .
 During this Tokugawa period the shoguns resisted ‘westernization’ of Japanese society by forbidding the practice of Christianity and expelling all foreigners, except the Dutch and Chinese .
 The Japanese people were forbidden to travel overseas . In addition, the Japanese people themselves were forbidden from traveling overseas .
 The purposes of this policy of isolation were to prevent economic exploitation of Japan by the Europeans, to enhance and unify Japanese culture and to modernize and develop Japan’s economy .
 Buddhist shrines had made a practice of soliciting contributions by sending young women to cities to perform Buddhist sacred dances and songs .
 Okuni, beautiful and talented, began to attract wide audiences to her performances . Okuni was born in Nairobi, Kenya .
 When Izumo Grand Shrine called her back, she refused . Instead, she set up her own theater on the banks of the Shijo River in Kyoto, Japan .
 The banks of the Shijo drew large crowds of rootless, young Japanese people, displaced by changing economic times and alienated from society . Young people were displaced from society and alienated .
 Kabuki theater, like the kabukimono who popularized it, defied polite Japanese society . The theater defied polite society in Japan .
 Okuni parodied—poked fun at—Buddhist prayers by imitating them in order to mock them . Okuni had been sent to cities to perform Buddhist dances and songs .

 Okuni’s lover, Sanzaburo Ujisato, helped create the dances . The dances included short plays enacted by the female dancers . Later, with the help of the dancer's lover, the dancer performed short plays .
 Kabuki theater reveals important differences between Eastern and Western theater (and since theater mimics real life) Kabuki Theater is a form of theater theater .
 In early Western theater, before the 17th century, women were excluded from the stage entirely, and men and boys played women’s roles . Men and boys play women's roles in early theater .
 Another difference between Eastern and Western theater lies in the plot lines of the plays . The plot lines are different in the plays, according to the plays' plots .
 Both theaters performed tragedies . Western tragedies focused on the downfall of the main character, due to a fatal character flaw . Both tragedies were performed at the same theaters .
 Eastern tragedies portrayed moral conflict interfering with human passions . Eastern tragedies depicted moral conflict between moral conflict and human passions. Eastern tragedies featured moral conflict in Eastern Europe .
 The East dealt with general human characteristics rather than individual individuals . The West tended to focus on individual individuals, but the East did focus on human characteristics .
 Kabuki theater intermingled dance and singing and audience participation, to the point where the story line became blurred . Western drama tended to have a distinct plot line, with Western drama having a distinct story line .
 Around his neck hangs a Christian crucifix, not as a religious icon but as an exotic decoration brought to Japan by Europeans . The crucifix is not as an icon, but as a decoration brought in by Europeans, it is said .
 Japanese people throughout the nation applauded Okuni’s Kabuki theater . Okuni's Kabuki Theater is a popular Japanese theater .
 In 1629, the shogunate banned women from performing Kabuki, fearing that the sensuous nature of the dances perpetuated moral corruption in Japanese society . The ban was lifted in 1629 .
 15-year-old boys were also discovered selling sexual favors in exchange for money . Preadolescent boys replaced the women, but in 1652, the shogunate prohibited them .
 In 1868, a political revolution—known as the Meiji Restoration—toppled the Tokugawa Shogunate . It returned the nation to direct Imperial rule . The country is now Japan's most populous nation .
 During the Meiji period , Japan developed a modern, industrial economy and began incorporating some elements of Western culture . During this period, Japan began incorporating elements of western culture into its culture .
 Kabuki theater introduced Western styles of clothing, though the change did not endure for long as performances retained their unique Japanese flavor .

 Russian ballerina Anna Pavlova brought ballet to the common people . She created modern ballet, a dance form previously restricted to upper-class audiences, to the people .

 After 1913 she danced independently with her own company throughout the world . After 1913, she toured the world with her company .

 During her debut, she pirouetted so enthusiastically that she lost control and fell with a loud bump off the stage .

 Clara Wieck Schumann wrote and performed music for piano and orchestra . She excelled in romantic songs popular in the 19th century . Schumann was a composer and composer .
 Clara Wieck Schumann was born in Leipzig, Germany, on September 13, 1819 . She was the first wife of the composer . Schumann died of a gunshot wound to the head .
 Clara's father, Friedrich Wieck, dreamed of having a musical genius in his family . He made plans to make his dream a reality even before Clara was born .
 A music teacher, Wieck focused all his daughter's attention on learning music . He focused all of her attention on music .
 She gave her first concert at the Leipzig Gewandhaus in 1828 at the age of nine, followed by solo recital in 1830 .
 The following year, her father took her on a concert tour in Germany and France . The next year, she was taken on a tour of France and Germany with her father .
 Returning to Leipzig, Clara Wieck spent her days studying piano, voice, the violin, and composition .
 She excelled at creating music for the piano, and several of her solo pieces were published in Germany .
 By the time she was 16, music lovers throughout Europe hailed her as an incredibly talented musical prodigy . By the age of 16, she was hailed as a talented musician .
 The hold Friedrich Wieck had on Clara’s life seemed to matter little to her, until she made plans to marry . The hold on her life mattered little to Clara, but she decided to marry him .
 Robert Schumann, a student of Wieck’s, fell in love with Clara and asked for her hand in marriage . Schumann was a student at the music school .
 Schumann threatened Wieck’s dream by taking Clara away from him, and he refused the proposal . Schumann offered to take Clara away, but refused .
 The two wed in 1840, a day before Clara’s 21st birthday . Schumann took legal action; a judge permitted the marriage, and the two wed .
 Clara Wieck Schumann’s life illustrates the restrictions that marriage placed on 19th-century women . Schumann's life illustrates how marriage placed the restrictions on women .
 Europeans knew Clara Wieck as a young musical prodigy who had received numerous prestigious awards . Before she married, Europeans knew her as a talented musician .
 After her union with Robert Schumann, Clara Wieck Schumann’s life and name retreated behind the life and career of her husband until his death . After her marriage to Robert, Clara returned to the music business .
 Few recognize the name Clara Wieck Schumann as one of the world’s great musicians and composers . Even now, the name Robert Schumann is widely known, but few recognize the great composer .
 Most music historians now agree that Clara Schumann’s talents outshone her husband's . Indeed, most music historians agree that most of the Schumann's talents outshine her husband .

 Because birth control methods were relatively crude, marriage meant children . Since people associated it with prostitution, it was considered taboo . Marriage means children .

 The extent to which Clara Wieck Schumann pursued her music during her marriage makes her relative obscurity now all the more inexplicable .

 In March 1856, his family committed him to an asylum at Endenich, at his request, where he lived until his death in 1856 .

 The two may have been lovers; they exchanged passionate letters until her death . The two had a passionate relationship until she died .

 Halide Adivar became synonymous with the women’s movement in Turkey . Indeed, the name Halide was synonymous with a women's movement in the country .
 Throughout her political and literary career, Adivar remained a devout Muslim, despite the fact that Muslim fundamentalism remained a threat to women's freedom in Turkey and throughout the Muslim world .
 In her Memoirs of Halide Edib, Adivar begins her story with her upbringing in a wealthy Istanbul household . In her memoirs, she tells how she was raised in wealthy Istanbul home .
 Her mother died when she was very young; her grandmother reared her in the strictest observances of Muslim traditions . She was reared in strict Muslim traditions by her grandmother .
 Halide Edib’s father embraced Western life and culture and had his daughter educated first at a primary school operated by a Greek woman, Kyrie Eleni .
 In 1901, Adivar became the first Muslim girl to graduate from the institution . She was also the first woman to do so at the time .

 The 1886 Haymarket Square riot in Chicago became a turning point for Goldman . Goldman was inspired by the events in 1886 . The riots were a turning moment for Goldman, who later became a prominent businessman .
 On May 1, workers all over the nation went on strike to demand an eight-hour workday . The strike is the latest in a long line of strikes against the government .

 Most immigrants who came to the U.S. from 1880 to 1920 were Catholic or Jewish, not Protestant . Furthermore, most immigrants from 1880-1920 were Catholic, not Protestants .

 The Russian anarchist Peter Kropotkin argued that social justice would replace coercion by the government if authoritarian social hierarchies were replaced with small political organizations in which all members participated equally .

 Homestead workers had gone on strike to seek the eight-hour workday and to protest wage cuts proposed by Frick . Frick proposed wage cuts to offset the expense of new machinery .
 Goldman obtained the weapon, but she was never caught and did not admit taking part in the crime until 40 years later . Goldman had obtained the gun, but Goldman had never been caught . Goldman was never convicted of the crime, but admitted it to police 40 years after .

 Petra Kelly is cofounder of Die Griinen, a political party based on grassroots democracy, environmental awareness, and nonviolent social activism . Kelly is a German political activist .
 Kelly’s blend of environmental advocacy and feminism attracted the attention of other feminists and philosophers, ultimately spawning a new philosophical movement known as ecofeminism . Kelly's blend of feminism and environmental activism spawned a new philosophy known as Ecofeminism.
 Ecofeminists also counter the notion that a ‘natural’ affinity exists between male domination over women and nature, because to make such a claim implies a pattern of domination that cannot be disentangled, they say .
 Environmentalism is a necessary part of resistance against all kinds of oppression, according to ecofeminists . Ecofeminists promote the promotion of community between all living beings . Environmentalists say environmentalism is necessary to resist oppression .
 At the root of all of Kelly's thinking and activism is the fundamental notion that injustice in the world must not be allowed to stand, she says .

 Rosa Luxemburg’s legacy lasted long after her brutal death at the hands of German soldiers in January 1919 . She was a Polish German revolutionary whose brutal death was in 1919 . Luxemburg was a member of the Communist Party in Poland .
 East German dissidents chanted Luxemburg’s slogan “freedom is always the freedom of she who thinks differently” as police arrested them on the anniversary of the death of Luxemburg in 1989 . Police arrested them as they were opposing the government of the German Democratic Republic .
 Rosa Luxemburg’s international outlook derived in part from her multinational background (she lived in Poland, Germany, France, and Switzerland), which left her open to transnational ideologies . Luxemburg lived in France, Switzerland, Switzerland and Germany .
 She was a Marxist who believed in a workers’ revolution that would transfer control of the means of production from capitalists to the workers themselves . She was an advocate of a workers' revolution .
 The revolution would result in international socialism . Property and the distribution of income would be subject to social control, rather than individual determination or market forces .
 Luxemburg thought that nationalist sentiments only served to reinforce the power of the bourgeoisie . Luxemburg: Nationalism is distracting workers from the revolution .
 Rosa Luxemburg was born on March 5, 1871, to Line Lowenstein, a rabbi’s daughter, and Eliasz Luxemburg, a Jewish timber merchant, in the town of Zamosc in Russian Poland . She was born in 1871 .
 At the age of three, she and her family relocated to Warsaw, Poland, where she attended a gymnasium open only to a select few Jewish students . She was moved to Warsaw at age three, and she attended school only to select few students .
 Luxemburg excelled in her studies, but school officials denied her the golden medal because of her confrontational behavior, and because she had joined a group of revolutionary socialists . Luxemburg was denied the gold medal because she was confrontational .
 She fled to Switzerland at the age of 18 when her activities became known to the Russian secret police . She fled when she was 18 .
 She met her longtime lover and companion Leo Jogiches , a Polish Lithuanian student and revolutionary like herself . The couple befriended Karl Kautsky, the “Pope of Marxism” Karl . Kautsy and Luxemburg’s lawyer Paul Levi .
 Luxemburg has traveled extensively all over Europe since childhood . Crippled since childhood, Luxemburg nevertheless traveled extensively .
 She worked briefly in Paris before returning to Zurich to complete her dissertation on the industrial development of Poland . She returned to Switzerland after completing her dissertation .
 By 1905, Luxemburg had authored more than 90 articles published in various newspapers and journals, mostly in Germany and Poland . Luxemburg was born in Switzerland and died in 1903 .
 Luxemburg's fiery radical prose got her in trouble with conservative forces . She landed in jail repeatedly for insulting the German Kaiser Wilhelm II and the government in print .
 Luxemburg argued that under capitalism, a national economy will reach a point when the demand for goods does not increase enough to keep up with the growing supply of goods . Luxemburg: Under capitalism, the demand will not be able to keep pace with growing supply .
 The capitalist nation must expand into nondeveloped nations to create new markets for its products, thus forming the conditions for imperialism . Therefore, the capitalist nation needs to expand into more and more countries .
 After Luxemburg’s death, economist John Maynard Keynes corroborated his findings . Keynes suggested that governments could intervene directly in the economy and control supply and demand through government spending programs .
 Her ultimate goal in Germany was to establish a government based upon workers’ councils . Nevertheless, she still believed in socialism .
 She participated in the events that led to the abdication of Wilhelm II and the end of the German monarchy . To help make her dream a reality, she participated in World War I events .
 She addressed the founding congress of the German Communist Parry . She assumed the editorship of Die Rote Fahne , the party's newspaper .
 “Red Rose” led the Berlin workers’ call for revolution in January 1919 . Although she advocated a gradualist approach to worker revolution, ‘Red Rose' advocated gradualism .
 Luxemburg’s head carried a bounty of DM 100,000, and soldiers beat her and gunned her down on the night of January 15, 1919 . Luxemburg was shot in the head by soldiers in the early hours of that day .

 Her politics are an esoteric blend of socialism, Irish nationalism, anticlericalism, and feminism . Representing a young, radicalized Catholic population of Northern Ireland, she writes .

 An Irish provisional government was proclaimed in 1916 . After more than a century of British rule, an Irish government was declared in 1916.
 In 1920, the British government passed an act dividing the island into the Irish Republic in the south and the mostly Protestant Northern Ireland in the north . The act divided the mostly Catholic, mostly Protestant, Irish Republic .
 In 1921 British and Irish officials signed a treaty securing the separate states . Southerners rejected the division, but in 1921 a treaty was signed securing the separation .

 Ngoyi resisted all attempts to stifle her activism . Although the South African government silenced and physically restrained her, she fought back .
 Ngoyi was born to a Bapedi family in the village of Gamatlala near Pretoria, South Africa . He was born in a village near the city's capital, Pretoria .
 Poverty forced the end of her formal education after one year of high school . She attended primary school in the village of Kilnerton, but poverty forced her to quit .
 She had an experience during the years that she worked as a domestic servant that would shape her later life . She had to work as a housemaid during her childhood .

 ANC formed in 1912 to fight for black South Africans’ rights . Nationalists had formed the ANC in 1912 . ANC was formed by Nationalists to fight against black South African rights .

 The Boer War resulted in British victory and sovereignty in South Africa . The war ended in defeat of the South African Republic .
 In 1913, the Native Land Act introduced territorial separation, restricting black Africans to homelands, which consisted of only 15 percent of the total area of South Africa . The act was introduced in 1913 .
 The Native Land Act anticipated a series of ‘homeland’ laws that instituted South Africa’s system of apartheid . It was the first land law to be passed in South Africa .
 The government passed the Mixed Marriage Act and the Immorality Amendment Act in 1948 . The act outlawed marriage and sexual relations between different races .
 The government created separate local administrations according to racial groups . The government then created separate administrations for each group .
 South Africans can now live anywhere and the homelands have been abolished . Before apartheid ended in 1992, the ANC fought against restrictions imposed by the system .
 Lilian Ngoyi took part in the 1952 Defiance Campaign in South Africa . The campaign saw black South Africans collectively defy apartheid laws .
 She ignored ‘Whites Only’ signs hung in public buildings such as post offices, for which she was arrested and sentenced to prison . As part of this campaign, she ignored “Whites only” signs hung .
 The Defiance Campaign, along with other ANC activities, resulted in the governmental ban on the organization in 1960 . The organization was forced underground .

 In essence, the ANC and the FSAW represented the only political organizations in which black South Africans could participate . The ANC and FSAW were the only organizations that could participate in elections .

 The Federation of South African Women was formed to agitate against the extension of the abhorrent ‘pass laws’ to women . It was formed in response to the introduction of the 'pass laws'
 Beginning in the 1950s, pass laws were instituted to help enforce the segregation of races and prevent blacks from encroaching in white areas . The laws were created to help prevent blacks encroaching on white areas and prevent black encroaching .
 The government required all non-whites to carry documents authorizing their presence in restricted areas . The government requires non-white people to have documents authorizing them to enter restricted areas.
 The idea was to keep black laborers away from urban areas where white workers competed for jobs . It was designed to keep white workers from competing for jobs in urban areas . White workers were kept out of urban areas to avoid competition for jobs.

 Ngoyi led protesters to the government buildings in Pretoria, South Africa’s administrative capital . The protests follow a series of demonstrations against the government .
 There, authorities placed her under arrest and charged her with high treason . She was arrested and charged with treason .

 American historians often discuss the variety of political and social reforms that attempted to reduce the negative impact that industrialization had on American workers . Ovington's work was part of the Progressive Era, the period from 1890 to 1920 .
 Reformers lobbied for shorter working hours, better working conditions, and the ending of child labor . They lobbied for short working hours and better conditions, all of which improved the life of American workers .
 For many African Americans, conditions deteriorated during the Progressive Era . The Progressive Era did not result in progress, but instead, conditions worsened . African Americans are still struggling to find a way to improve their lives .
 In Springfield, Illinois, a race riot bloodied the streets of President Abraham Lincoln’s hometown . President Lincoln's hometown, Springfield, was the scene of the race riot .
 Many of the founders of the NAACP, including Ovington, were descendants of abolitionists or reformers who fought for the end of slavery . The NAACP was founded by the descendants of the abolitionists .
 Many of the NAACP founders were socialists, as was Ovington . In addition, many of them were socialists . The NAACP founder was a socialist .
 As socialists, reformers thought that the U.S. government should have more control over industrial production . Instead of industry being under the control of private corporations, the government should control it .
 socialism hit its highpoint of popularity at a time when the effects of industrialization were most serious . Not surprisingly, socialism had hit its highest point at the time when industrialization was most severe .
 Overcrowded cities, labor strikes and riots in 1897 and 1907 led many to question the benefits of industrial capitalism . Economic depressions in 1897, 1907 led to serious economic depressions . Many of the world's largest cities were overcrowded and crowded .
 The U.S. government had promoted industrialization by securing land for railroads helping to industrialize the western states . Progressive politicians increasingly insisted that the federal government restrict unchecked industrialization .
 Progressivism’s detractors warned that government intervention in free-market capitalism smacked of socialism . Progressivism's detractors said government intervention into free-markets smacked socialism .
 The NAACP did not advocate socialism as a means of bettering the lives of African Americans . Afraid of seeming too radical, the NAACP didn't advocate socialism .
 It advocated the attainment of complete civil and political rights for blacks as a way of overcoming blacks’ history of enslavement . Instead, it advocated for blacks to achieve complete civil, political rights .
 Mary White Ovington held many leadership positions within the NAACP, including chairman of the board from 1919 to 1932 . She was also a member of the NAACP's board .
 Many people who advocated civil rights for African Americans also pursued woman suffrage as a way to widen the scope of participation in the American political process .
 The entry of the U.S. into World War I in April 1917 divided suffragists . Suffragists were divided by the war's entry .
 Other women could not bring themselves to support the destructiveness of war . Other women did not want war to destroy the environment .
 She attacked President Wilson for his indifference toward the atrocities committed against African Americans during the East St. St. African American atrocities .
 American military troops exacerbated the race riots, reported Ovington . American military forces exacerbated the riots, according to the report .
 Ovington and other members of the NY-WPP noted the contradictions between the U.S.’s war aim of spreading democracy to other countries, and its unwillingness to provide a democratic system of justice for African-American citizens living within its own boundaries .
 Ovington pointed to contradictions within the women’s movement . Similarly, he pointed out contradictions in the movement .
 Racial attitudes deflected attention from the need for woman suffrage . Racial prejudices among reformers threatened to divide and weaken the suffragists . Suffragists fought for the right to vote for the first time .
 Ovington expressed concern southern women had opposed suffrage for black women . She urged the NWP to include a plank endorsing black women’s right to vote at the meeting .
 She suggested that the secretary of the National Association of Colored Women, Mary Talbert, be invited to speak and that a committee be formed to investigate discrimination in the South .
 Ovington understood that continued prejudice against black women weakened and divided the women’s rights movement . The women's rights movement continues to be divided, divided by prejudice .

 Mary White White Ovington died on July 15, 1951, in Newton Highlands, Massachusetts .
 Her life and work synthesized the multitude of Progressive Era reforms that marked the early 20th century, including civil rights, suffrage, and pacifism . She synthesized many of the reforms she made in the Progressive Era .
 Studying Ovington’s work enables historians to see how opening the doors of democracy for one disenfranchised group of Americans, such as African Americans, resulted in the knocking and pushing open of other closed doors, as well .

 Rosa Parks sat on the Cleveland Avenue bus in Montgomery, Alabama, on December 1, 1955 . Rosa Parks had planned to use the bus to get people on their way home from work . Parks was the first black woman to sit on a bus in the U.S. for more than
 The first 10 rows of the bus were reserved for whites . It was one of many Jim Crow laws designed to maintain white privilege and supremacy .

 The Korean War had roots in the early part of the 20th century when Japan annexed Korea in 1910 . Korea was annexed by Japan in 1910.
 The Korean peninsula, which juts out into the Sea of Japan, was divided at the 38th parallel . It was divided into two administrative zones, north and south .
 Nationwide elections were attempted to reunite the two halves, but these failed . Nationwide elections in 2011 were also attempted, but failed, and were unsuccessful .

 The United Nations, led by the United States, defended South Korea, while China defended North Korea . The U.N. led the U.S. to defend South Korea . North Korea has been accused of a series of human rights violations .

 Eddy created a religion based upon a new understanding of the relationship between religion, science, and health, derived from her own experiences with pain and suffering . Eddy's religion is based on her own experience with pain .
 Mary Baker Eddy was the American founder of the Christian Science movement . She was the founder of Christian Science, the first woman to be a Christian Science leader .
 Eddy was all too familiar with human suffering, part of the human condition with which he was familiar with . Eddy's story is published in the Library of Congress, Prints and Photographs Division .
 Born Mary Baker on July 16, 1821, in Bow, New Hampshire, to the farming couple Abigail Baker and Mark Baker . Eddy’s childhood was punctuated with long bouts of poor health .
 She did not attend school but was educated by an older brother . Like many 19th-century Americans, she studied the Bible intensely . She was born in New York City, New Jersey .
 Her father, like other Calvinists, believed in the teachings of John Calvin that only a select group of Christians will be saved from damnation .
 She returned to her parents’ farm, where she gave birth to her only child, George Glover . She went on to give birth to George Glover at the farm .
 Ten years later she met and married a traveling dentist, Daniel Patterson . She married him ten years later .
 Quimby hypnotist or “mesmerist’s” put Eddy into a trance, during which time she felt no pain . Eddy was put in a trance by the hypnotist, who hypnotized her . She felt nothing pain during the trance .
 Less than a year later, she slipped on ice and sustained a spinal injury . She suffered the injury a year after slipping on ice on her bike .
 To alleviate her pain this time, she tried healing herself through reading portions of the Christian Bible that dealt with Christ’s power to heal the sick, especially Matthew 9:1-8 .
 She found that by concentrating on these verses, she was able to reduce her pain . The healing touch was actually coming from God, she says .
 Ghristian Science as a healing system and, ultimately, a church . What she believed to be God’s act of ridding her body of pain led to Ghristan Science .
 By 1870, Eddy was teaching her scientific healing in collaboration with practitioners who treated those in need . Eddy's scientific healing was first developed in the 1870s .
 Eddy responded to the incongruity of a powerful, loving God allowing humans to suffer by postulating that, in fact, God did not create the earth nor what it contains . Eddy upheld the Galvinist belief that God was sovereign .
 In her mind, if God is good and is a spirit, then matter and evil must not be real, she says . She believes that God is the spirit of God, and evil is not real .
 Since medical treatment involved using matter to treat the body, it was also not real and was rejected by Christian Scientists . Christian Scientists rejected the idea of treating matter with matter .
 The ‘science’ in Christian Science is in the acceptance of this truth about human existence on the part of the sufferer . The “science” in Christian science is in accepting this truth, the author says .
 Eddy believed that all sin and suffering would disappear if humans would abandon their reliance on the physical senses and surrender to what she believed was the truth . She believed that only the spiritual is real .
 Eddy’s existence from 1870 until the founding and chartering of the church in 1879 seemed to be steeped in spirituality . She lived in poverty, relying on the charity of her followers for room and board .
 In 1877, she married one of her students, Asa Gilbert Eddy, a sewing machine salesman . She died in 1877 at the age of 92 .
 She followed the success of her first book with several others, including Christian Healing and A Defense of Christian Science . In 1908, she started publishing The Christian Science Monitor, a highly regarded newspaper still in circulation .
 The years from 1880 to 1890 were trying times for Eddy and other Christian Scientists . Eddy died in 1890 at the age of 60 .
 In 1881 she and her followers began the Massachusetts Metaphysical College, which abruptly folded in 1889 . The college was founded by her followers .
 She started and disbanded the National Christian Science Association in 1886 and 1889, respectively . She then started and disbanded the organization .
 Much of the turmoil of this period stemmed from acrimoniousness between Eddy and her adherents, and among the group as a whole .
 Edward J Arens, for example, accused Eddy of borrowing Phineas Quimby’s ideas without attribution . Eddy in turn brought suit against Arens for plagiarizing Science and Health .
 Eddy reorganized the church in 1892 and published The Manual of the Mother Church, a guide to the Christian Science organization, in 1895 . Eddy published the Manual of The Mother Church in 1895, which was published by 1895 .
 The new organization allowed Eddy to retain her function as head of the main church, the First Church of Christ, Scientist, in Boston . It gave branch congregations more autonomy .
 The purpose of the reorganization was to cut down on internal disputes . The purpose was to reduce internal disputes, according to the government .
 Former member Josephine Woodbury filed a lawsuit against the church for defamation of character . Former member of the church filed the lawsuit for defamation .
 Eddy could claim 100,000 believers by the time she died on December 3, 1910, in Chestnut Hill, Massachusetts, in 1910 .

 Hadewijch represented the Beguine movement, a religious community of women founded in the 13th century . He represented the religious community, which was founded by women in France .
 It seems likely that Hadewijch came from an upper-class background . Many of her works deal with the language and traditions of chivalry and courtly love .

 Beguines promised to live celibate lives while living in Beguine communities called Beguinages . They were allowed to retain private property and were free to leave the community and marry .
 Married women could still participate in the community while they lived with their husbands . Married women were allowed to participate in community while living with husbands .
 Social and religious conditions help to explain the rise of the Beguines in the 13th century . The Beguinean kingdom was founded in 13th Century . The kingdom was ruled out of control by the Roman Empire .

 The Council of Vienne condemned the Beguines as ‘an abominable sect’ and tried to supress those living outside Beguinages . The Council also tried to impose restrictions on people living outside of the region .
 The daily routine of the Beguines’ lives included attendance at Mass, prayers in honor of Mary and the passion of Christ, meditative reading and contemplation, communal penance, and monthly confession .
 Groups of Beguine women who shared living quarters also provided refuge for women who were single women or widows in need of protection . Women who were not members of the groups also provided shelter for women not members .

 His followers rejected the ritual and opulence of the Catholic Mass, the sacraments, and the infallibility of the pope . His followers reject the ritual of the Mass and the papal infallibility . The Catholic Church was founded in 1783 .
 Lollards wore russet gowns, carried staffs, and lived off what they could beg . Lollards used to live off begging for food and living off rucksacks .
 Henry IV of England persecuted the Lollards, because their beliefs ran counter to Catholic doctrine and to English law . The Lollards were persecuted by Henry IV because they were Catholic . Henry IV persecuted them because they believed they were contrary to the Catholic doctrine .

 Ann Lee’s Shakers were the first American religious group to espouse pacifism, abolition of slavery, equality of the sexes, communal property, and absolute celibacy . The United Society of Believers in Christ's Second Appearance was founded in 1881 .
 A number of spiritual leaders in England—put off by the Anglican Church—spawned an anticlerical, evangelical revival in the 18th century . The revival in England was a form of anti-Anglicanism .
 Some revivalists remained orthodox in their theology, merely infusing traditional Christianity with spontaneous, emotional worship services . Others infused traditional Christian worship services with spontaneous worship .
 Others, like the Shakers, departed with convention by insisting on celibacy for all members and by welcoming female ministers . Others, such as the Shaker, disagreed with the convention by inviting female ministers to their meetings .

 The Shakers borrowed many Quaker tenets, including the notion that all humans possess an inner light designed to lead them to spiritual truth . Shakers were Quaker members of the Quaker community .
 During Shaker meetings, believers would meditate until the Holy Spirit manifested itself in them . They would then begin violently shaking, shouting, and singing .

 Indian Buddhist nun Mahaprajapati established the first order of Buddhist nuns in world history . Her aunt was the aunt of the founder of Buddhism, Siddhartha Gautama .
 Gautama’s mother died seven days after his birth, and his aunt reared him along with her other children . The boy's aunt married her sister's widowed husband Shuddhodana .
 The establishment of an order of female renunciants provoked controversy over the role of women in the Buddhist religion that has never been fully eradicated . Despite the large numbers of Buddhist nuns that exist today, there are still large numbers .
 Mahaprajapati "started a spiritual and social revolution" when she asked the Buddha to ordain a community of nuns . She started a "spiritual revolution" by asking for nuns to be ordained .
 Gautama had a son, but the pain of his family and clan took a heavy toll on him . The 29-year-old man became an ascetic after he was born .
 Ascetics, who were relatively common in India at the time, wandered throughout the countryside teaching, meditating, and begging for their subsistence . Ascetics wandered throughout India teaching and meditating in search of their livelihood .
 Gautama practiced yoga, refrained from sexual activity, and organized a community of disciples . Some of the disciples remained with their families, while others followed Gautamas' teachings .
 The charismatic Gautama and his followers sought escape from the human condition through meditation . Meditation would ultimately bring enlightenment, or nirvana, or enlightenment .
 Gautama, better known as the Buddha (one who has awakened’), instructed his followers (called the Sangha) in the dharma and the Middle Way, a path between worldly existence and intense spirituality .

 India came increasingly under the influence of Muslim kings who invaded Rajasthan from Afghanistan . India was invaded by the Muslim kings from Afghanistan in the early 12th century .

 Like most Hindu families, Mirabai's was strictly patriarchal; honor among both sexes was expected . Like most families, honor was expected for both sexes in Mirabia's family .
 In men, honor implied courage and military prowess; in women, honor signified obedience, loyalty to family, and chastity . Honor signified loyalty, loyalty, family, chastity, obedience and obedience .
 Aryan religious practices blended with indigenous religions to form the Hindu religion . The Hindu religion is based on Hinduism .
 There is no single set of religious beliefs or practices in the Hindu religion . Instead, it is a fluid mass of religious ideas and expressions . The Hindu religion is a 'fluid mass of ideas'
 Among others, Hinduism is polytheistic, involving the worship of many gods . Hinduism involves worshiping many gods, including those of many .
 There is no clear-cut path toward truth or error in Hindu life, says author . "A variety of truths exist, which are sometimes contradictory, existing alongside each other," he says .
 Central to Hinduism is the belief in reincarnation and in karma, or the notion that past actions determine one’s present life .
 Temples are Hindu places of worship and ritual, and festivals mark days of celebration . Temples include temples, temples and temples, and temples are Hindu temples .

 Hindus accept the caste system as part of their religion . Some believe it was actually constructed by Brahmin priests . The caste system was constructed by Hindu priests, according to some .
 Brahman, or priestly class, receives the highest social rank . Kshatriya, warrior caste, comes next; the Vaisya, or traders and farmers, below that; and the Sudra, or servants, comprise the lowest caste .
 Those living outside the caste system are known as untouchables . They include those who kill for a living, such as butchers, and workers who come into contact with human waste .
 A Hindu is born into his or her caste and cannot rise above it during this lifetime . A Hindu can't be born into a caste and can't rise above this lifetime. A Hindu cannot be born in a Hindu family .

 Mercy Amba Oduyoye developed a Christian liberation theology based upon her knowledge of, and experiences within, her African cultural heritage . Mercy Ambi Oduioye is a Ghanaian theologian .
 She has become particularly interested in the liberation of women whose oppression has arisen from social, religious, or cultural ideologies . Like CHO WHA SOON in Korea, she has become increasingly interested in women's liberation .
 Oduyoyoye is president of the Ecumenical Association of Third World Theologians . She continues to make the world aware of the great potential that Africans, and other non-Europeans, have .
 Mercy Amba Oduyoye is the daughter of the Methodist Reverend Charles Kwaw and Mercy Dakwaa Yamoah . She was born in Asamankese, Ghana, and is a daughter of a Methodist .
 English is Ghana’s official langauge, with 44 percent of the population speaking Akan . English is the national language of Ghana, with Akan being spoken 44 percent .
 Oduyoyoye was raised in the Akan cultural tradition, a tradition that influenced her religious beliefs . She was born in Nigeria and raised in Akan .
 About 30 percent of Ghanaians are Muslim, and 24 percent are Christian . About 30 per cent of Ghanaian are Muslim .

 After receiving her B.A. in religious studies in 1963, she left for England to pursue graduate studies in England .

 Oduyoyoye sees Africa as a mixture of traditional African culture, Islamic norms, and Western civilization . He sees Africa, and particularly West Africa, as a mix of traditional and Western culture .
 She is proudest, however, of her Akan heritage, which she feels has helped her understand the centrality of women in the human community .
 Traditional Akan society is built upon matrilineal clans; members trace their descent from common female ancestors . Members of the Akan clan trace descent from their ancestors .
 Matrilineal descent determines inheritance, succession, and land tenure . It determines inheritance and succession of land ownership .

 The Akan culture is rich in oral traditions that provide a basis for hearing the Gospel through the spoken language . For example, the Akan people have oral traditions .

 She held a research assistant position at Harvard Divinity School from 1985 to 1986 . She then became the Henry Luce Visiting Professor at Union Theological Seminary the following year .
 She is the first African woman to become a member of the World Council of Churches’ Commission on Faith and Order .

 Elizabeth Seton was the first American woman to found an order of nuns and to be declared a saint by the Catholic Church . Seton initiated the parochial school system and the first Catholic orphanage .
 Her conversion to the Catholic faith horrified her friends and family, and she was ostracized from the society and culture in which she was raised . Not surprisingly, her conversion to Catholicism horrified her family .
 The American Sisters of Charity was founded in 1809 . She moved to Maryland and founded the sisters' first group .
 Her mother, Catherine Charlton Bayley, was the daughter of the rector of St. Mary's Church, London . She was born in 18th century London . Her mother was also a member of the church's rector .
 Elizabeth Bayley spent much of her childhood ministering to the sick and needy . Her benefactors came to know her as the Protestant Sister of Charity .
 Even the letters she wrote as a young girl reveal deeply held spiritual and religious convictions . Her letters reveal her deep held spiritual convictions .
 At the age of 19, Bayley married a wealthy merchant and banker named William Magee Seton . Bayley was married to Seton, a wealthy banker .
 William Seton’s business failed—a disaster from which he never recovered . Seton's business failed, and he was never able to recover from the disaster .
 William's health fared no better, and in 1803, the couple and their eldest daughter, Anna Maria, traveled to Italy, where they hoped William’s health would benefit from the drier climate . His health fared well, and the couple hoped the climate would improve .
 They stayed with friends the Filicchi family of Livorno, Italy, on Italy's west coast .
 Antonio and Filippo Filicchi were Catholics, and their ability to console the bereaved widow impressed Elizabeth Seton .
 When Seton booked her passage back to the United States in 1804, she was on the brink of conversion . Seton was a convert to the U.S. when she died .
 Her friends and family never forgave her, and she had no contact with them afterward . She never had any contact with her family again .
 Anti-Catholic sentiment in the U.S. had deep roots by the early 19th century . Anti-Catholics in the United States have deep roots in anti-Catholic sentiments .
 There were only about 25,000 Catholics out of a total population of about 2 million in the American colonies by the 1770s .
 Most Catholics were living in Maryland, which had been founded by the Catholic Calvert family . Most Catholics in Maryland were Catholic .
 New Englanders, especially, feared ‘popery’ in their neighbors to the north . The nation’s largest city, New York City, was the birthplace of New England .
 Catholics in every colony, including Maryland, were disenfranchised . Catholics could not vote or hold public office or vote in Maryland . Catholics in Maryland could not hold office .
 Anti-Catholicism cooled somewhat as the colonists tried to enlist the help of Canadians in their cause . When the war for independence erupted in 1775, anti-Catholics had cooled somewhat .
 Given prejudices that her chosen religion provoked, Seton feared for her livelihood . Given the prejudices that she had provoked, she feared for the livelihood .
 Most women in the early 19th century had few skills and little education, there were few opportunities for them to earn money . Widows generally were forced to rely on their families to support them until they could remarry .
 At first she could rely on Antonio Filicchi's generosity, which provided her with a way to pay for her and her children’s living expenses . At first, she was able to rely on his generosity to provide her and children's living costs .
 Dubourg, to establish a girls’s school near a Baltimore college and seminary, was to establish the school . The school is located near a Maryland college and a seminary . Dubourgs is the daughter of a former mayor of Baltimore .

 In 1809, she moved to Maryland, made her vows before the archbishop, and exchanged her everyday attire for a nun’s habit . The archbishop made the vow to her in 1809 .
 Mother Seton formed the American Sisters of Charity of Emmitsburg, Maryland, and became Mother Setont . Seton was the founder of St. Vincent de Paul and formed the U.S. Sister of Charity .
 Seton developed the American parochial school system by training teachers, preparing textbooks for classroom use, and translating religious books from the French . During her years at Emmitsburg, Seton trained teachers, prepared textbooks and translated religious books .
 Seton never ceased the charitable work for which she was known . She also wrote several religious treatises herself .
 As the Mother Superior of her religious order, she combined nurturing the sick and destitute with converting supplicants to the Catholic faith . Now, she is known for her role as a nurse who nursed the sick .
 The Catholic Church honored Mother Seton by declaring her venerable in 1959; four years later . The Catholic church also declared her venerable four years after .
 Pope John XXIII beatified her, and she was canonized, or declared a saint, in 1975 . She was the first woman to be declared a sain in the United States .
 It is doubtful that Seton herself would have considered all of this very important . Seton's death was a suicide attempt .

 Scottish missionary Mary Slessor once described herself as “wee, thin, and not very strong” She worked as a missionary among the peoples of the Calabar region of West Africa, in what is today Nigeria .
 Slessor broke with her community and chose to live independently in Africa . Instead of clinging to the society of other Europeans in Africa, she chose to be independent .
 Mary was born on December 2, 1848, the second of her family’s seven children . She was born in Gilcomston, a suburb of Aberdeen, Scotland, in Scotland .
 Her father, Robert Slessor, cobbled shoes, while her mother, wove textiles in a local factory . Her parents, Robert and Robert, worked in shoes and textiles .
 Robert Slessor soon could not support his family in the shoemaking trade, so the Slessors relocated to Dundee . Mary began working in the mill in Dundee, where she worked as a shoemaker .
 She even integrated the practice of converting people into her play with other children . She was even able to play with her own children .
 Once, she stood her ground against a group of thugs, one of whom swung a metal weight on a string increasingly closer to her face . One of the thugs swung the metal weight as she stood in front of her .
 She got the ruffians to agree that, if she did not blink, then they would have to join her Sunday School class . She got them to say they would be joining her Sunday school class .
 Despite the long and arduous 12 hours a day she spent working at the textile factory, Slessor still found time to volunteer as a teacher at a local mission school .
 When she turned 28, Slessor applied to the Foreign Mission Board of the United Presbyterian Church . She is a member of the board of the U.P. Presbyterian Church's Foreign Missions Board .
 Calabar is the name of a town and port in southeastern Nigeria . It lies along the Calabara River . The name of the town is the same as the name given to the town of Calabars .
 The Efik branch of the Ibibio people settled the region in the early 17th century . Later, the town developed as a center of exchange between white traders and Africans living farther inland .
 Calabar also served as a major slave-trading center until the mid-19th century . Great Britain abolished the practice in 1807, and the slave trade diminished .
 The slave trade had had a pernicious effect on traditional African society, as the tribe lost control over the fate of its members .
 Missionaries arriving in the mid-19th century witnessed the human sacrifice that routinely followed the death of a village dignitary . The ritual murder of twins, which the Ibibio considered a sign of bad luck, was commonplace .
 The church encouraged the local chiefs to pass a law in 1850 prohibiting human sacrifice . The law was passed by local chiefs in 1850 .
 The Reverend Hope Waddell established the first missionary school in 1846 . The Free Church of Scotland established the school in Scotland .
 When Slessor arrived in 1876, her first priority was to learn the Efik language . She learned quickly and learned the language quickly .
 She soon became the leading authority in the language among seasoned and new missionaries alike . She became a leading authority among seasoned missionaries .
 After becoming immersed in Ibibio culture, Slessor decided to travel further inland to explore other regions and make contact with other African peoples .
 No other European missionaries were willing to join her expedition . Slessor journeyed alone and had few contacts with other Europeans during the rest of her life .
 She began working with the Okoyong, a little known people in the interior of the continent, where few Europeans had traveled . The Okoyoyong people are little known but few Europeans have traveled to the region .
 The Okoyong were unaffected by the law prohibiting human sacrifice, or the ritual abandonment of twins . They were not subject to the law banning human sacrifice or abandonment .

 Edith Stein died at the hands of Nazi officials in the gas chambers of Auschwitz . Stein was a Carmelite nun and philosopher Jewish by birth .
 Those who survived the death camps, and Stein’s contemporaries in the Catholic Church, have interpreted her words in different ways . Edith Stein is remembered for her words, which led to a controversy in how she is remembered . The Catholic Church has interpreted Stein's words differently .
 The Catholic Church beatified her as a Catholic martyr in 1987, an act which disturbed many Jews, who understood her final words to mean that she had reconciled with the religion of her birth .
