 The Catholic Church borrowed a judicial technique to root out heresy, sorcery, witchcraft, and alchemy throughout Europe . The technique was used to question the accused until a confession was procured .
 Catholic Church viewed heretics as threats against its power . Catholic Church had consolidated its power during the Middle Ages and early modern period .
 Pope Gregory IX assigned church officials to the task of inquiring into heresy in specific areas . The pope's office was tasked with investigating heresy into specific areas of heresy .
 Those accused of heresy were questioned and granted the opportunity to confess their crimes . If no admission of guilt came forth, inquisitors ordered torture if no confession was made .
 In Spain, Ferdinand and ISABELLA I used the Inquisition to force political and religious unity by deporting Jewish people . Even Jews who were conversos had to leave the country . Ferdinand and Isabella I used to use the Inquisition as a way to force unity .
 In 1485, the Tribunal of the Inquisition offered a pardon to all those who confessed their “secret” Jewish practices . Teresa of Avila’s grandfather, Juan Sanchez de Cepeda, and his son Alonso were Jewish converts who had reverted to their Jewish customs
 In 1485, the two men were “reconciled” to the Catholic Church by proceeding barefoot through the streets of Toledo wearing the sambenitos symbolizing their rapprochement .
 Teresa of Avila’s reforms, however, made religion a private, spiritual, detached-from-the-world relationship between humans and God . The reforms were made to make religion more of a private relationship with God .
 Teresa was born March 28, 1515, in Avila, Spain, in 1515 . Teresa’s calling to the faith occurred early in her life .
 She was one of 10 children of her father’s second wife, Teresa de Cepeda y Ahumada . She was born into a 10-strong family .
 In 1535, Teresa entered the Carmelite Monastery of the Incarnation, in Avila . Teresa was a nun at the Monastery . She is now a nun in the Spanish city of Avilas .
 The Carmelite ideal was to live a completely cloistered, or isolated, existence devoting oneself to prayer and contemplation . Carmelites were meant to live an isolated, or cloistered life devoting themselves to prayer .
 Teresa herself left the Incarnation three times . She returned home to recover from an illness, to nurse her father before his death, and to make a pilgrimage to a Spanish shrine .
 During one revelation, God exhorted her to reform the Carmelite order, which had lost some of its early zeal . The Carmelites lost some early zeal in the early years .
 Teresa founded a reformed house of Carmelite in 1562, called the “Discalced,” or unshod, order . The nuns adopted coarse clothing and sandals to wear, instead of shoes, to wear .
 At first, Teresa’s confessor and her other advisers had encouraged her in her plan to establish the new order, but when the townsfolk caught wind of the change, a public outcry erupted against her . Teresa's confessor: ‘Teresa’
 The opposition to the establishment of a new convent stemmed primarily from Teresa’s intention to operate the convent in complete poverty . Teresa wanted the convent to operate in poverty .
 City fathers complained that existing orders, too, were impoverished . The city could not stand the strain on its resources, they said . City fathers said existing orders were impoverished, too .
 Biographers contend that the objection put forth by the city officials masked their true fears that the reformed convent would be run separately, beyond the city’s control . Teresa's biographers say the objection was meant to be a cover up for the city .
 Teresa and her sister, Juana, and her brother-in-law, Juan de Ovalle, purchased a home in Avila to begin the life of the new order . Father Alvarez, lent his support, and Teresa and Juana bought a home for the order .
 Pope Gregory XIII recognized the Discalced Reform as a separate order in 1580 . The reform order was officially recognized by the Pope as an order of order .

 She insisted upon three prerequisites for a fulfilling Christian spiritual life . She insisted on three pre-requisites to a fulfilling spiritual life: faith, faith, prayer, love and prayer .
 One must remain emotionally detached from human beings in order to be able to devote one’s life wholly to God . At the same time, however, one must remain emotional detached from humans, says the author .
 Teresa described an observable path taken by Christians from conversion to Christianity, to death and salvation . She recognized that each individual’s path may differ from that taken by other believers, since God leads each person differently .
 Teresa, like other mystics in her time, conceived of Christ as a bridegroom .
 One’s spiritual journey, then, is really the progression that one makes before finally achieving a spiritual marriage with God . One's spiritual journey is to achieve a spiritual union with God, says author .
 Her book Castillo interior traces the spiritual journey toward communion with God . The author's latest book, Castillo Interior, is about the journey to God's side .
 Teresa used the idea of a multiroom castle as a metaphor for the journey one takes during one’s spiritual life . Teresa used it to be a symbol of the journey she takes during her life .

 Mother Teresa was the founder and leader of the Order of the Missionaries of Charity in India from 1950 until her death in 1997 . Mother Teresa died in 1997 at the age of 85 .
 The primary task of the Order of the Missionaries of Charity is to love and care for those persons for whom others are unwilling to assume care . The Order is to 'love and care' for those people for whom people are unwilling .
 The order includes more than 1,000 men and women in India . Many of them work as doctors, nurses, and social workers .
 The order has also undertaken relief work in African, Latin American, and Asian nations . It has outposts in Great Britain, Italy, Ireland, and the United States .
 Mother Teresa operated some 50 relief projects, including work among slum-dwellers, AIDS and leprosy victims, and undernourished children . Mother Teresa worked among slums, AIDS victims, children and AIDS victims .

 Corazon Aquino was elected the first woman president of the Philippines in 1986 . After upsetting Marcos in 1986, she upset Marcos and became the first female president .
 By creating and instituting a new constitution, Aquino ended the long period of dictatorship in the island nation . But her government was unable to effect other social changes .
 Aquino’s rise to power is a complicated one, involving the history of the Philippines, a nation of 54 million people living on 7,000 islands in the Pacific Ocean . Aquino is a former President of Philippines .
 Like many female politicians, Corazon Aquino became involved in politics after her husband, Benigno Simeon Aquino, died in 1983 . She became involved into politics after his death .
 Both husband and wife opposed the regime of Ferdinand Marcos, president and dictator . Marcos' wife Imelda opposed the Marcos regime . Marcos controlled the armed forces, national finances, and press .
 For the duration of his rule, his opposition floundered, weak and divided . The opposition to his rule of power has been a problem for the past two decades .
 The Aquinos married in 1954, after Corazon finished her education at Mount St. Mary's . Corazon and her husband were born in 1945 .
 Benigno Aquino entered politics after their marriage . He was the youngest mayor, governor, and senator to serve in the Philippines . He is married to the current president of Philippines .

 In 1983, Benigno Aquino returned to the Philippines, in order to support the opponents of Marcos . He returned in 1983 to support opposition to Marcos' regime .
 Corazon Aquino flew immediately to Manila to arrange his funeral and to continue his work in the next legislative election . The former President of the Philippines will be buried in his hometown .

 When the military threw its support to Aquino, Ferdinand Marcos fled to Hawaii, where he remained until his death in 1989 . Marcos remained in Hawaii until he died in 1989, when he was assassinated .
 Her goals were to restore democracy and free enterprise to the Philippines, she said . She said she wanted to restore free enterprise and democracy in the Philippines .
 She replaced Marcos’s appointees with popularly elected officials, put an end to martial law, and instituted a new constitution . To accomplish this, she replaced Marcos's appointees . She replaced many of his appointees, including those who were elected officials .
 The new constitution reaffirmed many of the principles of the Philippines’ first constitution written in 1935 . It was aimed at avoiding another Marcos. The constitution was written in the Philippines' first constitution .
 The Philippines limited the presidency to one six-year term and restricted the president’s powers to overrule Congress and impose martial law . The Philippines also limited the president's power to impose a state of martial law and impose a curfew .

 Sri Lankan prime minister Bandaranaike became the first female prime minister in the world in 1960 . She was Sri Lanka's first woman prime minister .
 Sri Lanka rejected its colonial past and became a nation with a new name and a new political identity . During her term, she rejected her colonial past .
 Sri Lanka, an island nation located off the southern tip of the Indian subcontinent, had been a British crown colony called Ceylon since 1802 . The island nation is now Sri Lanka .
 Sri Lanka's two largest ethnic groups are the majority Sinhalese and the Tamil, who have ties to groups living in southern India . The two largest groups of people live in Sri Lanka and Sri Lanka .
 Ceylon became an independent dominion and member of the British Commonwealth in 1948 . Ceylon has a parliamentary system modeled after that of that of Great Britain, headed by a prime minister .
 Sirimavo Bandaranaike's husband formed the SLFP in 1951 . The SLFP championed traditional culture and the eradication of Western influences . The party was formed by her husband, a former local government official .
 The 1956 elections swept the SLFP into power, with Solomon Bandaranaike becoming prime minister . The SLFP was elected to power in 1956 .
 He replaced English with Sinhala as the official language; he terminated the British military presence on the island . He declared Ceylon to be neutral in the global power struggle between communist and capitalist nations .
 Bandaranaike was at home raising her children and avoiding direct political involvement . Meanwhile, Benazir Bhutto was avoiding direct involvement with the government .
 Sirimavo was born on April 17, 1916, in Ratnapura, Ceylon . He was born in 1916 to Barnes Ratwatte Dissawa and Mahawalatenna Kumarihamy .
 St. Bridget’s, in the capital city of Colombo, remained a practicing Buddhist .
 When Solomon Bandaranaike declared Sinhala the national language, the policy enraged the Tamils, and tensions between the two ethnic groups increased .
 Compromises enabled the Tamils to retain their language in areas in the north and east of the island, where they formed a majority .
 Sirimavo's leadership in the SLFP bore seed; the parry won a majority in Parliament, and Bandaranaike became the first woman prime minister .
 She mediated an end to the India/China border conflict of 1962, when China invaded India and occupied its northeast provinces . She was also involved in the 1962 border conflict between India and China .
 Bandaranaike credited with working out a solution with Indian prime minister Lai Bahadur Shastri regarding the political status of Indian-born plantation workers in Ceylon . Most of the workers had been disenfranchised after Ceylon’s independence from Britain .
 Sirimavo-Shastri Pact conferred either Ceylonese or Indian citizenship on workers on a proportionate basis . The pact was ratified by the Indian Council of States of India .
 Bandaranaike’s economic policy called for the nationalization of the American and British oil companies operating in Ceylon . Bandareanaike's economic policy was to nationalize the companies .
 Bandaranaike’s government fell, and in the 1965 elections she lost her position . She was forced to resign as a result of the fall .
 She retained her leadership within the SLFP, however, and in 1970, she regained the position of prime minister .
 Bandaranaike implemented other socialist measures, such as the nationalization of tea plantations, and restricted the amount of land held under private ownership .
 He set up a commission to investigate charges of nepotism against Sirimavo Bandaranaike when she was prime minister . The commission was set up to look into allegations of corruption against her .
 She had named herself minister of planning and economic affairs, and of defense and external affairs .
 Her nephew, sons, and daughter also held government posts during her term . Her nephews, sons and daughters were also in government posts .
 As a result of the inquiry, Bandaranaike lost her civic rights for seven years . The inquiry was conducted by the Sri Lankan government .
 Prime Minister Jayawardene had amended the constitution to create the new, more powerful office of president, to which he was elected . The constitution has been amended to create a more powerful presidency .
 In 1994, Chandrika Kumaratunge was elected president, and she appointed her mother prime minister . Chandrika was appointed prime minister in 1994 . Her daughter Chandrika appointed her as president .

 Sirimavo Bandaranaike died on October 10, 2000, moments after casting her vote in the 2000 parliamentary elections in Sri Lanka .
 In 1501, she instituted two new professorships of divinity at Oxford and Cambridge, and completed the endowment of Christ’s College at Cambridge .
 Margaret Beaufort was born on May 31, 1443 . She was the daughter of John Beaufort, first duke of Somerset and great grandson of King Edward III . Margaret was carefully educated by her mother, Margaret St. St. John .
 Rumors circulated that John Beaufort had died by his own hand, after disastrous military campaigns in France . Rumors of his death were circulated that he died by the death of his father .
 Margaret had a claim to the throne as long as King Henry VI remained childless . Margaret was born in 16th century England . She was the last monarch to be childless and ruled over for three decades .
 The duke of Suffolk knew this and had Margaret Beaufort married at the age of seven to his son (only a year older than she) to intertwine his family with a contender to the throne . Margaret was only seven when she was married to her son .
 Under law, Margaret could refuse to ratify the union, which she ultimately did . Margaret could also refuse to accept the union .
 When Margaret Beaufort turned 10, her mother was commanded to bring the girl to court . Margaret was ordered to bring her to court by her mother .
 King Henry VI ordered that his ‘well-beloved cousin Margaret’ be paid a hundred marks for dresses . The allowance was four times the income of a well-to-do squire . King Henry VIII must have been impressed by his generosity .
 On May 12, 1453, the king gave her as a ward to his half-brother Edmund Tudor, commanding that he marry her . The queen died in 1453 . She was given to Edmund's half-sister, who was in charge of Edmund's family .
 Margaret gave birth to their son, Henry Tudor, later Henry VII, in 1457 . Margaret was married to Henry VIII, Henry VII .
 Lord Stafford died in 1471, leaving Margaret Beaufort widowed once again . Lord Stafford was married to Lord Beaufort's wife .
 In 1472, Margaret married her fourth husband, Thomas, Lord Stanley . She was not yet 30 when she married him . She died in 1472 .
 Lord Stanley was instrumental in bringing about an end to the War of the Roses . Lord Stanley helped end the war of Roses in England .
 The Lancastrian monarch, Henry VI, was constantly challenged by the duke of York and his supporters in southern England . Henry VI's reign was ended by the death of his son, Henry VIII .
 Richard III's brother and successor was Richard III . His reign saw the growth of support for the exiled Lancastrian Henry Tudor, Margaret Beaufort .
 Henry Tudor ruled as Henry VII, the first of the new Tudor dynasty that would remain until 1603 . Henry VII was Henry VII of the Tudors, who ruled until 1602 .
 To end the fighting, Henry VII married Elizabeth of York, daughter of Edward IV, uniting the two former opponents . Henry VII's marriage to Elizabeth unifies the two ex-royalties .
 Parliament declared Margaret Beaufort a “femme sole,” giving her the right to hold property in her name and sue in the courts, regardless of her husband . No other married woman in England had that right .

 Egyptian queen Hatshepsut was the second female king in Egyptian history . She was the first female queen in Egypt's history .
 Her reign as Egypt’s king occurred during the New Kingdom . The New Kingdom was during the reunification of the ancient Egyptian empire through the expulsion of foreign invaders .
 Hatshepsut’s rule coincided with a general peace, prosperity, and extended trade throughout the Middle East . The king's rule was one of the most successful monarchs in the region .
 Based on the work of Egypt’s first historian Manetho, modern historians have divided Egyptian history into three major periods known as the Old Kingdom, Middle Kingdom, and New Kingdom . The New Kingdom is the third period of Egyptian history .
 Each period was characterized by long-term stability, strong monarchical authority, and impressive intellectual, cultural, and architectural activity . Each period is characterized by strong monarchial authority .
 Lower Egypt includes the Nile Delta at the mouth of the Mediterranean Sea . Upper Egypt includes first and second cataracts (or waterfalls) of the Nile River, the boundaries that mark Egypt’s border with Sudan today .
 From around 1640 B.C.E. much of Egypt was ruled by the Hyksos, a Semitic people from the Levant . They gradually took control of Lower Egypt, which they ruled from their capital at Avaris .
 Upper Egypt remained independent, ruled by the royal dynasty at the city of Thebes . Upper Egypt was ruled by Thebes and ruled by a royal dynasty .
 Hyksos rule made Egypt more open to foreign influences, such as the use of bronze, war chariots, and weapons including the composite bow and scale armor . Egypt was the first to use bronze, chariots and composite bows .
 The Hyksos introduced new crops, new fashions, and new musical instruments . Hykos introduce new crops and musical instruments to the world .
 Lower and Upper Nubia, in presentday Sudan, came under Egyptian control as well, becoming a great source of wealth . Upper and Lower Nubya was also a source of great wealth .
 At the time, a female king, that is, a woman who ruled in her own right, without the help of a man, was practically unheard of in Egyptian history . A female king was virtually unheard of .
 Women's ability to rule Egypt was limited to passing the throne to the next king through marriage . Egypt's women were able to pass on the throne through marriage to the king .
 The royal blood could only be passed down through marriage and procreation by the oldest princess . The oldest princess could pass down the royal blood through marriage .

 By the 1950s, the United States government’s policy toward its Native American population had reversed courses once again . The U.S. government's policy toward Native Americans in the 1930s was reversed .
 In the early 20th century, the government had tried to “kill the Indian, save the man” by forcing Native American boys and girls to dress like European Americans and speak only English .
 In the 1930s, the government had given up assimilation policies in favor of tribal sovereignty . After World War II, policy-makers reversed gears again and pursued a program designed to encourage Native Americans to be like city-dwelling Euro-Americans .
 The Bureau of Indian Affairs produced hundreds of “relocation” propaganda posters . They promised American Indians jobs and happy homes in America’s urban centers in exchange for leaving reservation .
 The term relocation embraced several policies, including termination of tribal organizations, greater U.S. legal jurisdiction over tribal organizations . Relocation of Indian families from reservations to United States cities was a key policy .

 Organic reading method is organic in that the student’s vocabulary grows naturally and not by memorizing lists of vocabulary words . The organic reading method was developed in the 1970s .
 These are words that the student articulates as words he or she wants to learn . These words are the words that students want to learn to use . Students can use these words to express their desire to learn.
 The teacher acts as scribe by writing the words down and then helping the student to spell and to learn different forms of the words .
 In the second movement, the student forms sentences based on his or her key vocabulary . In the first movement, a student forms phrases based on key words .
 The teacher writes the sentences down initially, using correct spelling, but copying the student’s grammar as he or she verbalizes the sentence . The teacher uses correct spelling and correct grammar to help students understand their sentences .
 The third movement has students exchanging sentences, adding words that they like from other students' key vocabularies . Students exchange sentences with words they like to hear from others .
 Teachers assign students to make up stories using the words in their key vocabularies . Teachers also assign stories to students who use their key words in key stories .
 Taken as a whole, the four-movement process can be used at any grade level . It can also be used with students who are learning a second language .

 French philosopher and writer Simone de Beauvoir's existentialist and feminist ideas became the battle cry of the women’s rights movement of the late 20th century .
 In The Second Sex, she undermines the notion that women’s lives are tied irrevocably to their maternal function . She says society has made women think so .
 Beauvoir was born January 9, 1908, in Paris . She was the daughter of a lawyer and a homemaker . She looked upon her parents' marriage with apprehension .
 As the family’s income dwindled during World War I, Beauvoir noticed that the unpleasant housework performed by her mother kept her from earning money . The unpleasant work prevented her from being able to earn money .
 In any case, Beauvoir vowed never to marry or have children; she pursued an education instead . She pursued a career in politics instead .
 At 15, she fell in love with her cousin, Jacques Champigneulles . Her parents had sent her to a Catholic school where she was at 15 . She fell into love with him .
 He introduced her to French novels, books that caught her mother’s attention and her immediate disapproval . Her mother's approval of the French novels caught her attention .
 Madame Beauvoir pinned together pages in the books that she did not want her daughters to read . The pages were pinned together by the French author .
 When Jacques Champigneulles married a wealthy young woman, Beauvoir’s obsession with him ended . The French writer was obsessed with the Frenchman .
 She went on to study philosophy at the Sorbonne, an elite university in Paris . She met her lifelong companion, the philosopher Jean-Paul Sartre, in 1929 . She was married to the philosopher, who she met in 1929, in France .
 Sartre’s ideas about human freedom, explained in his book Being and Nothingness, influenced her life and her work . The French philosopher's work influenced her work and her life .
 The two remained lifelong companions until Sartre’s death in 1980, although they never married and only briefly shared an apartment . The two never married .
 Beauvoir taught philosophy at Marseilles, Rouen, and Paris, but her philosophy is best understood through her written work .
 Beauvoir and Sartre helped to popularize a school of philosophy known as existentialism . The term encompasses ideas about individual choice, the absence of rational understanding of the universe which limits rational choice, and the resulting sense of the absurdity of human life .
 Existentialists resist the notion that there is any intelligible system of meaning in life . They say that there are no intelligible systems of meaning .
 In the meaningless, irrational universe in which we live, we have only our freedom of choice . In the face of the irrational universe, we are only free to choose our choices . We have no choice but to choose what we want.
 If a woman says she cannot choose to work because she has to care for children, a Beauvoirian existentialist might respond by saying that the woman chooses to think of her situation in that way, not in a way that might help her discover other options .
 Beauvoir’s feminist position, as found in The Second Sex, is existentialist, in that she argues against biological determinism and in favor of individual choice . Beauvois argues that individual choice is individual choice, not biological determined .
 Beauvoir wrote The Second Sex in part to discover the extent to which the course of her own life was determined by the fact that she was born female instead of male . She wrote the book to discover how her life was affected by being born a woman .
 Using her life as a springboard, she goes on to analyze women’s roles in society through mythology, political theory, history, and psychology . She also analyzes mythology and political theory .
 She advises women to pursue interests beyond the home and family . She says marriage and motherhood render women into ‘relative beings’; that is, individuals whose lives are dependent upon their relationship to others .
 In the latter, Beauvoir speculates on how her life might have been different had she not met Jean-Paul Sartre or made certain other choices .
 By the time of her own death on April 14, 1986, Beauvoir had become a symbol for women’s equality . She had become an icon for women's equality .
 She had also been president of the League for the Rights of Women, a group that helped battered wives, working women and single mothers .

 During this period of European history, scientific and philosophical inquiry had reached its peak . During this time, scientific inquiry was at its peak in Europe .

 An Essay on Human Feeling is a three-volume work written between 1967 and 1982 . It is written in three volumes .
 The third volume of the set concludes in outline form, because hanger’s worsening eyesight and other health problems precluded its completion . The hanger is now retired .
 In this final odyssey into the mind, Langer relates her theories of language, aesthetics, and the mind to the evolution of the human being . Langer: The evolution of language and aesthetics is an important part of our evolution .
 Langer concluded that humans evolved into a higher life-form because our posture, hands, and central nervous systems enabled us to improve our abilities to create symbols to communicate to each other .
 Human evolution has been the process of improving our responses to each other and to our environment . Human evolution is the result of improving responses to the environment and the environment, says the author .
 She won the Radcliffe achievement medal in 1950, the Edgar Kaufmann Charitable Trust research grant in 1956 and several honorary doctorates .
 Langer was a small, suntanned “woman of iron will, impatient of laziness and self-indulgence” Langer preferred solitude in her colonial house in Old Lyme, Connecticut, to company .
 Sindiwe Magona's life convincingly illustrates the power of politics over an individual’s life and career . The South African teacher, human rights worker and writer is a former human rights activist .
 Her autobiography To My Childrens Children recounts her experiences as an African teacher in a nation darkened by apartheid .
 The book earned an honorable mention in the 1991 Noma Award for Publishing in Africa . The book was published in 1991 .
 Magona completed her teaching certificate in 1961 . She taught at Hlengisa Higher Primary School in Nyanga, a village just west of Cape Town . She is survived by her husband and three children .
 Magona expected to be able to implement skills she had been taught . But she found that the harsh reality of impoverished black African schools, intensified by apartheid, required much more of her than she had dreamed .
 Sindiwe Magona was born in the village of Tsolo but grew up in Cape Town’s black townships . She is the second of eight children and grew up with eight black children in Cape Cape Town . Sindiw Magono was born and raised in
 The South African national government began instituting apartheid in 1948 . To My Childrens Children was published by Magona in 1988 .
 Black Africans forced to relocate into segregated home283 SCHOLARS AND EDUCATORS lands in rural areas and black townships in urban centers . Black Africans were forced to move into segregated homes and schools in urban areas .
 Magona experienced the upheaval of relocation and then the consequent erosion of traditional tribal African life . The upheaval was the result of relocation .
 Magona’s father worked as a gas station attendant . The father-of-one worked as an attendant at a local gas station .
 She went to St. Matthews Training School in Nyanga and then completed her primary school teaching certificate .
 Unable to find work for several months, she worked at a fish market in the black township Guguletu, north of Cape Town .
 Magona was a teacher at Nyanga School in Nyanga, Tanzania, in 1961 . She was given a contract to teach in the second quarter .
 She marched confidently to the school building building the following week . Thrilled, she marched confidently into the building following week.
 Chipper and bright in beige skirt, blazer, and kid gloves, Magonas face fell when she saw her students .
 Seventy-two African pupils stared expectantly at her as she walked into the room . She was greeted by a group of African pupils .
 She had been expecting 11and 12-year-olds; instead, they ranged from age nine to 19 . She was expecting 11-12-years-old; instead she was expecting nine-to-19 . The children range from age 9 to 19.
 She reported that the skill levels of her students varied just as widely . She said she was surprised by the wide range of skill levels .
 On her first day, she resorted to remedial lessons when she discovered that most of the pupils could not do simple arithmetic .
 She divided the class into the capable and incapable, and she planned lessons off the top of her head accordingly . She planned lessons based on the fact that she was incapable and capable .
 She made up a story problem involving corrals and cattle to teach remedial students how to do addition and subtraction . Students already able to do math were asked to read their Xhosa language books quietly .
 Magona taught her 72 students Xhosa language, English, Afrikaans, health education, social studies, music, math, and religious education .
 South Africa’s currency) went to white students, while R28 was spent on blacks . South Africa's currency (R28) went for white students .
 The classrooms in which Magona taught were extremely overcrowded . Even though, the classrooms were overcrowded, they were extremely crowded .
 Magona lamented that she could only encourage above-average students to excel on their own . The time she spent trying to help remedial students was never enough, she said .
 In 1961, three things happened to Magona that impressed upon her the intertwining of the personal and the political . In 1961 she was inspired by the events of that year's events .
 Two students met their deaths at school when the floor covering the pit toilets collapsed and they drowned; and South Africa became a republic . She, like all other black South Africans, was forced to carry a pass with her wherever she went .
 In 1962, only three months after her second year of teaching began, Magona was forced to resign when she became pregnant . It was against department regulations for unmarried mothers to teach .
 In 1967, she returned to teaching primary school until 1980, and then she taught high school Xhosa until 1981 . In 1967 she taught primary school . She also taught primary and high school high school .
 Maria Montessori was the founder of the first school system for children . Her method of education is the chosen method of thousands of private schools throughout the world .
 Montessori's method is based on the notion that children exhibit creativity and an interest in learning during certain periods of childhood . Teachers should make the most of these periods by encouraging independent learning in each child .
 Maria was born on August 31, 1870, in Chiarivalle, Italy, in the province of Ancona on the central coast of the Adriatic Sea .
 Her father was an army officer who discouraged Maria’s interest in pursuing a career . Maria's father was a military officer who encouraged her to join the army .
 Maria's mother, however, disagreed with her father and supported Maria's dreams . Her mother also supported Maria’s dreams and supported her daughter's dream .
 When Maria was 12, the family relocated to Rome, where the young girl could take advantage of better schools . Maria's mother moved her to the city of Rome, Italy, when she was 12 years old . Maria is now in the middle of a career in journalism .
 She announced an interest in mechanical engineering and math when she was 14 . She sought out classes at a technical institute at age 14 .
 She soon switched her area of study to biology and then decided to study medicine . She then switched her interest to biology before deciding to become a doctor .
 Medical careers, except in the fledging occupation of nursing, were seen as inappropriate for women . Medical careers were also seen as unsuitable for women in the 1930s .
 In 1896, Montessori became the first woman to receive a medical degree in Italy . She specialized in pediatrics and psychiatry; she specialized in pediatriciatrics .
 She decided to view education as a science requiring observation and experimentation . She decided she wanted to focus on the science of education .
 She concluded that children build themselves from what they find in their learning environment . She said children learn from their own environment .
 Much of her work at the clinic involved retarded children . She became convinced that handling retarded children was more a question of instructional method than medical treatment .
 Montessori created methods for teaching retarded children and instructing employees in her method . The method was created to teach the retarded children .
 Montessori gained recognition for her methods when many of her retarded students passed the standard sixth-grade tests of Italian public schools . Her methods helped her students pass the standard 6th grade tests of public schools in Italy .
 The government had put her in charge of a state-supported school in a slum area of Rome . The school is really more of a day-care center for preschoolers .
 This gave her a chance to test what she had learned about child development, in her work with retarded children, on other children . It gave her an opportunity to test her knowledge of child development on other kids .
 Montessori called the center the Casa dei Bambini, or Children’s House . The center was the center for children in the 1960s and 1970s .
 Montessori purposely called it a house rather than a school, for she viewed education for young children as a process that could be done anywhere that children were free to act on their environment . She viewed education as an educational process, not a school .
 She found that education is not something that a teacher does, but rather, it is a process that develops spontaneously in all human beings . Education is not a teacher's job, but it's a process of developing spontaneously .
 The teacher's task is to arrange an environment that will stimulate and motivate learning . The teacher’s task, then, is to organise an environment where learning is stimulated .
 Montessori had carpenters build child-sized tables and desks . Carpenters were used to build the tables for children .
 She recognized that an adult-sized world frustrates children, which is not conducive to learning . An adult-size world is not a good environment for children, she said .
 Montessori designed child-sized toilets, lowered windows, and lowered bookshelves . In a sense, she became an environmental engineer designing child-size toilets and lowered windows .
 Montessori was also a womens rights activist . Her primary energies were devoted to education . She also campaigned for women's rights .
 In 1915, Montessori attracted the world’s attention with her Casa dei Bambini exhibit at the Panama-Pacific International Exhibition in San Francisco . The exhibit was the first of its kind in the world .
 The Spanish government asked her to open a research institute . Two years later, she was asked to open an institute in Spain .
 She continued her work worldwide until her death on May 6, 1952, lecturing and opening new teaching institutes . The Association Montessori Internationale, in 1929, still exists today .
 Montessori influenced Anna FREUD, Jean Piaget, Alfred Adler, Erik Erikson, and countless others involved in child psychology and education . Anna Freud is the founder of the Montessoria Foundation .
 She was nominated for the Nobel Peace Prize three times, in 1949, 1950, and 1951 . She had been nominated three times for the Peace Prize, three times .
 She is credited with developing the open classroom, individualized education, teaching toys, and alternative instruction .

 Olimpia Fulvia Morato thanks her tutor for encouraging her learning . Olympia Morata is a 14-year-old Italian .
 Morata was born nine years after the Protestant Reformation shook European society . Morata is born in Morata, Italy, in 17th century .
 In 1517, Martin Luther nailed his 95 theses to the church door in Wittenberg, Germany . The 95-theses were nailed to the door of the church in 1517 . Martin Luther had nailed the theses on the door to a church door . Luther's 95
 Theses were statements of protest against the Catholic Church’s practice of the selling of indulgences that supposedly granted a person pardon from sin . The theses were theses of protest .
 Luther proposed that each individual believer could be saved from sin only through her or his faith in Christ, not through a priest’s mediation . Luther: "Each individual believer can be saved only through their faith"
 Protestantism spread throughout Europe in the 16th century, aided by the printing press and translations of Protestant works from the Latin into vernacular languages . The printing press helped spread Protestantism throughout Europe .
 Olympia had learned two classical and one vernacular language by the age of 12 . Olympia had also learned two vernal and two classical languages by age of 11 .
 Her early life at court perpetuated her studies and introduced her to Protestantism . Additionally, she also introduced her Protestantism to her early life .
 Renee brought to the Italian court liberal ideas about religion . She welcomed a number of Protestant guests, including John Calvin and Clement Marot .
 Morata reveled in the spirited religious and philosophical debates she heard in court among Europe’s finest thinkers . Morata was invited by Renee to tutor her youngest daughter, Anne .
 In 1543, Morata’s world faced dark threats from the Counter, or Catholic, Reformation . Counter-Catholic Reformation defended the Catholic Church against the Protestant Reformation, while reforming the church's abuses . Morata's world was threatened by the Counter-Reformation
 Pope Paul III visited Ferrara in 1543 and established a Council of Inquisitors to ferret out heretics . The Council was established by the Pope in 1542 .
 Morata visited him in prison, and her friend Princess Lavinia della Rovere traveled to Rome to intervene on his behalf, but to no avail . Morata died in prison in 1944 .
 In 1554, Renee herself capitulated and attended Mass, probably to save her own neck . Renee attended Mass in 1554 .
 Olympia Morata was absent while the worst of the Inquisition swept through the court . Fortunately, she was absent from the court while it was under attack .
 She was ill much of the time and then left to attend to her sick father, who died in 1548 . The queen was ill during her time in England .
 Her former pupil Anne married the Duke de Guise and left Ferrara for France . Her pupil Anne was married to the Duke of Guise .
 After 1548, the Ferrara court no longer welcomed Olympia Morata, whereupon she began tutoring her younger siblings at home . The Ferrara Court no longer allowed her to attend court events .
 The following year, Olympia met Andreas Grundler, a scholar from Schweinfurt, Bavaria . Olympia met the scholar at the end of her trip to the University of Munich .
 While Grundler studied medicine in Ferrara, the two fell in love and married in a Protestant wedding ceremony in 1550 . The two were married in Protestant wedding ceremonies in 1549 .
 After Grundler finished his degree, he began looking for a position at a university in Germany . He left his bride behind to care for her brothers and sisters . Grundlers' wife was left to look after her siblings and her family .
 In June 1550, Grundler returned to Italy, and he and his wife and her brother Emilio left Italy forever . In 1550 he and her family were forced to leave Italy forever.
 Morata's family moved to Schweinfurt in the summer of 1551 . Grundler was hired as a physician and Morata could resume writing projects .
 Morata's Dialogue of Theophila and Philotina is Morata’s most significant work . Morata was born in Rome, Italy, and lived there with his wife and children in the 1930s .
 Morata’s work was shaped by the Protestant notion of personal salvation . Theophila and Philotina converse on matters of worldly pleasures, suffering, sin, and individual responsibility .
 Theophila urges her companion to expend her energies seeking God through scriptures, for only God, she promised, could sate her earthly desires . She promised, she also promised, that only God could satisfy her earthly needs .
 Germany experienced its own turbulence during the mid-16th century . Far from being a refuge from the Inquisition, Germany experienced turbulence .
 Schweinfurt was occupied for 14 months, during which time half of the city’s population expired from the Black Plague . About half of city's population died from the plague during that time .
 Occupying soldiers had not been paid, Morata reported in a letter written to her sister Victoria in Ferrara . The town’s resources were being depleted by the angry mobs of soldiers .
 For several weeks, Morata nursed her husband through a bout with the plague . She nursed him through several weeks of illness .
 During the waning months of the siege, the family hid in a wine cellar during the siege . The family was forced to hide in the wine cellar for months .
 Grundler, Morata, and her brother fled to Heidelberg, leaving behind all their possessions, including Morata’s substantial library . The family was forced to flee to the city, leaving all of their possessions behind .
 Morata and his team-mates made the journey on foot, the latter half of it with no shoes . They made their way to the Santiago Bernabeu with the help of Morata's wife .
 Morata set out to rebuild her library, but in the summer of 1555, she too fell victim to the plague as it swept through Heidelberg, her last refuge . Morata died of the plague in 1555 .
 Morata's house in Schweinfurt was later rebuilt, and a commemoration to Morata was set at its entrance . The house Morata occupied was later built, and was later set at the entrance .

 Indian womens rights advocate and educator Dhanvanthi Rama Rau was one of the first Indian women to attend college and to teach at an institution of higher learning in India . She was the first woman in India to be allowed to study in college .
 She became secretary of the All-India Child Marriage Abolition League . She became a member of the International Alliance for Suffrage and Equal Citizenship . She also became president of the Women's Conference .
 Her primary concern, however, was in the area of family planning and birth control . She said she was concerned about birth control and family planning .
 She worked for the Family Planning Association of India from 1949 to 1963 . She was president of the International Planned Parenthood Association from 1963 to 1971 .
 Rau was born on May 10, 1893, to Rup Krishna Handoo and Bhagbhari Shah, Kashmiri Brahmins from the northern region of India . He was born in Kashmiri Bhagbari Shah .
 The Brahmin class is the highest class, as the Brahmins were Hindu priests . Brahmin is a Brahmin Hindu priest .
 Dhanvanthi’s father was an official on the government-owned Southern Mratha Railway . He was a railway official .
 The railway was headquartered in Hubli, and the family lived in one of several modest homes in the new section of town known as the Railway Colony . The family was moved to the railway colony of Hubli .
 There was little interaction between the Indian population that lived and marketed their goods in the center of the village and the railroad officials who lived in the Railway Colony .
 St. Mary’s Catholic school was built by Catholic missionaries in the 1880s . It was the first Catholic school built by the missionaries .
 Her male colleagues protested Rau’s presence daily, calling her a traitor to her caste . Rau's male colleagues called her a 'traitor' to their caste .
 While at the university, Rau learned of the tremendous social changes brewing in India, and of the small professional class of women working as doctors, lawyers, and teachers .
 When she received her M.A. from the university, she began lecturing, in English, at Queen Mary’s College in Madras .
 Dhanvanthi’s parents were still strict Hindus and insisted that she marry . Although they encouraged her education, they still insisted on her marrying .
 Sir Benegal Narsing Rama Rau was a Cambridge-educated, liberal-minded official in the Indian Civil Service . His parents arranged a marriage between their daughter and Sir Bengal Narsi Rau . They arranged the marriage between them and a Cambridge educated official in India
 The two wed in 1919, relieving Dhanvanthi’s parents of the prospect of a spinster daughter . The two were able to live outside of the confines of a traditional Indian household .
 During the early years of her marriage, Rau kept her house and raised two daughters, Santha and Premila . She kept her home and raised her two daughters . Rau was married to Rau's first husband and died in 2003 .
 In a November 1953 interview with the American magazine Glamour, Rau explained the traditional Indian marriage . Rau was married to an Indian woman .
 Rau was elected secretary of the All-India Child Marriage Abolition League . Rau campaigned actively for the Sarda Act, which raised the legal age of marriage for girls to 14 .
 Her involvement in trying to abolish child marriages led to her interest in woman suffrage . Quite naturally, her involvement led to an interest in the issue .
 She and her family lived in England from 1929 to 1938, where she met other suffrage advocates . In 1932, she joined the International Alliance for Suffrage and Equal Citizenship .
 Both husband and wife desired independence for their homeland, but since Rama Rau was employed by the government, they could do nothing overtly to effect change .
 After Indian independence, Rau returned to India and launched her crusade for emancipating women through the use of birth control .
 Rau and her allies felt that women’s lives in India were crippled by incessant child-bearing . Rau said that women were crippled in India .
 Her goal was to introduce birth control methods to women living in the 550,000 villages . Her goal is to bring birth control to women in the villages . She says birth control is a vital part of the survival of the world's poorest people .
 From 1963 to 1971, Rau served as president of the International Planned Parenthood Association . Rau is credited with saving the lives of Planned Parenthood .
 Her daughter, Santha Rama Rau, became a novelist and writer . Her granddaughter, Aisha Wayle, became the first woman to own a London investment company .
 American political and social activist and educator Eleanor Roosevelt’s life spanned some of the most crucial decades in American social and political history . Eleanor Roosevelt was an educator and activist .
 Eleanor Roosevelt oversaw many of the programs designed to bring relief to millions of Americans during the Great Depression . Her husband, Franklin Delano Roosevelt, became president during the Depression .
 She lived to see the Kennedy administration’s Peace Corps program coalesce . She had been appointed to be an adviser to that organization when she died in 1962 .
 Roosevelt was an author, diplomat, and political activist whose name became synonymous with liberal causes such as social and racial equality .
 Eleanor Roosevelt promised some of the most neglected people within the United States—women and African Americans—that the federal government was their government, too .
 Roosevelt's political philosophy can be partly explained by her traumatic childhood . Roosevelt’s political philosophy is at least partly explained, she says . Roosevelt was a victim of a traumatic childhood, she writes .
 By the time she was 10 years old, all of her immediate family had died except one of her brothers . By the age of 10, she was at the center of her life .
 Eleanor Roosevelt's father was Elliot Roosevelt, brother of U.S. President Theodore Roosevelt . Eleanor's father, Elliot Roosevelt , loved her dearly but disappointed her repeatedly . Elliot Roosevelt was the brother of Theodore Roosevelt, who died in 1918 .
 Elliot Roosevelt made promises to spend time with his daughter, but instead he spent hours drinking in bars . Elliot Roosevelt was an alcoholic who spent hours in bars every night .
 Eleanor’s mother grew embarrassed by what she saw as her daughter's unattractive appearance . In the meantime, her mother was worried about her daughter’tattattattability .
 The children were sent to live with their grandmother, where Eleanor’s older brother died . The children are now living with her grandmother in the UK .
 When she turned 15, Eleanor’s grandmother sent her to a finishing school in England . She was sent to the finishing school when she was just 15 .
 The finishing school, operated by Mademoiselle Souvestre, imbued its charges with a sense of social responsibility . It is now a finishing school in Paris, France .
 Her cousin Franklin Roosevelt tried to woo her away from her work . Meanwhile, however, she was being wooed by her cousin .
 From 1906 until 1916, Eleanor Roosevelt gave birth to six children, one of whom did not survive infancy . One of her six children was not born alive .
 During World War I, Eleanor did relief work for the Red Cross and toured battlefields in Europe . She toured the battlefields and toured Europe during the war .
 After the war, an event occurred in her family that would change her private and public life forever . Her family was devastated by the loss of her life .
 Eleanor coaxed her husband back into public life after her mother-in-law wanted him to retire . Franklin Franklin's wife, Eleanor, was forced to give up politics and retire immediately .
 At the same time, she pursued social activism, working for the League of Women Voters, the National Consumer's League, and the Women’s Trade Union League .
 When FDR was elected president in 1932, Eleanor became the most loved and most hated first lady in U.S. history . She was also the most disliked first lady of all time . FDR's wife was the most hated and most loved first lady .
 Eleanor Roosevelt hated parties unless they served a larger political or social function . Eleanor Roosevelt, however, hated parties, unless they were for a larger purpose .

 She became a frequent visitor to poor neighborhoods and towns where working women, African Americans, and tenant farmers were struggling to feed their families . She visited working women and African Americans in poor neighborhoods, towns .
 Eleanor Roosevelt wanted to secure equal opportunities for other neglected segments of American society . Eleanor Roosevelt was assassinated in 1944 .
 She promoted the cause of Arthurdale, a farming cooperative built by the government for unemployed miners in Appalachia . She helped organize the National Youth Administration in 1935, a program designed to provide work for unemployed youth .
 For the first time since Reconstruction, African Americans felt that the federal government was willing to assist them in their plight . African Americans feel that the government is willing to help them in the struggle .
 After FDR’s death in 1945, Eleanor Roosevelt shifted her focus to educating the nation in its new role within the newly organized United Nations .
 Frances Elizabeth Caroline Willard was an educator and international temperance leader . "DO EVERYTHING,” exhorted Frances Willard of students and fellow temperance advocates .
 The phrase became one of her favorite slogans during the years when she led the American movement against the excessive consumption of alcohol .
 The intellectual life of America’s foremost social activist is riddled with paradox, he says . The social activist's life has been filled with paradoxes .
 Willard argued that a woman’s primary duty was to devote herself to home and family . A skillful and charismatic leader and public speaker, Willard was known for his charismatic style .
 Never before in their history had American women left the house in so many numbers and with such alacrity . For while 19th-century Victorian women were steeped in ‘separate spheres’ ideology .
 Willard’s advocacy of women leaving the home to lobby for temperance resulted, in part, from her experiences as an educator . Willard's advocacy was based on experiences as a teacher .
 Willard advocated temperance because she felt that inebriated husbands and fathers threatened the firm moral and financial foundation upon which the home rested .
 When Frances Willard turned two, her father sold his large farm and business and moved the family to Ohio . Josiah and Mary Willard both attended Oberlin College .
 The Willards moved back to Janesville, Wisconsin, where they resumed farming . Five years later, the family relocated once again to the Willards' hometown .
 Mary Willard tutored Frances at home, except for a few years that she spent attending rural schools . Frances Willard was tutored at home by Willard until she died .
 Frances Willard was president of the National Women’s Christian Temperance Union for nearly 20 years . At the age of 18, Willard entered the Milwaukee Female Col. Col. Willard .
 During the decade following her graduation, Willard faced several important crossroads . Willard's life was at the center of her career .
 She became engaged in 1860 to Charles Fowler, a Methodist minister whom she admired and respected but did not love . She was engaged to Fowler in 1860 .
 For months she turned over the engagement in her mind and heart, finally deciding that she could not fulfill her own ambitions to lead American women in a political movement and be a proper wife to a husband .
 Frances Willard was deeply attached to and in love with Mary Bannister, who ultimately married Frances’s brother Oliver Willard .
 In the midst of this emotional turmoil, Willard began her teaching career . Willard is now a teacher in Texas .
 Willard is best known for her work in temperance . Willard's first career was in education .
 She taught school in rural Illinois and in an Illinois academy during the 1860s, during which time she also wrote her first book .
 She spent two years in Europe and the Near East, studying at the Sorbonne and the College de France in Paris .
 When she returned to the U.S. she accepted a post as president of Evanston College for Ladies . When she left, she became the president of the college .
 In her post, Willard began meeting women leaders of the suffrage and temperance movements, especially those living in the eastern part of the U.S. Willard met many women leaders in her post .
 She disagreed with Northwestern’s administration over the governance of the division . She resigned her position in 1874, but disagreed with the administration .
 Temperance had long been a concern among religious leaders in the United States . Frances Willard raised the movement into a vigorous political force by making it a women’s issue . Temperance was a women's issue .
 Willard felt that women’s views were needed in all aspects of society, but temperance struck a chord in her because of the pernicious effect alcoholism was having on the home .
 She wrote letters to newspapers, published pamphlets, made speeches, and organized locals . She soon transformed herself into the powerhouse behind the organization .
 In 1879 she became the WCTU’s president . Few questioned her talent and drive, and in 1879, she became president .
 Under Willard’s leadership, the WCTU grew in membership, expanded its interests to include suffrage . Willard supported the kindergarten movement, lobbied for federal aid to education, promoted vocational training .
 The WCTU lobbied successfully for compulsory temperance education and raising the age of consent . Well before women had won the right to vote in the United States .

 Historians present a fairly clear picture of what life was like for women in Greek society . Historians draw from a wealth of ancient Greek texts to present a picture .
 From about the sixth century B.C.E. onward, Greek philosophers began to study the world as an objective phenomenon that humans could view in a rational, scientific manner . The world was studied by Greek philosophers from the 6th century to 7th century .
 Political decentralization and the formation of strong poleis, or city-states, also characterized the Hellenistic Age . Rivalry and warfare between poleis also characterized Hellenism .
 Agnodike was probably born not long after Alexander the Great . Alexander the Macedonian ruler, conquered Greece, Persia, and Egypt, conquered the region .
 Xenophon stated in his Economicus that the duty of a woman or wife was to manage the internal affairs of the household, while the duties of a man were to manage public affairs . Xenophon also stated that a man's job was to handle the affairs of his family .
 Women who “worked outside the home” were prostitutes, street vendors, or wet nurses . Those widowed widowed and who had not produced an heir were prostitutes . Those who were widowed were prostitutes and street vendors .
 Hyginus, a Roman historian and librarian to Emperor Augustus recounted Agnodike’s story . The story was translated into English by an English midwife in 1687 . Hyginuus was a librarian and historian of the Roman Empire .
 Hyginus's account does not inform us of Agnodike’s childhood, but she appears to have been a freeborn Athenian woman . Hyginuus’ account doesn’t tell us of her childhood .
 There, still disguised, she studied medicine under Herophilus, a famous physician . She was still disguised when she arrived in the country .
 We know from Greek literature that female relatives or neighbors, or nonprofessional midwives, usually assisted ordinary Greek women when they gave birth . The midwives were often used as midwives in Greek literature .
 Hippocrates founded a school of gynecology and obstetrics on the island of Cos, but women were not admitted as students . Women were not allowed to attend the school .
 A rival school of gynecology existed at Cnidos on the coast of Asia Minor, and this school actually encouraged women students .
 By the 4th century B.C.E.E., women doctors in Athens were accused of performing abortions . They were then barred from the profession .
 Many women died during childbirth, or of “private diseases,” in ancient Greece . Ancient Greek women died of ‘private diseases’ in childbirth .
 Agnodike’s patients, thinking that she was a man, expressed their reluctance to be treated by a man . A man would not be able to be seen by a woman in a hospital .
 Agnodike lifted her cloak and revealed her sex in an attempt to put her patients at ease .
 Agnodike was the most popular physician in Athens . Soon, established doctors found out that she was a woman, and established doctors discovered her true identity .
 Her patients stormed the courtroom and demanded the release of Agnodike . Her patients, according to Hyginus, stormed the court and demanded her release . Hygenus: "Her patients, who were in the courtroom, are demanding her release."
 Freeborn Athenian women could become physicians, although they were allowed only to treat women . After that, freeborn Athenians could become freeborn women .

 American physician Elizabeth Blackwell was the first woman to graduate from an American medical school . Blackwell graduated from the University of Medicine in New York City .
 By the time of her death in 1910, there were more than 7,000 female doctors in the United States . Blackwell’s initiative was largely thanks to her initiative . Blackwell died in 1910 .

 Elizabeth Blackwell was born on February 3, 1821, in Bristol, England, to a family of reformers . She was one of 12 children, one of a dozen children .
 Her father, Samuel Blackwell, a sugar refiner, and mother, Hannah Lane Blackwell, belonged to a loosely organized religious group known as Dissenters . Her father and mother were both members of the dissenters movement .
 The term Dissenter refers to members of a variety of Protestant denominations that refused to take the Anglican (or Church of England) communion, or to conform to the tenets of the church .
 Dissenters were subject to persecution after the restoration of the monarchy in 1660 . They faced harsh legislation against them after the passage of harsh legislation . They were subject of persecution in the wake of the 1660 and 1660 monarchy .
 In 1689, Parliament passed the Toleration Act, which permitted Dissenters to congregate and hold services in licensed meetinghouses . The Act was passed by Parliament in 1689 and was repealed in 1688 .

 Carson was devoted to creating an environmental awareness in the American popular mind . Carson blended her literary talents and her love of science in a career devoted to environmental awareness . Like Margaret MEAD, she blended her talents and science in her career .
 Silent Spring raised awareness of the environmental costs of capitalism and agribusiness . Her book Silent Spring condemned the use of the pesticide DDT, which she condemned .
 Rachel Carson effectively launched the modern environmental movement . The U.S. government banned most applications of the pesticide in the United States . Rachel Carson was a pioneer of the environmental movement.
 Carson credited her mother, Maria McLean Carson, with teaching her to love the natural world . Carson was born in Springdale, Pennsylvania, on May 27, 1907 .
 Her father, Robert Warden Carson, was a salesman and electrician who struggled to support his family . The Carsons lived somewhere between poverty and modest means .

 She supplemented her M.A. by working at prestigious Marine Biology Laboratory in Woods Hole, Massachusetts .
 In 1936, the United States Bureau of Fisheries hired her as an aquatic biologist . She was a member of the U.S. Fish and Wildlife Service . Her work was published by the National Institute of Fisheries .
 Between 1935 and 1937, Carson experienced the deaths of her father (who had been ill for much of his life) and her sister Marian, who left behind two children that Rachel began caring for, in addition to her mother . Carson died in 1937 .

 Silesian astronomer Maria Cunitz’s work in mathematics and astronomy advanced revolutionary changes in the way humans perceived the location of the Earth in relation to the Sun and other planets . Her work changed the way people perceived the Earth's position on the Sun .
 She wrote the treatise in Latin and vernacular German, ensuring the work’s accessibility to other scholars . The treatise was written in Latin .

 A heliocentric universe went against the teachings of the Catholic Church, which believed in an Earth-centered universe . The Catholic Church believed an Earth centered universe was not a reality .

 Marie Curie’s discovery of radioactivity as an intrinsic property of the atom changed forever our understanding of our physical universe, the nature of scientific research, and the status of women scientists . Curie's discovery changed forever .
 Marja Sklodowska was born in Warsaw, Poland, on November 7, 1867 . She was the fifth and youngest child of Bronsirwa Boguska, a musician and teacher, and a professor of math and physics .
 Ladislas raised his five children in Warsaw, Poland, during Russian occupation of the Polish capital . Ladisla raised his children in the Russian capital during the Russian occupation .

 Marja Sklodowska graduated from high school at the top of her class when she was only 15 . Marja was the top student in her class at 15 .
 She spent eight years working as a tutor and governess, earning money for both her own and her sister Bronia’s education . She spent the following eight years as a governess and tutor .
 In her spare time, she attended a ‘floating’ university in Warsaw, Poland . The loosely run, underground program conducted by Polish professors in defiance of the Russian-instituted program in place .

 Marja, who began using the French version of her name, Marie, graduated at the top of her class in 1893 . Marja began using her name Marja after she was named Marie .

 She then searched for a facility in which she could conduct experiments in physics . She then decided to conduct experiments at a facility she could do so .
 Her search led her to Pierre Curie, a physicist recognized for his work on crystallography and magnetism . Curie is a professor of physics at the Municipal School of Industrial Physics and Chemistry in Paris .
 Marie Curie embarked on her doctorate in physics in 1895 . The two married in 1895, and Curie went on to earn a doctorate degree in physics . Curie's husband died in 1945 .

 Marie Curie met Henri Becquerel, a scientist who studied X rays . Curie was at the Municipal School at the time of the discovery of the first X ray ray rays .
 Marie wanted to find out more about these mysterious rays and about uranium . Intrigued, she wanted to know more about the rays and uranium .
 The intensity of the rays was in direct proportion to the amount of uranium in her sample, she says . Other factors, such as combining it with other elements, or subjecting it to heat, cold, or light, didn't seem to affect the rays .
 She experimented with other elements, and found that another substance, thorium, was also “radioactive”—a term she coined—giving off similar rays to those found in uranium . She coined the term thorium .
 By studying pitchblende, Marie discovered that it was actually more radioactive than uranium alone . Pitchblende is a substance that contains more than uranium and is more radioactive . Marie discovered pitchblend, a uranic substance, is actually a radioactive substance .
 She discovered two new elements, polonium (which she named after her native land) and radium, in 1898 . She then discovered two more new elements in 1896 . Her discovery of the elements was the first of her kind .
 Marie and Pierre Curie, along with their partner Henri Becquerel, won the Nobel Prize in physics for their discovery of natural radioactivity in 1903 . Marie Curie and Henri Becqueerel were the first to discover radioactivity .
 Pierre began observing the effects of radiation on human beings . Pierre became fascinated with the radiation effect of radiation . Pierre was fascinated by the effect of the radiation .
 He noticed that when he applied radium to his skin, it caused a burn and then a wound . He noticed, for example, that when . applied . radium, he said, "when he applied . it caused, or not, a wound"
 Marie and Pierre Curie had another daughter, Eve, in 1904, but in 1906, tragedy struck; weakened by exposure to radiation, he was struck and killed by a moving vehicle on the streets of Paris . Marie Curie died in 1906 .
 Marie Curie assumed her husband’s position as professor of physics at the Sorbonne . Her appointment made her the first woman faculty member there . Pierre Curie died at the age of 50 .
 She continued experimenting with the new elements of polonium and radium . In addition to teaching courses, she continued experimenting .
 Her success in isolating them earned her a Nobel Prize in chemistry in 1911 . She was the first woman to isolate them and later won the Nobel Prize for chemistry .
 Curie was operating the Radium Institute, an experimental laboratory in Paris . Curie operated the laboratory at the time of the discovery of the radium in the 1950s .
 During World War I, Curie abandoned her experiments and went to work developing an X-ray machine that could be used at field hospitals to treat wounded soldiers who needed immediate attention . Curie created the machine to be used in field hospitals for immediate treatment .
 Radiology is a new branch of medicine in which X rays and radium were used to diagnose and treat disease . Marie Maloney, a journalist, invited her to raise funds for a hospital and laboratory dedicated to radiology .

 British biophysicist and chemist Rosalind Franklin is best known for her contributions to the study of DNA and plant viruses . Franklin was a pioneer in the field of plant viruses and DNA .
 The sugar-phosphate backbone of DNA lies on the outside of the DNA molecule . Her experiments with X-ray diffraction led to the discovery of the sugar phosphates in DNA . Her research led her to discover that the sugar-phenomenon of DNA is the backbone of
 Her studies also revealed the helical, or spiral, structure of the molecule . The molecule is also known as a spiral molecule .
 Franklin’s discoveries, which were incorporated into the work of her colleagues, went largely unacknowledged by them, and by scientific history, after her death at the age of 37 . Franklin's discoveries were incorporated .
 DNA is a self-replicating material present in nearly all living organisms, mostly in chromosomes . DNA is present in most of the world's most organisms, including humans .
 It functions as a carrier of genetic information that determines hereditary characteristics . Genetic information can be used to carry genetic information .
 Scientists knew that DNA stores all of the information needed to create a living organism . They did not yet know what the DNA molecule looked like, or exactly how it performed its role in determining hereditary characteristics .
 Rosalind Franklin enlightened the world of science through her discoveries . She was a pioneer of science in the 1930s and '60s .
 Franklin was born July 25, 1920, in England to an upperclass Jewish family . Franklin knew that she wanted to be a scientist when she was 15 years old .
 Rosalind Franklin’s aunt came to her rescue by insisting that her niece's intellect was too sharp to neglect . Franklin's aunt insisted that she was not neglecting her daughter .
 Franklin's mother sided with her aunt, and her father relented . Rosalind headed for Cambridge, where she took courses in physical chemistry at Newnham .
 When she finished her undergraduate degree, she went to work as a physical chemist at the British Coal Utilization Research Association . She now works at the University of Manchester .
 Her work helped launch the field of high-strength carbon fibers . Her work in this field helped to launch the world's first carbon fibers.
 She published five papers on the subject before she reached the age of 26 .
 In 1947, Franklin began experimenting with Xray diffraction in Paris, working with crystallographer Jacques Mering . Franklin was inspired by Mering's work in the 1950s and 1960s .
 In 1951, she accepted an offer to join a team of scientists studying cells at the King’s College Biophysical Laboratory in London .
 Franklin, trained as a chemist, made an excellent addition to the laboratory . Franklin trained as chemist, he was an excellent additions to the lab .
 By using the crystallography technique, Franklin was able to locate atoms in a crystal, which could then be mapped by looking at the image under an X-ray beam .
 Franklin brings her expertise with crystallography to the lab at King’s College . Franklin thus brought her expertise into the lab .
 She was treated as a lab assistant rather than as a colleague . Unfortunately, she was treated like a colleague rather than a colleague.
 Rosalind Franklin’s research helped other scientists to build accurate models of the DNA molecule . Franklin's work helped scientists build accurate DNA models .
 At King’s College lab, she built a high-resolution X-ray camera that produced the first usable pictures of DNA ever taken .
 DNA forms two kinds of fibers with different X-ray diffraction patterns . Depending on the water content, DNA forms different types of fibers . DNA forms with different patterns depending on water content .
 She discovered the sugar-phosphate backbone of DNA on the outside of the molecule and described its helical structure . Continuing her analysis, she also described the structure of DNA .
 Franklin’s findings were also publicized at a seminar, which Watson attended . Watson attended the seminar .
 Franklin began working at the Crystallography Laboratory at Birbeck College in 1953 . Disliked the atmosphere at King’s College (women scientists, for example, were not allowed to eat in the common room)
 She studied the changes in the shapes of heated carbon . Continuing her work she had pursued at the British Coal Utilization Research Association .
 This research became important in atomic technology and in the cooking industry . This research was important for atomic technology .
 She then turned her attention to plant viruses, helping to lay the foundation for structural virology . She then helped to develop the theory of plant viruses .
 Franklin worked in her lab up until a few weeks before her death from ovarian cancer on April 16,1958 . Franklin died of ovarian cancer in 1958 .
 The three have been hailed as making the single most important development in biology in the 20th century . The three are believed to have made the most important discoveries in biology history .

 Anna Freud was born in Austria but accomplished much of her work while living in England . Freud was the founder of child psychoanalysis .
 Anna Freud's father, Sigmund Freud, introduced her to his theories about the human mind . Anna Freud’s work with children influenced her work with her daughter .
 She believed that children developed psychologically through various stages, and that understanding those stages, which were discerned through observation, was essential in treating them .
 Anna Freud focused on the practical implications of the ego, or the conscious mind, and its development in children . Unlike Sigmund Freud, her work stressed the unconscious side of the human mind . Anna Freud's work focused on children's development .
 Some psychologists argue that Anna Freud’s work in what is now called ego psychology is the most influential and widely practiced today . Some psychologists today argue that this is the type of psychoanalysis that is most influential .
 Anna Freud was the youngest of Sigmund and Martha Freud’s six children . Born on December 3, 1895, in Vienna, Austria, she was born in 1895 .
 She finished her education at the Cottage Lyceum in Vienna in 1912 . She had no other formal schooling . She was born in Austria .
 In 1914, Anna traveled to England to improve her English, but World War I interrupted her plans . Anna traveled in 1914 to improve English but her plans were interrupted .
 Freud began teaching at her old school, the Cottage Lyceum, in Vienna . Freud returned to Vienna to teach at the school .
 Anna had been reading Sigmund Freud’s work since she was 15 years old . The Interpretation of Dreams by Freud was published in Freud's famous book, which he wrote about his interpretation of dreams .
 Anna had told her father that she, too, wanted to become a psychoanalysist . He insisted that all practitioners of psychoanalysis should themselves undergo analysis .
 Sigmund Freud created psychoanalysis as a technique to better understand the human mind . Freud created the term psychoanalysis in the 1930s . Freud used it to help people understand their inner workings .
 In the course of his work, he developed a psychodynamic theory of how the human mind works .
 The ego mediates between the id (instinctual desires) and the superego (suprego) All three struggle to dominate the mind . The ego, or conscious mind, mediates .
 Psychoanalysis is used by the analyst to uncover the patient’s repressed desires and other aspects of his or her unconscious mind . Free association and dream interpretation is used in the analysis of the patient's dreams .
 Freud's theories of infantile sexuality shaped Anna Freud’s work with children . Anna Freud was a child psychiatrist who studied Freud's work in the Freudian formative years .
 According to Sigmund Freud, humans are sexual beings from the time they are born, not when they reach adolescence . According to Freud, sexual beings are sexual from the start of the day .
 Freud believed that repression of infantile sexuality causes neuroses in adults . Freud believed infantile sexual repression caused the neuroses of adults .
 Children between the ages of three and five develop an unconscious sexual desire for the parent of the opposite sex . Children also develop an accompanying fear of the same-sex parent’s jealousy, psychologist says .
 Anna Freud began her career in psychoanalysis in 1922, when she presented her paper, “Beating Fantasies and Daydreams,” to the Vienna Psychoanalytical Society . Freud was a pioneer of psychoanalysis .
 Her first book, Introduction to the Technique of Child Analysis, resulted from her practice and seminars . She has published more than 1,000 books since her seminars .

 Jane Goodall has devoted her life to the study and protection of chimpanzees . Goodall is a British primatologist and conservationist .
 Her research on the species is the longest continuous study of animals in their wild habitat . Her research has been conducted for more than 30 years .
 Her studies reveal much about this humanlike species and, therefore, much about humanity, she says .
 Dwindling habitat has caused a reduction in the population of chimpanzees in the wild . Jane Goodall’s mission is to see that they will have a livable habitat for centuries to come .
 Animals and their habitat have been a lifelong interest of Goodall’s, ever since her childhood near Bournemouth, England, where the family moved from London soon after Jane was born on April 3, 1934 .
 One day, when she was five years old, she gave her family quite a scare . She gave them a scare, but it wasn't a bad thing .
