 Goodall started her research on this particular group of chimpanzees . Soon, however, they began to interact with her, and Goodall began her research .
 In it, Goodall described a mostly peaceful chimpanzee society, spending most of their time gathering food and interacting with each other .

 Her chimpanzee research formed the basis of her dissertation, and she completed the degree in 1965 .

 Kenyan biologist and environmentalist Wangari Muta Maathai has spent her career demonstrating the connection between a healthy, tree-growing environment and human health and well-being .
 Maathai left the university to found the Green Belt Movement, a grassroots organization devoted to restoring Kenya’s environment through the planting of trees . After a successful academic career, he found the organization after leaving the university .
 Kenya lies between Ethiopia and Tanzania and is partially bordered by the Indian Ocean to the east . Kenya lies in the middle of the world's most populous region .
 Most of Kenya consists of a broad, arid plateau, with high mountains in the west . Most of the country is largely arid and arid, with mountains in its west .

 Around 97 percent of Kenya’s forests had been cut down, either to clear land for cash crops or to provide wood for cooking fires . The forests were cut down to clear cash crops and provide wood .
 Tourism accounts for much of the service industry, which is about 50 percent of Kenya’s economy . Tourism is a major source of growth in Kenya's economy .

 Kenya has one of the fastest population growth rates in the world, and poverty is widespread . However, Kenya also has a fast population growth rate, which is also widespread . Poverty is widespread in Kenya, but the country has a history of poverty .
 Deforestation, as Maathai discovered, is directly linked to impoverishment . Deforestation has been linked to poverty, says Maatai .
 Kenya traditionally has been self-sufficient in food production . But drought has hindered its ability to keep its people adequately fed . The drought has been exacerbated by deforestation .
 In traditional Kenyan culture, women are the farmers and responsible for feeding their families . Women are responsible for the survival of their families in traditional Kenya culture .
 Maathai found that, as forests became thinner and thinner, women had to spend more and more time searching for firewood with which to cook . The former president of Kenya's government found that forests are thinning and thinning .
 To reduce the time spent building and tending fires and cooking, mothers began feeding their children lownutrient foods that did not require cooking, such as cassava .
 In addition to requiring more labor, cutting down trees also contributes to poverty . Cutting down trees reduces fertile topsoil by reducing fertile top soil .
 When trees are removed from the land, root systems that retain moisture in the soil die and leave the topsoil vulnerable to wind and water . Wind and water carry the valuable soil into river systems .
 After her campaign ended, Maathai became active in the National Council of Women . She would serve as its chair from 1981 to 1987 . She was the chair of the council .
 Through the NCW, she introduced the idea of women farmers planting trees around their land . The idea was introduced to women farmers .
 To demonstrate her initiative on World Environmental Day, June 5, 1977, she planted seven trees in a public park in Nairobi, Kenya .
 In 1986, the Green Belt Movement established a Pan African Green Belt Network . The network led to the adoption of tree-planting programs in Tanzania, Uganda, Malawi, Ethiopia, Ethiopia and Zimbabwe .
 The long-range goal of the Kenyan Green Belt Movement is to establish sustainable agriculture . Kenya's long-term goal is to set up sustainable agriculture in the country .
 Sustainable agriculture is the growing of food in a way that preserves the environment and allows farmers to continue to grow food crops . Sustainable agriculture can be seen as a way to preserve the environment for farmers .
 Food security is a means of achieving food security, or the ability of farmers to feed themselves, their families, and local populations . It is a way to achieve food security for farmers .
 Sustainable agriculture would require a reduction in the number of trees cleared to produce cash crops in Kenya . It would require the planting of trees to ensure fertile soil and successful food crops .

 Alchemy was a precursor to the modern science of chemistry . The practice of turning base metals such as lead and mercury into precious metals silver and gold .
 Alchemists supposedly performed this transmutation of base metals into precious metals by using the philosopher’s stone, a hypothetical substance that was also believed to give eternal life . The philosopher's stone is believed to be used by alchemists to transmutation base metals .
 Alchemists were the first to combine theory with scientific experimentation . Alchemy was a mixture of chemistry, astrology, occultism, and magic .
 Egyptian alchemy may have originated in ancient Mesopotamia where women alchemists made perfume and other cosmetics . Egyptian alchemist may have started in Mesopotamian culture .
 According to Dee, the transmutation of base metals to gold was a metaphor for the transformation of man to god . Dee: The transmutation was a symbol for the . transformation of . man to . god .
 Many alchemists performed their experiments in secret and used allegorical language to describe them, for fear of persecution . Alchemists often used the language of their experiments to protect themselves .
 As physics and chemistry developed in the 17th and 18th centuries, alchemists fell into disrepute . Alchemists were accused of being bad for their work .
 Alexandria was a center of learning throughout the Roman Empire . Liberal ideas helped loosen the strict patriarchal attitudes toward women held by many Jewish and Greek people at the time .
 Maria the Jewess was able to explore the mysteries of alchemy, in Alexandria . The Greek physician AGNODIKE studied medicine in Alexandria, Egypt, and Maria studied alchemy in the same place .
 Maria the Jewess wrote many treatises on her experiments and inventions, but little of her work survives today . Little of her works survive today .
 Fragments of her Maria Practica exist today in collections of ancient alchemy . Fragments are still found in alchemy collections .
 Maria wrote under the name Miriam the Prophetess, sister of Moses, causing some to mistakenly think that Miriam was an alchemist .
 The Maria Practica combined the theoretical aspects of alchemy with practical descriptions of laboratory devices and processes . The Mariapractica combined theoretical and practical aspects of the alchemy theory with descriptions of lab procedures .
 The best-known device invented by Maria was the double boiler . It has been an essential part of laboratories, and kitchens, for the past two thousand years .
 The double boiler, or bain-marie, consists of two containers, one of which nests on top of the other . The French still call it a bain marie, as the French do .
 The water slowly heats the material inside the upper container . It allows the chemist to heat a substance slowly, or to maintain it at a constant temperature .
 Maria’s description of the tribikos, or threearmed still, is the oldest known description of this useful device . Maria's description is the most accurate description of a device .
 A still is used in the process of distillation, in which a liquid mixture is heated in a vessel until part of the liquid begins to evaporate into a gas . The still is a still used in distillation .
 Maria recommended using a paste made of flour and water for keeping the joints of the tribikos sealed . Maria recommends using a mixture of water and flour to seal the joints .
 Maria invented the kerotakis, consisting of a cylinder with a round cover to be set over a flame . For the purpose of vaporizing arsenic, mercury, and sulfur on metals, she invented the Kerotakis . Maria invented a cylinder to vaporize arsenic and mercury .
 Near the top of the cylinder, suspended from the cover, was a plate containing a copper-lead alloy to be treated . The plate containing the alloy was attached to the cylinder and was used to treat it .
 As the substance below boiled, the vapor condensed at the top of the cylinder and the liquid flowed back down in a continuous cycle . The liquid flowed down the cylinder as the substance boiled .
 The kerotakis was also used for extracting plant oils, such as attar of roses, such a plant oil .
 Marias work marks the end of alchemy as practiced in the Roman Empire . Emperor Diocletian began persecuting Alexandrian alchemists and burning their texts .
 Arabs rescued the science and transported it to Europe during the Middle Ages . The Arabs rescued it from the region and transported the science to Europe .
 Barbara McClintock is a cool, detached scientist with a biting wit and a warm heart . She discovered that genes are dynamic systems that interact with their environment . She says genes are a dynamic system that interacts with the environment .
 McClintock argued that genes could move and could control other genes . This suggests that living things control their own evolution, he said .
 In 1983, after other scientists finally corroborated and accepted her work, she won a Nobel Prize . Thirty-two years later, she became the first woman to win an unshared Nobel in physiology .
 When she asked her father, a physician for Standard Oil Company, if she could go to college, he gave his assent . Her father was a physician who worked at Standard Oil .
 Her mother, on the other hand, balked at the idea . She worried that her daughter would become even more isolated from the rest of society .
 Barbara was afraid that Barbara might become a college professor . Barbara's mother feared that Barbara would become a professor . She was afraid Barbara might be a professor.
 By the time she graduated in 1923, she had decided upon a career in genetics . She had decided to study genetics .
 Geneticists have already discovered that microscopic bodies called chromosomes carry information that determines inherited traits . Geneticists had already found out that genetic information can be passed on to others .
 Each cell contains pairs of chromosomes; each of the pairs is only slightly different from the others . The chromosomes are only slightly similar to each other in the cells .
 By studying Indian corn, a unique, multicolored variety, McClintock found that the pattern of kernels on each ear of corn is inherited .
 She identified 10 different pairs of chromosomes that determine the different colors of kernels .
 The next step was to link changes in chromosomes to changes in the living organism, scientists say . The study was published in the prestigious journal Nature Nature .
 McClintock and her graduate student, Harriet Creighton, performed one of the truly great experiments in modern biology . After completing her Ph.D. in 1927, McClintocks and Creighton performed what was called one of their great experiments .
 McClintock and Creighton beat the German scientist who made a similar finding a few weeks later .
 McClintock wanted to find out more about damaged genomes, or complete sets of chromosomes . He wanted to study damaged genomes or complete chromosomes .
 Another Missouri professor, Lewis Stadler, had shown the damaging effects of X rays on corn .
 McClintock identified ring chromosomes that she realized had been broken by radiation . She said she realized ring chromosomes were broken .
 She found that the broken ends of the chromosomes sometimes fused onto other broken ends, forming a ring . She also found that broken ends sometimes fused into each other .
 McClintock postulated that chromosome tips had a special structure that she called telomere . She believed that the Telomere maintains chromosomal stability . McClintocks postulated the structure maintains the stability of chromosomes .
 Telomere geneticists are applying their research to diseases such as cancer and to the aging process . Today, telomere genetics is applied to diseases like cancer and aging processes .
 McClintock presented her discovery that mutable genes appeared to be transferred from cell to cell during development of the corn kernel . Then came the disastrous reception at Cold Spring Harbor’s Symposium in 1951 .
 Biographer Nathaniel Comfort explains the audience’s reaction in part by her choice of research material . The audience reacted to the book by reacting to the author's research material, Comfort says .
 By the 1940s, Indian corn had simply gone out of fashion in the scientific community . Indian corn went out of science in 1940s .
 By 1951, biologists were becoming ever more specialized, and many of the virologists in the audience did not have the necessary background to completely understand McClintock’s discussion of genetic transposition .
 She inadvertently stepped on toes when she proclaimed the mutability of genes, she said . Furthermore, she also said that genes can be mutable .
 Geneticists had made careers out of mapping genes, pinpointing their exact location on chromosomes . Most geneticists made careers in mapping genes into chromosomes .
 It was not until the late 1970s that other geneticists began to duplicate McClintock’s findings . Other geneticists started to duplicate his findings .
 Researchers began finding transposable genes in other organisms, such as fruit flies and humans . Researchers also found genes in fruit flies, humans .
 McClintock’s notion that some genes could control others, and that therefore genes control their own evolution, was also corroborated by the study . The study was published in the prestigious journal Nature Nature .
 The National Academy of Sciences awarded her the Kimber Genetics Award in 1967; three years later she won the National Medal of Science . 13 years later, 13 years after winning the Nobel Prize, she was awarded the title again . The Nobel Prize was awarded to her by the Academy of Science in
 Like Simone de BEAUVOIR, Margaret Mead called into question the notion that biological differences between men and women determine their behavior .
 She based her understanding on her study of the New Guinea people among whom she observed men and women engaged in what most Europeans and Americans would consider feminine behavior .
 She concluded that the concepts of femininity and masculinity must be culture-specific . The concepts of masculinity and femininity must be cultural-specific, she said .
 Mead viewed cross-cultural knowledge of the world as one of the most important challenges facing modern societies . Mead viewed colonial systems breaking down under the pressures of two world wars .
 Mead was the author of several anthropological studies accessible even to nonacademic audiences . Mead lectured around the world and wrote a column for the popular women’s magazine Redbook .

 Ramphele was born on December 28, 1947, in the Bochum district of the northern Transvaal, near Pietersburg, South Africa . He was born in 1947, and died in 2007 .

 Her parents, Pitsi Eliphaz Ramphele, were both primary schoolteachers, positions of relatively high status at the time . Her parents were both high-status primary school teachers .
 Ramphele’s family comes from the Bapedi, or North Sotho people of the northern Transvaal . He comes from a family of the Bapingi people of northern Sothotho .
 Ramphele's parents named her after her maternal grandmother’s praise name, Mamphela . She was named after her mother's mother's praise name .
 Traditionally, praise names link people with their clan; naming babies after a relative is the means by which the North Sotho people incorporate newborns into the extended family . The North African people name babies after their relatives .
 The European names are a legacy of the European missionaries who came to South Africa and gave the indigenous people baptized Christian names . The missionaries were unwilling to learn the African names, Ramphele says .
 For convenience’s sake, many South Africans have kept their European names . For convenience, many keep European names for convenience .

 Kathe Kollwitz was one of the best-known artists of the early 20th century . She produced hundreds of etchings, lithographs, and woodcuts during her career .
 The content of her work was inspired by her anticapitalist and feminist political philosophy . Her work is based on her anticapsitalism and feminism .
 Her work epitomized her sympathy with the working classes and with the tragedies of the age in which she lived . Her work was her sympathy for the working class and the tragedies she lived in .
 Kollwitz’s work reflects German expressionism, a style of art begun around 1905, in which the artist sought to depict bold and sometimes harsh emotions in her work .
 Most of her work was done on flat surfaces, but she also sculpted . Although most of her sculpted, she also used to sculpt .

 Lady Li gazed at the rice-papered window of her study, saw the sensuous play of bamboo branch and leaf shadows against the paper, and traced its outline .

 In premodern China, calligraphy and painting were considered complementary arts because both used the same materials and methods . Calligraphy was considered complementary to painting because it used same materials .
 Paintings considered aesthetically pleasing when the forms and figures were as lovely as the inscription accompanying the work . Paintings were considered aesthetic pleasing when they were as pretty as the inscriptions accompanying them .

 The depression-era photography of Dorothea Lange created an indelible imprint on the conscience of American society . Lange's depression era photography of Lange left a lasting imprint on American conscience .
 Her most widely regarded work is the photographs she made of migrant farmworkers during the Great Depression . Her work brought the plight of an impoverished agricultural labor force to the forefront of Americans’ consciousness .
 Photography was invented in the early part of the 19th century but was not considered an art in the late 19th and early 20th centuries . Photography was not an art until the late 20th century when it was considered as an art .
 Most photographers made their living taking portraits of individuals and families . Most photographers make their living photographing individuals and family .
 During the American Civil War, the documentary photographs of battlefields were used to spread news about the events of the war . Mathew Brady and his workers captured the aftermath of major battles in the Civil War .
 Unlike the fine arts of painting and sculpting, no established schools of photography existed to disseminate technical information about how to take pictures . Anyone who could afford a camera could become a photographer .
 Because there were no restrictions, women photographers were recognized soon after the new medium was born .

 The work that Lange did during the Great Depression assured her a place in the history of photography . Lange was a photographer during the Depression in the 1930s .

 A decade of rash speculation in the stock market, overproduction and underconsumption, drought conditions in the Great Plains, too much buying on credit, and poor economic conditions in Europe, combined to dash hopes of such optimists .

 Roosevelt established several government-sponsored programs to reduce unemployment, get hungry people off the streets, and reestablish confidence in the government’s ability to serve the American people . Roosevelt established programs to help reduce unemployment and get people out of poverty .

 The Vietnam Veterans’ Memorial sits in a flat park setting in the Washington, D.C., Mall . It sits across the Lincoln and Washington memorials .
 On the street side, the slabs protrude only slightly above ground, while on the inside the walls rise above the earth to form a shallow bowl . On the inside of the walls, the walls are seen to be rising above the ground .
 Inscribed in the inside of the granite walls are the 58,000 names of men and women who died, or are still missing in action, during the war . Inscription includes the names of those who died or are missing in service .
 Lin wanted the names to read like a narrative history of the war . The names are listed in the order that their deaths occurred, rather than alphabetically . Lin wanted to make the names read like an historical narrative .
 Visitors seem to instinctively raise their hands to touch the names of the soldiers, perhaps their relatives or friends, and their hands can be seen in the reflection of the walls . Visitors can also see their hands touching the soldiers' names .
 Others seem to touch names randomly, as though they carry the burden of loss of the entire nation on their shoulders . Others seem like to carry the weight of the loss of a nation on them .

 Louise knew she wanted to be an artist when she was nine years old . By the time she turned nine she knew she was going to be a professional artist .
 In 1920, Louise Berliawsky married Charles Nevelson, who owned and operated a cargo shipping business . The couple was married in 1920 .
 In 1931, separated from her husband, Nevelson went to work under the artist Hans Hofman in Munich, Germany . Her husband died in 1931 .
 She had been interested in art from around the world and began collecting American Indian, South and Central American native art, and African art .
 She continued to paint through the 1940s, although she never really found her niche in this particular medium .
 It was only when she began working with wood that she found her artistic identity, she said . She said: 'I found my artistic identity when I started working in wood'
 She began by nailing pieces of wood together and painting the resulting sculpture a uniform color . The sculpture was created by combining wood pieces and painting them together .
 By the late 1950s, she had created a reputation based on her ability to form a sculpted environment standing more than eight feet tall and stretching 11 feet wide . She had a reputation for being able to stand more than 8 feet tall .
 Her environments were assemblies of objects of almost every possible shape into one overarching shape . Her environments included objects of all shapes and sizes of objects .
 Art critic Cindy Nemser uses the word tableaux, or vivid representations, to describe the stage-like presence of the environments . Nemser: Tableaux are vivid representations of environments .
 The environments demonstrate a degree of unity that is remarkable since they are made up of so many different shapes . The environments are remarkable because of their unique shapes and their unity .
 Nevelson combined pieces of wood in arch shapes with straight wood pieces . The artist created the arch-shaped wood pieces in the shape of arch shapes . The arch shapes were created by combining wood and straight pieces .

 Georgia O'Keeffe developed an original style of both simplicity and towering magnitude in her paintings of the natural world . O’KEEFFE, Georgia, was an American artist of the day .
 Some critics have labeled O’Keeffe’s work as abstract and precisionist . Some critics say her work is abstract .
 Abstract art in sculpting and painting began in Europe and North America in the 1910s . Abstract art began in the 1900s in North America .
 The other approach, called nonobjective, or pure art, has no connection or reference to any real object at all . "Pure art" is "nonobjective"
 Impressionism reduced the importance of the object by looking instead to the effects of light on the subject . The result was less a painting of an object and more a painting of light .
 Wassily Kandinsky, Marcel Duchamp and Pablo Picasso are among the bestknown abstract artists . Kandinsky is one of the best known abstract artists in the world .
 Precisionists, such as Charles Sheeler, employed the philosophy of mechanism to their art . Precisionists employed a philosophy of the art to their work . Precisionist Charles Sheerer employed the theory of mechanism .
 Mechanism is a system of adapted parts working together, as in a machine . Mechanism means adapted parts of a machine are working together . Mechanisms are a system that works together, like a machine, to work together .
 Mechanists hold that all natural phenomena have a mechanical explanation . Artists seek to portray the mechanical aspects of the objects they paint .
 Precisionists’ works included very precise lines (as opposed to the blurred lines of the impressionists) They frequently used photographs as the basis of their paintings .
 O’Keeffe’s work, generally speaking, cannot be called purely abstract, because her paintings do reflect—even if exaggerated—their natural forms . Her paintings reflect their natural forms, even if exaggerated, they reflect them .
 The fluidity of her flower paintings would gainsay any connection she might have with the precisionists . Her fluidity would gainay her connection with the preciseists .
 O'Keeffe was born on a dairy farm near Sun Prairie, Wisconsin, on November 15, 1887 . Her early interest in music was soon replaced by her resolve, at age 10, to become an artist .
 She won a class prize from William Merritt Chase at the Art Students League for her still life . She soon lost interest in imitating European styles .
 In 1912, Alon Bemont, a prodigy of Arthur Wesley Dow, tutored her . He also rejected academic realism . In 1914, she was the subject of a Pulitzer Prize-winning novel .
 Dow believed nature’s forms should be used to express human emotions, not merely serve as models to be reproduced in a painting . Dow believed that nature's forms should not be used as models but as models for artworks .
 Between 1912 and 1916, O’Keeffe taught art in Amarillo, Texas, where she discovered a landscape that inspired her . The landscape was the inspiration for her work .
 She began drawing abstract shapes that reflected both the open north Texas plains and her imagination .
 She sent a few paintings to an art school friend, Anita Pollwitz, with the proviso that Pollwitz was not to share them with anyone else . She sent the paintings to a friend with the caveat that they were not to be shared with others .
 Pollwitz remembered that O’Keeffe had once told her that she would rather have photographer Alfred Stieglitz admire her work than anyone else . Pollwitz said she would have preferred to have her work admired more by Stiegitz than any other photographer .
 Georgia O’Keeffe’s talent lies in her ability to look deeply at natural objects and express them in her own style .
 One of her most famous pieces, Black Iris, features a single bloom spread across a canvas . The artist's most famous piece is a painting of a single flower .
 The black-gray lower section of the bloom forms a solid base on which the bloom rests . It is the largest bloom of its kind in the world .
 O’Keeffe redeemed the flower from its excessive use in the commercial art of the early 20th century to once again become the subject of serious artists .
 To critics’ astonishment, she began to combine flowers with bones . She then began combining flowers and bones to create a mosaic of flowers .
 Stieglitz moved permanently to Abiquiu, New Mexico, when she died in 1946 . She had been spending summers in New Mexico since 1929, but moved permanently .
 There, she would stumble upon dried-out bones in the desert that inspired a series of desert scenes . The bones were found by the author of the book, The Desert Desert .
 Red Hills and Bones juxtaposes bleached animal bones with rolling hills backdrop . Stieglitz painted before his death, painted before he died, in a series of paintings .
 Both the bones and the hilly background stretch out the length of the canvas . The bones and a hilly backdrop stretch out of the frame .
 The bones have gentle curves, reflected in the violet, red, and yellow hills behind . The bones are gentle curves and reflect the landscape .
 The viewer gets caught up in a luxurious, undulating, sensuous experience of desert colors and landscape . The viewer is captured in the desert desert .
 The victim of a degenerative eye disease at the age of 84, her central vision deteriorated, leaving only her peripheral vision intact . She was the victim of an eye disease that left her with only a small part of her vision .
 O’Keeffe was elected to the National Institute of Arts and Letters in 1949, the American Academy of Arts & Letters in 1963, and was awarded a Gold Medal for Painting in 1970 .
 Potter began drawing and writing stories as a way to counteract the children-should-be-seen-and-not-heard ethos in which she was raised . Potter: "I'm not afraid to be afraid. I'm scared to be scared," she says .
 Potter drew animals in their natural surroundings without the exaggerated or human-like features often seen in children's books about animals .
 She preferred to pair exact, detailed illustrations of small creatures with the intricate plots of her stories . Her stories were meant to evoke children’s curiosity about the world around them, as well as entertain .
 Potter spent the last few decades of her life as busy with her sheep farm as with the more than 30 children's books she wrote and illustrated . Potter spent most of her career as a sheep farmer .
 Her parents both received large inheritances from the cotton trade . Potter’s education was conducted by nannies and tutors in her third-floor rooms . Potter ate and slept separately from her parents .
 Beatrix and Bertram roamed among the Lake District during family vacations . The Potter children’s only extensive time free from the confines of their home was during family vacation . Beatrix, Bertram, and Beatrix roamed the hills gathering plants, fossils, and rocks .
 Occasionally, the two would skin and dissect dead animals so they could learn more about anatomy . The pair would skin dead animals and dissect them to learn anatomy .
 Beatrix Potter lost the companionship of her brother when he was sent away to boarding school . Beatrix started writing in a journal that she kept for over a decade, written in a code only she understood .
 She received an Art Students’ Certificate from the Science and Art Department of the Committee of Council on Education for her ability to draw freehand .
 Many of Potter’s early animal drawings were based upon samples she saw at the Kensington Museum of Natural History . Potter's first animal drawing was based on samples she found at the museum .
 Later, she took a 12-lesson course in oil painting but, she regretfully noted, she never had the opportunity to learn and draw human anatomy .
 She did, however, collect specimens of mold spores and lichens . She painted them in minute detail .
 Potter began her professional career as an illustrator by sending a sample of her work to a greeting card company in Germany . Potter has been a professional illustrator since 2000 .
 The company accepted her offerings and then, in 1893, asked her to illustrate a book of children’s verses written by Frederic E Weatherly called A Happy Pair . In 1893, she was asked to illustrate the book by the company .
 The book contained drawings of rabbits, piglets, and other farm animals . It was published in 1996 .
 When Potter's former governess asked her to write a letter to her ill son during his bout with scarlet fever, she gladly obliged . Potter’s ex-governess wrote the letter during his illness .
 She began the letter by explaining that she did not really know what to write to him, so she would tell him a story about four little rabbits named Flopsy, Mopsy, Cottontail, and Peter .
 She submitted a reworked and expanded version of the story accompanied with illustrations to six publishers . Later, she submitted an expanded version to six different publishers .
 The author resubmitted her work to the editor who had sent her the most courteous rejection letter . By 1902, the book had been published, and by 1902, it was published .
 The Tale of Peter Rabbit had sold so quickly in England that a pirated version of it had appeared in the United States . Later, her works were translated into more than 15 languages . Her works have been translated into over 15 languages.
 A number of features endeared Potter’s books to children and their parents alike . Harry Potter's books have been published in more than 40 years .
 Maria MONTESSORI, who designed small desks for pintsized students, has designed desks for students .
 Potter thought that children’s books should be small and easy for small hands and fingers just learning to manipulate pages to hold . Potter's book is designed to be easy to hold for children's hands .
 The illustrations accompanying the stories showed animals in their own environments, albeit using human tools and wearing human clothes . The illustrations were accompanied by illustrations of animals in the human world .
 People were never allowed to wrest the spotlight from animals, says A. Milne . Milne’s Christopher Robin in his Winnie the Pooh stories, but people never wrested the spotlight .
 She used the money she earned to buy a farm in the Lake District called Hill Top Farm . She used it to help raise money to buy the farm .
 The solicitor who drew up the contract for Potter, William Heelis, became her husband in 1913 . Harry Potter was born in 1913 and died at the age of 92 .
 Potter and Heelis acquired more property in the Lake District in an attempt to save the region’s rural culture . The company has acquired more than 1,000 acres of land .
 Potter continued to write and illustrate her books, but failing eyesight, and her passion for farming, slowed her productivity later in her life . Potter died at the age of 92 at the end of her career .
 She always kept rabbits at her farm, telling visiting children, with a twinkle in her eye, that they were the descendants of Peter Rabbit . She always told visiting children she was Peter Rabbit's descendant .
 When Louis XVI and his queen were guillotined, Tussaud ‘borrowed’ their decapitated heads and made wax models of them . Later displaying them in her famous wax museum .
 Madame Tussaud emigrated to England after the French Revolution . She established a permanent exhibit of her worldrenowned wax models in her museum .
 Madame Tussaud’s father, a German soldier, died before her birth on December 1, 1761 in Strasbourg, France .
 Tussaud’s mother raised her in Bern, Switzerland, in the home of her brother, Dr. Dr. J. Tussau . Tussua was born in Switzerland and raised in Switzerland .
 Philippe Curtius left Bern for the art capital of the world, Paris, in 1770, with his sister and niece in tow . Curtius was a wax worker himself .
 He opened a wax museum in the Palais Royal and a second museum in 1783 . The first museum opened in the 17th century in Paris .
 Tussaud learned the art of wax modeling from her uncle, and at the age of 17 she had already become quite skilled .
 Waxworks, or life-size displays of wax figures, derive from an ancient custom of creating effigies of dead celebrities . Waxworks were created by ancient Egyptians in ancient times to create effigy of celebrities .
 Fourteenth-century English and French courtiers revived the practice, which continued until the 18th century . The practice was revived by the French and English courtiers .
 Various materials, such as grease, oil, and animal fat, were added to the wax to enhance its elasticity . Various materials such as resin increased its hardness .
 A model is built up by adding small bits of wax onto an armature, or framework, then worked with a spatula . A model can be built up using small pieces of wax then added to the armature .
 Casting, the second method, is done by first assembling a small mock-up of the sculpture in clay, and then creating a plaster cast of the desired shape . Casting is then made using plaster of the shape .
 When the wax cools and hardens, the cast is removed and finishing touches made with a spatula . The cast is then removed and the finishing touches are made with the spatula.
 From 1780 until the first rumblings of the French Revolution, Tussaud tutored Louis XVI’s sister Elizabeth in art . Louis XVI's sister Elizabeth was tutored in art from 1780 .
 The piece is now on display at Madame Tussaud's in London . It consists of a room decorated in rococo style, a type of art and interior design .
 The queen, Marie Antoinette, stands next to her son, Louis Charles, who stands in between his mother and father . Louis Charles is the son of the queen and the queen of France .
 All four members of the royal family appear to be listening to a recitation . The recitation is part of a series of recitations by the Queen .
 In October 1789, the king was forced to vacate his palace at Versailles and live in Paris instead . The king had been forced to move to Paris in 1789 . The French king died in 1791 .
 Madame Tussaud made casts from the severed heads of her friends . She poured wax into the casts to make her wax models .
 The wax models of the ‘heads of state’ were then displayed at Curtius’s museum . Curtius's wax models are now displayed at the museum .
 Madame Tussaud inherited both of Philippe Curtius' museums after his death in 1794 . She inherited both museums from Curtius .
 Tussaud spent some time in prison in 1794 . Due to her former liaison with the royal family, she spent time in jail .
 Her friendship with Josephine de Beauharnais, Napoleon I’s wife, benefited her later, when Napoleon I seized power in France in 1799 . Tussaud's alliance with the couple improved her waxworks business, and her friendship with Napoleon I's wife .
 The exhibit includes one of the knives used in the guillotines used to carry out the bloody deeds . She added to the exhibit by adding famous British subjects .
 Her French Revolution exhibit became known as the “Chamber of Horrors,” a phrase coined by a reporter for the English magazine Punch in 1845 . The phrase is still known today .
 Following Napoleon’s attack on Russia in 1812 and his defeat at Waterloo in 1815, Tussaud cast a model of Napoleon's carriage in her museum .
 She finally found a permanent home for her models in Baker Street, London . She continued to work until her death on April 16, 1850 .
 The severed heads of both the perpetrators and victims hung garishly from the same chamber walls in her best-known piece, “Chamber of Horrors,” may have enhanced the perception of the French Revolution as one of the most diabolical .
 Madame Tussaud's art brought the French Revolution into a public venue for inspection, ridicule, and, at the very least, conversation . Like today’s political cartoonists, she brought the Revolution into public space .

 Wertmuller has a reputation for being difficult on the set, for terrorizing her cast into submission, and for abruptly cutting parts of scripts .
 Her principal aim in making films, as she has said, has been to generate excitement and provoke thought . She said: "Her principal aim is to generate exciting and provoking thought"
 Susan B Anthony and Elizabeth Cady Stanton worked together for woman suffrage, and other liberal causes, nearly all their adult lives . They were friends and colleagues for over half a century .
 Both died before passage of the Nineteenth Amendment to the U.S. Constitution in 1920, guaranteeing the right to vote .
 Both worked tirelessly for women's rights, with Anthony’s contribution more in the area of the federal suffrage amendment . Stanton's work encompassed wider social changes, especially in the realm of religion . Anthony and Stanton were both prominent figures in the field of social change .
 Both women believed that if women’s sense of morality were added to American electoral politics, society would be greatly improved . Mirroring the broader women's rights movement in the late 19th century, both women highlighted differences from men .
 The abolitionist movement fought inequality in American society through the abolitionists . Women's rights activists fought for women's rights in America .
 Anthony was born in Adams, Massachusetts, on February 15, 1820, to Daniel Anthony and Lucy Read . He grew up in a Quaker farming family that worked to end slavery .
 Anthony first tasted sexual discrimination when she found that her wages were far less than what her male colleagues received . Anthony found that she was being discriminated against for being a teacher . Anthony says she was discriminated against because she was paid less than those of her colleagues .
 Anthony never married or had children; as a single woman, she had greater mobility and flexibility than her married colleagues . Anthony was essential asset to the women’s rights cause .
 The Scottish Presbyterianism of her conservative family influenced her less than her cousin Gerrit Smith's radical abolitionism . The abolitionist was born in Edinburgh, Scotland .
 Through Smith, she met the famous abolition orator Henry Brewster Stanton . The abolitionist met Stanton through Smith .
 Officials refused to seat Elizabeth Cady Stanton because she was female . Shortly after, they attended the World’s Anti-Slavery Convention in London .
 They blamed men for usurping religious power and for denying women their individual identities and rights within marriage . Further, they said men were responsible for usurging religious power .
 Stanton argued for a broad range of social changes, including higher education for women, the wearing of trousers, and short hair . Stanton wrote articles on women's rights in Amelia BLOOMER’s Lily and Paulina Wright Davis's Una . After the convention, Stanton wrote
 Elizabeth Cady Stanton was, with Susan B Anthony, the most important American women’s rights leader of the 19th century . Stanton was the most prominent leader of women's rights in America .
 Susan B Anthony, too, had shirked her corset and donned bloomers when she met Elizabeth Cady Stanton at a meeting in 1851 .
 In 1854, the collaborators focused on specific laws that discriminated against women, including custody rights and property rights . The collaborators were able to create a law that allowed women to have custody rights .
 Anthony's job was to circulate pamphlets, petitions, and political tracts . Stanton crafted the arguments, while Anthony circulated pamphlets and petitions .
 Both agreed that the fastest way to secure equality for women in American society lay in the legal realm . Women’s rights, as wives and mothers, were not being represented by men .
 Women, in other words, needed to represent themselves because they were different from men . Women needed to do so because of how different they were from men, she said .
 Anthony and Stanton lobbied Congress in favor of the Thirteenth Amendment which abolished slavery . Stanton and Anthony lobbied Congress to pass the amendment .
 When abolitionists began garnering support for the Fourteenth and Fifteenth Amendments, the two women hoped to pass woman suffrage on the coattails of voting rights for blacks .
 The leadership within the abolitionist movement claimed that the time was not ripe for woman suffrage . The leadership of the abolitionists claimed that it was not the time for women to vote for women .
 Stanton and Anthony formed the American Equal Rights Association, which promoted universal adult suffrage, in 1866, hoping to change their opponents’ minds . Stanton, Anthony and Anthony hoped to change the minds of their opponents .
 President Lincoln argued that African-American men’s service in the Union army during the Civil War proved them worthy of the vote . Abolitionists continued to support only universal manhood suffrage .
 By 1869, Stanton insisted that granting voting rights to black men was endangering women’s rights . Anthony and Stanton formed the National Woman Suffrage Association .
 She argued that black men’s voting rights in Southern states should be protected when segregationist laws began making it impossible for freedmen to exercise their rights . Although she never backed away from her position, she later argued that .
 By the 1890s, Stanton entered a new phase of her intellectual life in relation to women’s position in society . Stanton became a prominent advocate for women's rights in the early 1900s .
 Despite passage of legislation protecting women’s property rights, women at the federal level was still only a dream, she began attacking Christianity for degrading the status of women in society .
 Her Womans Bible, in which she refuted the common interpretation of the Bible as sanctioning women’s subordination, became a source of friction within the suffrage movement . She refuted the idea that the Bible sanctioned women's subordination .
 Anthony, always the more activist of the two, cast a vote in the 1872 election and was promptly jailed for breaking the law . In the meantime, Anthony was always more activist . Anthony was jailed in 1872 .
 Both women ended their public lives by pleading one last time for woman suffrage . Both women died in their last moments pleading for the vote for women's rights .
 The Nineteenth Amendment was added to the U.S. Constitution in 1920 . It was the first amendment to the Constitution .

 Armand edited the Rabotnitsa newspaper and organized and chaired the First International conference of Communist Women in 1920 . Armand was a member of the First Socialist Party of Russia . He edited and chaired a conference of women in the 1920s .
 Her goals were to increase female participation in the labor force by relieving women of their duties in the home . Her goal was to encourage women to work in the workforce .
 Armand was born on May 8, 1874, in Paris to a French mother, Nathalie Wild, and an English father, Theodore Steffen . Armand died of a gunshot wound to the head in March 1883 .
 When her father died while Inessa was still young, her mother sent her to Moscow to live with her maternal grandmother . Her maternal grandmother worked as a governess for the wealthy French textile manufacturing Armand family .
 Inessa benefited from the change, because she attended tutorials along with the seven Armand children, learning languages and literature and how to play the piano .
 Inessa Armand joined the Moscow Society for Improving the Lot of Women in 1897 . Armand was a philanthropist who helped destitute and abandoned women .
 The experience opened up her eyes to a range of problems poor women faced, including prostitution and mental illness, she says .
 Members of the Moscow Society for Improving the Lot of Women elected her president in 1900 .
 Russian czarist government thwarted her efforts at opening a Sunday School for working women and editing a newspaper that discussed issues of concern to Russia’s working women .
 Lenin believed that a single, centralized parry of professional revolutionaries should lead a worker revolution in Russia . The party’s leader, Vladimir Ilich Lenin, believed that such a parry should be led by professional revolutionaries .
 She managed to escape to Finland, where she met up with her lover, Vladimir Armand, younger brother of Alexander Armand . She escaped to meet up with Vladimir, the brother of her brother, Alexander .
 Lenin and his wife Nadezhda Krupskaya were leaders of a group of Russian Social Democratic emigrants living in France and Belgium . In Brussels, Lenin's wife was also a Social Democrat living in Belgium .
 Lenin asked her to teach in his school for Bolsheviks in Longjumeau, south of Paris, in 1911 . The revolutionary leaders ignited a passion for radical political change in Armand .
 Armand sneaked back into Russia the following year, where she performed underground work for the Bolsheviks . Armand was a member of the Communist Party in Russia . The following year she returned to Russia to perform underground work .
 She was discovered and arrested again, and this time she was imprisoned . She was arrested again and imprisoned. She was imprisoned.
 Lenin and Krupskaya had moved to Cracow, Poland, where Armand rejoined them . Armand returned to Russia, where he was reunited with Lenin . The pair had been living in the Soviet Union for a year .
 Armand and Krupskaya became foreign editors of Rabotnitsa . Armand was editor of the Russian socialist journal published in St. Petersburg, Russia . He was a member of the Communist Party .
 In March 1915, she helped to organize the International Conference of Socialist Women, formed in Bern, Switzerland, to protest against the war . She was the founder of the Socialist Party of Switzerland .
 She translated many of Lenin’s writings into French during this period . She also translated Lenin's writings .
 Armand, Lenin, Krupskaya, and other Bolshevik leaders made a train trip back to Russia to topple the provisional government that had been erected after the February Revolution in 1917 . Armand and Lenin traveled to Russia in April 1917 to topple provisional government .
 The 1917 October Revolution, or October Seizure of Power, was the second, extremist stage of the Russian Revolution . The provisional government was replaced with the Soviet government .
 Armand joined protests against the Treaty of BrestLitovsk, ending Russia’s engagement in the First World War . Armand did not participate directly in the October Revolution, but she did join protests .
 The treaty was nullified when Great Britain, France, and the United States defeated Germany in November 1918 . Great Britain and France defeated Germany, Germany in 1918 .
 Armand returned to France in 1919 to help repatriate Russian prisoners of war . Armand travelled again to France to help with repatriation of Russian prisoners in 1919 .
 Armand set to work organizing Russian working women . Armand wanted to guarantee women equality in political and labor organizations. Armand felt it would help guarantee women's rights in political organizations .
 In the summer of 1920, she organized and chaired the First International Conference of Communist Women to coincide with the Second Congress of the Comintern, or Communist International . She was a prominent member of the Communist Party in Russia .

 Social and political activist Domitila Barrios de Chungara is best known for her work in the Housewives’ Committee of the Siglo XX mining camp in the Andean region .
 The women led protests in Bolivia’s capital of La Paz on behalf of their imprisoned husbands in the early 1960s . They led protests against their husbands . The women were jailed in the 1960s for refusing to give up their husbands' freedom .
 A decade later, Barrios was selected to represent the Housewives’ Committee at the United Nations Tribune of the International Women’s Year in Mexico City . Her actions brought to light the class, race, and ethnic differences separating the sisterhood of women .
 Insurrection and instability have marked Bolivia’s political and economic history since its independence from Spain in 1825 . Insurrection has marked Bolivia's political, economic and political history .
 In April 1952, an alliance between mine workers, peasants, and religious leaders resulted in the overthrow of the existing military regime and the beginning of the Bolivian National Revolution . The revolution began in April 1952 .
 The revolution produced universal suffrage, land redistribution and nationalization of the tin mining industry . The revolution also produced land redistribution to the indigenous population .
 In the late 1950s, social welfare programs were suspended in order to revive the failing economy . However, in the 1950s some of these programs were reinstated . The government suspended some of the programs in the wake of the recession .
 In 1961, Bolivian President Victor Paz Estenssoro instituted an agreement with the United States and West Germany that resulted in a decrease in the number of miners, wage freezes, and a plan to control the tin miners’ union .
 The reforms provided the mine owners with higher profits but meant degradation for the mine workers . The reforms were meant to provide profits for the owners . The mine workers say they are being degraded .
 Domitila Barrios de Chungara was born in the Andean highlands of Bolivia on May 7, 1937 . She is one of Bolivia's most famous women .
 She married her husband, a tin miner, in 1960, and over the next decade gave birth to seven children . She was living at the Siglo XX mining center near Lake Poopo in central Bolivia .

 A dysentery epidemic spread through the camp, due to unsanitary conditions, and exacerbated by lack of medicine . The outbreak of the disease was caused by a lack of sanitary conditions in the camp .
 The government responded by sending a group of performers to put on a show for the miners and their families, Barrios says . The government sent the performers to perform for the distressed miners .
 Women had been taught that their place was behind the scenes and in the home . Women decided to forge a plan that would enable them to travel to La Paz to voice their demands .
 They returned to Siglo XX XX and declared a hunger strike . Discouraged but not dispirited, they returned .
 A group of factory workers, college students, and women from surrounding villages joined in the crowd .

 The Housewives’ Committee decided to work on a newsletter that it sent to managers and government officials . It presented conflicts in the mines from the wives' perspective .

 Fredrika Bremer was born in Turku, Finland, on August 17, 1801, to a Swedish merchant family . Bremer lived in a prosperous household, first in Turkus and then on a farm near Stockholm in Arsta, Sweden .
 Sweden had gradually conquered most of Finland during the 13 th century . Swedish became the official language of Finland . Much of the Finnish economy and politics came into Swedish hands .

 The Bremers did, however, provide their seven children with a good education through private tutors . The family is famous for their philanthropic work and charity work .
 Birgitta Bremer implemented a strict diet for her female children . They were allowed a slice of bread and milk in the morning and evening, with the main meal served in the afternoon .
 She hoped to raise elegant, thinwaisted daughters who would make advantageous marriages . She hoped she hoped she would raise elegant and thin-waisted girls .

 Juana de Asbaje was born out of wedlock on November 12, 1651 . She was born in San Miguel Nepantla, a village southeast of Mexico City . Juana was born to Pedro Manuel and Isabel Ramirez .
 Her father came to Mexico from Spain from the Basque region of Spain . Her mother was Mexican born . Her father was born in Mexico .
 At the age of nine, she went to Mexico City to live with an aunt and uncle, where she learned Latin . She learned Latin from her aunt, uncle and uncle .
 By 1667, she knew that the only place she could continue to learn was the convent . Otherwise she would have to marry, care for children, and surrender her intellectual pursuits .
 Three months later, she left the order because her superiors did not give her enough time for study . Three months after she left, she said: 'I don't want to study. I want to learn'
 Sor Juana’s collection is considered the largest of her time . She continued her self-study, accumulating as many as 4,000 volumes in her library . Sor Juan was a self-librarian .
 She studied theology, logic, rhetoric, physics, music, arithmetic, geometry, and geometry . She also studied theology and rhetoric .
 Her private studies soon provoked the wrath of her peers in the convent . Her studies provoked the ire of her fellow nuns .
 Sor Juana defends herself against accusations that her religious duties suffered because she devoted too much to ‘profane’ studies . Sor Juan defended herself in a letter to Father Manuel Fernandez de la Cruz, the bishop of Puebla .
 Since 17th-century Mexican women were not allowed to write to men, she signed this letter with a pseudonym, Sor Filotea . The letter was signed by a woman in Mexican women who was not allowed by men .
 Her desire for knowledge, she explained to the bishop, was innate and could not be purged . Her desire to knowledge was innate, she said .
 When her superiors at the convent had finally banned her studies completely, she replied by affirming the right of a woman to have access to knowledge .
 To support her position, she quoted the Bible and several theologians to arrive at her insistence that women should have a broader role in society, education, and the church .
 Her letter made it clear that, to her, a lack of wisdom was akin to heresy . Her letter was made clear that she wanted to know more about wisdom .
 Sor Juana had been writing poetry since the age of nine . Her theological poem “Loa Eucharistica,” has been lost . Sor Juan was a poet who viewed poetry as a way of serving God .
 Between 1691 and 1692, Mexico suffered a wheat blight, bad harvests generally, and a rash of fires, crimes, and unrest . Mexico also suffered a bad harvest in 1691, 1692 .
 Sor Juana had ceased writing philosophical and theological texts and poetry in 1693 . By 1693 she had stopped writing philosophical texts and poems .

 It is thought that she gave away her library and most of her scientific instruments . It was thought she gave up her collection of scientific materials .

 Fusae's charisma and her work in women's rights won her the election, as she did not belong to a political party and had little financial backing .

 Chinese revolutionary andfeminist He Xiangning is known as the Mother of the Chinese Revolution . He worked in and through all phases of revolutionary politics and governments from the Republic of China through the Communist Revolution in 1949 .
 He remained committed to improving the lives of Chinese women through sexual equality . He remained steadfastly committed to helping women in China .
 He was among the first Chinese women to cut short her long, black hair in the 1920s and adopt a Western style of short hair . The gesture was designed to symbolize the onset of a new, modern womanhood .
 Born in Nanhai in Guangdong Province and raised in a middle-class, tea merchant family . Raised in the middle class, she grew up in a tea merchant .

 Sun Yat-sen joined the United League that Sun had founded in 1905 . The League was founded by Sun in 1905, and Sun founded the League .
 The group’s goal was nothing less than the ousting of the Chinese monarchy that had existed for thousands of years . The group's goal was to oust China's monarchy .

 A poor man, Stillingfleet supposedly could not afford proper silk stockings for evening wear, donning instead instead of wool blue stockings he wore during the day .
 The term bluestocking was used derisively to refer to pretentious women who discussed issues supposedly reserved for men .

 Japanese intellectuals derided the New Women writers and publishers and their publication . The New Women were published in Japan in 1959 .
 The term New Woman was coined around the turn of the 20th century and still used by women’s historians . It indicated a woman who had shirked the trappings of the Victorian “separate spheres” ideology in favor of independence from home .
 In Japan, New Women were seen as selfish, immoral women who were out to destroy the family, their particular race, and their nation . In Japan and elsewhere, New Woman was seen as immoral women .

 Dutch physician and women’s rights activist Aletta Jacobs was one of the first women doctors in the Netherlands . Jacobs came from a family of male physicians . Jacobs was a pioneer of Dutch medicine .
 In her practice as a pediatrician and gynecologist, Jacobs found that most health problems her patients suffered from were caused by social conditions . Jacobs: "Most health problems were caused not by disease but by social factors"
 Jacobs’s work with her female patients inspired her study of contraception . In 1882, she opened the first birth control clinic in the world in Amsterdam, Amsterdam .
 After retiring from medicine, she became president of the Association for Woman Suffrage . She was also a member of the National Association for Women Suffrage.
 Aletta Jacobs was born on February 9, 1854, to Abraham Jacobs and Anna de Jongh . She was the eighth child of a Jewish family of 11 children . Aletta was born in 1854 .
 Jacobs’s father allowed her to take Latin and Greek necessary for physicians . Most girls were not encouraged to aim for such lofty professional goals, but Jacobs' father encouraged her to study medicine .
 Her parents sent her to finishing school, customary for upper-class girls in the 19th century, where she learned proper manners and social graces . Her parents also sent her into finishing school .
 Jacobs studied the current laws to see if any legal restrictions existed that would prevent her from entering medical school . Jacobs says she has no legal restrictions that could prevent her entry into the medical field . Jacobs: "I want to be a doctor, not a doctor."
 At the age of 16, she passed an examination allowing her to become an apothecary . She then apprenticed with her older brother with her brother .
 Aletta Jacobs became the first woman in Holland to attend university classes . Jacobs attended university classes at the age of 18 . Jacobs was the first Dutch woman to go to university in Holland .
 Thereafter, universities all over Holland opened their doors to female students . Holland's first female university students were at the age of 16 .
 Jacobs found that her professors and her peers closely scrutinized her behavior on and off campus . Jacobs said that she was scrutinized by her peers and peers . Jacobs says she is proud of her work and her grades .

 Jacobs’s own brother, Johan, declared that he would rather see her dead than study at the university . No one took the advice, although her own brother did .
 In 1878, she completed the three-week series of tests, which granted her the right to practice medicine . She was awarded the right in 1878 to be allowed to practice .
 Practicing medicine in Amsterdam presented her with challenges right away . She was inspired by her desire to be a doctor in the Netherlands .

 Nawal el Saadawi is an outspoken feminist and critic of the Egyptian government’s treatment of women . Once referred to as the Simone de BEAUVOIR of the Arab world, she is a critic of women's rights in Egypt .
 She has published more than 20 books in Arabic, which have been translated into English, Japanese, Indonesian, Persian, Persian and Turkish .
 Her popularity among English-speaking audiences has brought greater awareness of the plight of Arab women throughout the world . Her popularity in English has led to greater awareness for Arab women worldwide .
 She was born on October 27, 1932, in the village of Kafr Tahlah near the Nile River . An official in the Egyptian Ministry of Education insured the education of all nine of his children .
 Her nonfiction book alMar’ah tva-al-Jins was published in 1972, and the government fired her from her position . Then, a storm of controversy erupted .
 El Saadawi’s contention that women were equal to men at the dawn of humanity incensed political and religious authorities . He argued that women should have been equal at the start of humanity . The claim incensed religious and political authorities .
 el Saadawi: Men were able to subjugate women and deprive them of their status within the culture . Because of economic conditions, men were able, he says, to dominate women .
 Most inflammatory was her notion of women’s mental and biological superiority to men . Her notion of a woman's mental and physical superiority to women is inflammatory .
 Al-Mar’ah wa-al-Jins examined the double standard between men and women regarding premarital sex and sexual discrimination . The study also examined a double standard in the sexual harassment of women and men .
 el Saadawi lost her job as the chief editor of a health journal, and her position as the assistant general secretary of the Medical Association of Egypt .
 The outcry over her book actually advanced el Saadawi’s career in the medical and political realm . The outcry has actually advanced her career .
 From 1979 to 1980 she was appointed as the U.N. Advisor for the Women’s Programme in Africa and the Middle East .
 El Saadawi’s political activism began to eclipse her work in medicine, however, . She became an outspoken advocate for women's rights and gender equality .
 In 1981, she and several hundred other Egyptian intellectuals were jailed because of their criticism of Egyptian President Anwar Sadat’s domestic policies . She and others were jailed for criticizing Sadat's policies .
 Egyptian society in the 20th century has been divided by the question of whether it should become an Islamic state or remain a secular nation . Egypt is a secular state in which freedom of speech is protected and religious differences are tolerated .
 Egypt's population is about 90 percent Muslim, with a significant minority identifying themselves as Coptic Christian . Egypt’s population of about 90% Muslim, about a quarter of the population is Coptic .
 The Christians are remnants of those that remained after Egypt separated from the Roman Empire in the fifth century . The Christians remain in Egypt today .
 Some Islamic fundamentalists have resorted to violence to further their goals . The government has been accused of human rights abuses in attempting to quell fundamentalists’ actions .
 Islamic groups insist on women’s traditionally subordinate position to men, while feminists such as el Saadawi protest restrictions and discrimination against women . In the midst of religious frictions, the question of women's rights remains divisive .
 The government released el Saadawi and other inmates from prison when President Sadat was assassinated by Islamic fundamentalists in October 1981 . The government was forced to release the prisoners after Sadat's assassination .
 El Saadawi organized the Arab Women’s Solidarity Association in 1982 . The group is dedicated to educating women about women's issues in the Arab world .

 The group focused particularly on women who had lost their husbands, or escaped abusive relationships, and orphaned children . The group was formed in response to a number of women who were involved in abusive relationships .

 The founders, including Trubnikova, favored a less regulatory approach, while others desired nearly total control over the residents . The founders favored less regulatory approaches .

 Readers of Wollstonecraft’s works during her lifetime considered her—and sometimes dismissed her—as a polemicist, or one who writes argumentative compositions to provoke or respond to controversy .
 Critics deem her offerings essays, or short works of literary prose, written in an analytical, speculative, or interpretive style . Centuries later, critics deem her offering essays or short prose written in a literary style . Her works include works of fiction, essays and short prose .

 Wollstonecraft was born on April 27, 1759, in Spitalfields, London, in 1759 . She was the daughter of a wealthy weaver and the son of an Irish weaver .
 The family wandered throughout England and Wales in search of regaining the older Wollstonecraffs lost fortune . The family's search for the lost fortune led to the death of the older family .
 Mary had little education and resented her parents' favor of their eldest son . Mary resented their father's preference for their eldest child . Mary was married to the eldest son, who died in 1918 .
 As a teenager, Mary Wollstonecraft took a job as a domestic servant to a wealthy widow in Bath . It gave her an early glimpse into the life of privileged dissipation in the city .
 She quit her job when her mother’s ill health beckoned her home . She soon quit her position when she was forced to return home .
 In 1784, Wollstonecraft helped her sister Eliza escape an unhappy marriage, and then she witnessed further sorrows a year later when her good friend Fanny Blood, a tuberculosis victim, died in childbirth .
 When she traveled to France in 1792 she fell in love with an American literary critic, Gilbert Imlay, and bore their daughter Fanny . Fanny was born in France and died in 1783 .
 In 1797 she married the radical author and philosopher William Godwin when she discovered she was pregnant by him . She died 10 days after giving birth to their child Mary, in 1797 .
 Mary Wollstonecraft Shelley, her daughter, went on to write the famous novel Frankenstein in 1818 . Shelley's daughter, Mary, wrote the novel Frankenstein .

 The Reverend Richard Price led the community and became an acquaintance of Mary Wollstonecraft . The Reverend Price became a friend of the author of the novel .
 Returning to England after Blood’s death, Wollstonecraft wrote her first book . She returned to England to write her first novel after Blood's death .
 A Fiction , told the semiautobiographical tale of the protagonist’s unhappy childhood and her resentment toward the frivolities of the upper classes . A Fiction .

 Between 1787 and 1790, Wollstonecraft authored cautionary tales for children . The cautionary tale was published in 1787 to 1790 .
 In addition, she penned an enthusiastic review of Catharine MACAULAY’s book on female education .

 Isaac left for Foleshill in 1824, while Mary Ann was sent to Miss Latham’s boarding school . Mary Ann left to be educated in 1823, while Isaac went to school in 1826 . Isaac and Mary Ann were married in 1828 .
 Mary Ann was lonely and isolated without her brother’s companionship, Mary Ann found comfort in books .
 She crawled out of her shell at another boarding school, where a teacher took an interest in her intellect . She soon crawled out from her shell and soon crawled back into her shell .
 She cultivated a sophisticated speaking voice and studied piano and the German language . Her voice was cultivated in a sophisticated voice .
 Mary Ann’s behavior strained the relationship between the two . Soon, however, Mary Ann and Mary Ann's relationship was strained .
 Mary Ann finds friends in a couple, Charles and Cara Bray, who doubted their Christian faith . Mary Ann found friends in the couple's home in Northampton, Massachusetts .
 In 1844, Mary Ann began working on a translation of the controversial German theologian David Friedrich Strauss’s Das Leben Jesu . The book became one of the most influential intellectual books in England .
 She received no credit for the translation in the English edition . Her reputation among England’s intellectuals grew .
 She also wrote articles anonymously for a newspaper, the Coventry Herald, which she also wrote anonymously .
 Through the Brays, Mary Ann also met John Chapman, a publisher and bookseller . The Brays also helped Mary Ann meet Chapman, who is now a publisher .
 He asked her to write an article for his scholarly journal, the Westminster Review . The Westminster Review is a scholarly journal by the author .
 When she finished the piece, she delivered it personally to Chapman’s home in London, where he lived with his wife and mistress . She delivered the piece personally to his London home .
 When Chapman and Mary Ann began flirting, his wife and mistress conspired to end their relationship . Chapman and his mistress were flirting with each other when they first met .
 Mary Ann’s father had died and she needed a place to live . In the meantime, Mary Ann had moved in to a new home . Mary Ann's father died .
 Chapman persuaded her to move into his house in London, promising that his wife and mistress would accept and consent to the living arrangements . Chapman persuaded the woman to move in to his home in London . He promised that the couple would accept the living arrangement . Chapman was married to his mistress,
 Mary Ann agreed, warning him that her relationship with him would be purely professional . Mary Ann told him that she would not be having an affair with him . She agreed, saying her relationship would be strictly professional .
 She edited Westminster Review for two years, although her name never appeared on the publication . She edited the Westminster Review, but never published her name .
 While living at the Chapman home, Mary Ann met writer George Lewes . Lewes, a married man, believed that married couples should be free to have affairs .
 By choosing to defy convention, Mary Ann faced public censure and the possibility of losing whatever editing jobs might come her way . Mary Ann's decision to take action was a bold move .
 She was also aware that, as Lewes’s live-in partner, she would be entitled to nothing if they separate or if he died .
 Her decision ended many of her friendships as well as her relationship with her beloved brother Isaac . Her decision to kill herself ended many friendships and her brother's relationship .
 When she had finished a story called “The Sad Fortunes of the Reverend Amos Barton,” she asked Lewes to send it to his publisher, John Blackwood . Blackwood was the publisher of the story .
 The story was published in 1857 under the name George Eliot, the name Mary Ann Evans chose as her nom de plume, or pen name .
 The next year, Blackwood published Adam Bede, which became a literary sensation . Blackwood's next novel, The Great War, became a major success .
 A humbly born, pretty girl named Hetty Sorrel gets caught between the honest devotion of her homely lover Adam Bede and the affections of an unprincipled but wealthy admirer .
 Sorrel becomes pregnant, lets her baby die, and is sentenced to death for infanticide . Sorrel was sentenced to the death of her baby, but was spared .
 Adam Bede author feared public would no longer continue to buy her books . Blackwood found out that a woman living out of wedlock with a married man was the author of the book .
 He reluctantly published Eliot’s The Mill on the Floss the next year; his fears proved unfounded . He reluctantly . published Eliot's The Mill On The Floss next year .

 By this time, Mary Ann Evans’s stories about rural English life had made her a rich woman . Evans's stories made her famous for their stories .
 Evans’s business manager, John Cross, proposed marriage in 1880 . Cross was 20 years younger than Evans, and Evans was 20 .
 Evans accepted, but the marriage did not last long . She died seven months later on December 22, 1880 . Evans accepted the marriage .
 Nigerian/British novelist, British novelist, scriptwriter, and publisher Buchi Emecheta is one of the most prolific and most acclaimed Nigerian writers today . He is best known for his work in Nigeria and Britain .
 She has written 19 published books, numerous essay, plays, and children's books . She has also written numerous essays, plays and plays .
 Her work deals mostly with tribal cultural norms that prevent women’s full participation in society, against a backdrop of clashing colonial and native cultures before and after Nigerian independence .
 Emecheta’s books mark a turning point in Nigerian literary history, as no writer had treated the subject of women’�s subjugation before . No Nigerian writer had written a book on the subject before .
 Great Britain directly controlled Nigeria as a crown colony from 1914-1960 . Great Britain controlled Nigeria from 1914 to 1960 .
 After independence, tensions between various ethnic groups heightened . After independence and the Republic of Nigeria was formed, tensions heightened .
 Two coups resulted in attempts by the eastern region, dominated by the Ibo people, to secede and form the Republic of Biafra . The eastern region is dominated by Ibo, who make up about 17 percent of the Nigerian population .
 After three years of civil war and a million deaths, the Ibo were forced back into the Republic of Nigeria . A million people were killed in the three-year conflict .
 Buchi Emecheta was born on July 21, 1944, in Yaba, a small village near the capital city of Lagos, into the Ibo tribe . She was born in a village near Lagos .
 Emecheta’s tribal heritage played an important role in her adult life and career . Although both parents died when she was young, both her parents died . Both parents were from the same tribe .
 The oldest woman in the traditional Ibo household is the matriarch . She gathers the young children around her and tells stories about ancestors and tribal origins . The oldest Ibo woman is a traditional Nigerian woman .
 As a child, Emecheta sat on her aunt’s knees as she told stories nightly to all the village children . She sat on the aunt's knees as a child . She now lives in a village in the Philippines .
 Emecheta has remarked that she could not imagine a job more important than that . She has said she is proud of her job as an artist .
 The couple had five children, but they separated permanently after Onwordi burned the manuscript of her first novel . The couple split after she burned her manuscript of a novel .
 Other than guest speaker appearances at various American universities, she has lived in London . She visits relatives in Nigeria frequently .
 Since 1986 she has operated her own publishing company, Ogwugwu Afor Company, named after an Ibo goddess . She has operated the publishing company since 1986 . She is the founder of the company named after a goddess of Ibo .
 In the Ditch —a British term meaning “on the dole” — is written as diary entries that recall Emecheta’s own failed marriage and struggles raising her children .
 While overall the tone of the book is morose, it is infused with moments of humor . The book is a dark, dark book with a dark theme .
 The Joys of Motherhood discusses the role of mothers in Ibo society . Motherhood is a key part of the culture of Ibo culture .
 The protagonist, Nnu Ego, marries, but she is sent home in disgrace when she fails to have children quickly enough . The protagonist was sent home after failing to have a baby quickly enough enough .

 A Novel relates the story of Nigeria’s move for independence through the collapse of the Biafran secessionist movement . The novel is based in Nigeria and is published by Nigeria's National Institute of Education .
 The collision of Western values with a traditional agrarian society forms the backdrop of the upheaval . Western values and traditional agriculture are at odds with each other .
 Unlike Emecheta’s other individualistic works, this book tells the story of entire societies and cultures caught up in a bloody, gut-wrenching civil war . Unlike the author's other individualist works, the book is about entire societies caught up .
 Emecheta remains objective as she recounts atrocities committed by all sides of the war, both military and civilian . She says she remains objective and remains objective in recounting atrocities .
