 Hayashi Fumiko is one of Japan’s most prolific and most popular writers . She has more than 70 books to her name, with over 70 novels published .
 Much of her work is autobiographical, some of it is controversial, and nearly all of it deals with society’s alienated outcasts . Her work is often autobiographical .
 Hayashi has won only one literary prize in Japan, the Joryu Bungakusho . Hayashi's short story Bangiku was published in English in 1956 under the title Late Chrysanthemum .
 Hayashi's work, and its reception, breach two different eras of Japanese literature . Hayashi’s work and reception of his work have been treated as though they are of two different generations .
 Until the 1980s, the writing of Japanese women was relegated to the ‘sentimental writing’ category, never receiving much critical scrutiny or acclaim . Until the 80s, Japanese women writers were relegated to "sentimental" writing .
 Sentimental writing, popular in the 18th and 19th centuries, exploited readers’ sympathy for the destitute, such as orphaned children and innocent and vulnerable women .
 More recently, literary critics have begun to integrate women’s writing into the general canon of Japanese literature .
 Hayashi’s writing, however, cannot be separated from its flamboyant author, Hayashi . Hayashi's writing is not separated from the author, but from the writer himself . The novel is set in Tokyo, Japan, and is set to be published in October
 Hayashi made the most of her status as a female writer, positioning herself in the “sentimental writing” category that, for her, meant financial, if not critical, success .
 Hayashi also employed a descriptive travel narrative in her journalistic writing . Hayashi used the term sentimental to describe her fiction .
 Hayashi drew upon the rollicking waves of her own personal life for her literary work . Hayashi's literary work was inspired by her personal experiences .
 Hayashi was born in Shimonoseki, a port city in between Kyushu and Honshu islands, on December 31, 1904 . Hayashi grew up an illegitimate daughter of her 22-year-old father, Miyata Asataro, and her 36-year
 Hayashi Kiku left with her daughter and moved in with a former employee of Miyata’s, Sawai Kisaburo, in 1910 . The three traveled around Kyushu island, selling wares from their cart, selling their wares .
 Hayashi began working her way through Onomichi Public Girls High School, graduating in 1922 . Hayashi was born in Hiroshima, Japan, with her family in Japan .
 After a few years she moved back south to Hongo on Kyushu island, where she waitressed at a cafe . She met and mingled with a group of anarchist poets .

 World War II coincided with the height of Hayashi’s popularity in Japan . Hayashi was a popular figure in Japan during the war .
 In 1931, Japanese army units invaded Manchuria, a northern region of China, as part of an aggressive program of territorial expansion . The invasion was part of a plan to expand China's borders .
 The Japanese then moved south, attacking the cities of Beijing and Shanghai in 1937 . They then fought their way on to Nanjing and fought for control of Nanjing .
 When Nanjing fell, Japanese troops went on an orgy of killing, known as the Rape of Nanjing . The Japanese troops then went on to punish the Chinese for holding up the army by their resistance .
 War between Japan and China caught the attention of the West . Criticism of Japanese aggression caused the departure of Japan from the international peacekeeping body of the time .
 Hayashi’s reaction to the war depended on the fortunes of the Japanese army, he says . Hayashi: ‘I’m not sure how much of the war will be affected by the outcome of this war.’
 Hayashi became severely critical of the war after the defeat . Hayashi was critical of his military campaigns .

 This book is largely descriptive rather than interpretive or analytical . It was written in the style of a travel journal .
 When the war ended in defeat for the Japanese, Hayashi denounced the destruction and personal devastation caused by the war . Hayashi was a Japanese politician who died in Japan in 1945 .
 Critics have described Bangiku as a tale of a former geisha and a ruined ex-soldier, anti-war in its tone . Critics have called it antiwar .

 Her popularity stems from her own ability to make the most of what life gave her . Her popularity comes from her ability to get the most out of life .
 Islam is a religion that was founded in the early seventh century in the Arabian Peninsula . Islam is the first religion to be established in the Middle Ages . Islam was founded by Muslims in the 7th century .
 Prophet Mohammad based the intensely monotheistic religion on revelations he received from Allah . Prophet Mohammad was a shepherd, trader, and selfproclaimed messenger of Allah .
 Mohammad and his followers unify nomadic Bedouin tribes that inhabited the peninsula . Monotheism enabled Mohammad to unify the rival nomadic tribes . Mohammad believed in only one god .
 Muslims believe Mohammad was the last of the prophets sent by Allah, from the biblical Abraham to Jesus of Nazareth . Muslims, as those who practice this religion, are called .
 Islam did not dominate the Arabian Peninsula until 630, when the Muslim army defeated forces at Mecca, and the city came under Muslim rule . Islam dominated the Arabian peninsula until 630 .
 Al-Khansa reached adulthood before the religion was thoroughly established . He reached adulthood .
 Al-Khansa was a member of the Sharid clan, a powerful family, of the Banu Suliam people of west central Arabia . He was a powerful member of a powerful clan of the powerful family . He is believed to have been the most powerful family in the world
 Al-Khansa turned down Durayd Ibn al-Summah’s marriage proposal . Her poems mention a husband and child, though Islamic tradition indicates she had three husbands and seven children .
 Her refusal of marriage provides historians with evidence that pre-Islamic Arabian women may have had more independence in marriage and divorce .
 Arabs trained their daughters to excel in these competitions and in the compositions of the verses themselves . Arab girls were trained to write their own verses in the competition .
 Al-Khansa’s elegies earned admiration and fame throughout the Arab world . Al Khansa's elegies were among the most famous in the world .
 Most of al-Khansa’s poems deal with the lives and deaths of two of her four brothers, named Sakhr and Muawiya .
 His brother, Sakhr, was obligated by tribal custom to seek revenge for the death of his brother . He was wounded in the attempt and later died of his wounds . His brother was wounded .
 Al-Khansa’s elegies exalted the ‘manly’ virtues of battlefield courage, endurance, and leadership . Al-Khanas: The "manly" virtues of “battlefield courage and endurance are the manly virtues of leadership .
 Although elegies were considered the special domain of women, male poets still ruled the literary world in Arabia .
 According to Arabian scholar Joseph Zeidan, female elegy composers were judged by criteria set up by al-Shurara al-Fuhul, the male master poets . The criteria was set up for female poets .
 In fact, the word for literary excellence, juhulah, was derived from fahl, which originally meant a sexually superior male .
 The poetry judge Bashshar ibn Burd praised the masculine qualities of al-Khansa’s elegies, according to Zeidan . He noted that women do not write without a trace of feminine weakness .
 Some Islamic scholars claim that al-Khansa converted to Islam later in life but kept the pagan funeral traditions . Others say she referred to Allah in her poems; others acknowledge that such references were added by Muslim copyists . Some claim she met Mohammad and converted later to Islam .
 The collected poetry of al-Khansa, called Diwan, was first published outside Arabia in France in 1889 .
 American writer Maxine Hong Kingston attacks themes of racism, sexism, family history (particularly the mother/daughter relationship)
 The Woman Warrior , treats all the above in a multilayered, autobiographical narrative broken into five sections . Each section has its own theme and characters .
 Kingston wrote her story as an act of protest against the oppression of Chinese women, particularly those within her own family . Kingston wrote the story as a protest against oppression of women in her family .
 Maxine Hong Kingston was the first of Tom and Ying Lan Chew Hong’s American-born children . She was born in Stockton, California, on October 27, 1940, in 1940 .
 Kingston's father had been teaching school in Sun Woi, near Canton in Guangdong Province . He decided to leave China for the “golden mountain,” the Chinese term for America .
 He sent money that he made at a laundry home to his wife, who used the funds to pay for her training in midwifery . He sent the money to her to the To Keung School of Midwiferery in Canton .
 Tom Hong named his daughter after a blond customer who came in frequently to gamble . Tom Hong moved to Stockton to take a job in a gaming hall and named her after a customer .
 Tom and Ying Lan Hong bought another laundry in a Chinese neighborhood in Stockton, California . After the birth of their six children, they bought a laundry in the Chinese neighborhood .
 The Hong business became the social center of the Chinese-American community within Stockton . The business became a social center for the Chinese American community .
 Maxine Hong Kingston heard the ‘talk-stories, or myths and legends, at the laundry where she and the rest of the family worked in China .
 Kingston soon had a repertoire that would feed her own literary passions . Along with the talk-stories told to her by her mother, Kingston learned from her mother's stories .
 In 1962 she married Earll Kingston, an actor, with whom she had one son . She also had a son with Earll, who she married in 1962 .
 Section one of The Woman Warrior, titled “No Name Woman,” recalls the chilling tale of Kingston's father’s sister back in China . Section one is titled ‘No Name Women’ .
 After she gives birth to an illegitimate child, the family’s home is raided by masked men . The aunt's sexual indiscretion is judged as an unforgivable crime during times of deep poverty .
 No Name Woman drowns her child to purge the family of the curse she has brought upon them and commits suicide . She commits suicide to purge her family from the curse .
 In divulging the secret by writing the story, the narrator breaks generations of silence and complicity in keeping No Name Woman a nonentity . "No Name Woman" is the title of the novel, which is published in New York .
 Kingston also makes use of the ancient Chinese tale of Mulan, the girl who disguises herself as a male warrior . Like XIANG JINGYU, Kingston also uses the tale of the female warrior .
 Kingston’s heroine, Fa Mu Lan, has a husband and child and does not need to transform herself into a man to perform heroic deeds . In the second part of The Woman Warrior, “White Tigers,” ‘White Tigers’, "Fa Mu Lan
 Kingston’s young Fa Mu Lan goes up into the mountains to learn to be a warrior from two kung fu teachers . Kingston's young fa Mu Lan learns from two teachers in the mountains in a new documentary .
 She leads her army into Beijing and beheads the emperor in retaliation for causing the death of her father . She then returns to her life as a housewife and mother .
 Kingston avenges the perpetuation of the stereotypically weak Chinese female . In portraying a strong female figure like Fa Mu Lan, Kingston avengers the perpetuating of the stereotypeically weak female .
 The middle chapter of The Woman Warrior, called “Shaman,” relates the story of Kingston’s mother . Kingston's mother is the woman he writes about .
 Kingston contrasts Brave Orchid’s life in China, where she was a healer, medicine woman, exorcist, and storyteller, to her life in America . Kingston contrasts her life with that of a healer and medicine woman .
 The relationship between Brave Orchid and her daughter, and their attempt to reconcile their differing perceptions of national and self-identity, are interwoven throughout the story . The relationship is the result of the story being told by the author's daughter .
 The fourth section of The Woman Warrior deals with Brave Orchid's sister Moon Orchid’s sojourn to America and her victimization at the hands of her husband .
 The final section, “A Song for a Barbarian Reed Pipe,” treats Kingston’s own battles against sexism and racism in the U.S. The final part of the book is a song about Kingston's battles against racism and sexism .
 Kingston has also written China Men , a fictionalized history about male heroes from a ChineseAmerican perspective . Kingston also wrote China Men .

 Gabriela Mistral is a leading authority on popular education in Latin America . She is a poet, journalist and educator .
 Since her death, literary critics have remade her in the image of a saindy yet coquettish Chilean goddess, according to Elizabeth Horan . Horan: Literary critics have made her image of the saintdy yet sassy goddess, an image that she shunned
 The political and social content and message of much of her poetry and prose contradicts a saintly image . Much of her prose contradicts an image of herself as a saint .
 She represented her country abroad for almost 20 years, first as Chile’s delegate to the League of Nations, then the United Nations, and in consulates in Lisbon, Naples, and Madrid .
 In 1945, she became the first Latin American to win a Nobel Prize in literature . She was also the first woman in Latin America to win the Nobel Prize .
 Mistral was born on April 7, 1889, in the northern Chilean village of Vicuna . Mistral’s birth name was Lucila Godoy Alcayaga .
 Lucila’s mother, Petronila Alcayaga, had a 13-year-old daughter, Emelina, by a previous relationship .
 Petronila Alcayaga and Emelina Villanueva supported the family on meager teachers’ earnings . Her father was a vagabond poet, unemployed schoolteacher and sometime seminarian .
 Lucila Godoy spent her childhood and adolescence wandering from village to village in the Valle de Elqui, a farming and mining region north of Santiago, Chile’s capital .
 Lucila's mother and half-sister moved often in hopes of improving their lives, all the while encouraging Lucila to become a teacher as well . Lucila was inspired by her mother to be a teacher and mother .
 Lucila’s formal education ended at 14, and she took a series of lowwage jobs in Coquimbo and La Serena . Lucila was born in Peru and moved to the United States at age 14 .
 She was already writing poetry and prose, publishing some of it in local newspapers . She was also writing poetry .
 The early 1900s were propitious times for a young woman of talent in Chile . Chile was one of the world's most successful women artists .
 Social movements were ripening in Santiago, with a politicized working class, and women’s groups mobilizing to achieve advanced education and the vote . Women's groups were mobilizing in Santiago .
 Mistral’s resourceful personality surely contributed to her success as well . While the progressive flavor of the era was in her favor, Mistral's .
 Gabriela Mistral became headmistress at one of Chile’s most prestigious public schools in just 15 years’ time . Despite her lack of academic training, Mistral moved from working as a teacher's assistant in 1903, to obtaining a teaching certificate in 1912, to
 Mistral is best known for her rich but simple, unadorned lyrical poetry . Mistral's poetry has been translated into film and television shows .
 Fler's first forays into verse writing came after the tragic suicide of her fiance in 1900 . Fler first began writing after her fiance committed suicide .
 Mistral’s national reputation came in 1914 with the publication of “Sonetos de la Muerte” (sonnets of death), which won first prize in literary contest in Santiago .
 She drew parallels between the life of a poet and that of a religious believer . She said she drew parallels with the lives of a believer and a poet .
 She personified poetry as a haughty queen who demanded that her supplicant—the poets—perform arduous tasks to win her approval . Poems were personified by her as a queen, demanding that she perform tasks for approval .
 In “The Flowers of Air,” the Queen of Poetry instructs Mistral to climb the steepest mountain, cut flowers for her .
 In 1917, Mistral used her pen to improve education by authoring 55 entries in a series of school textbooks . Mistral's work was distributed throughout Chile and other Latin American countries .
 Mistral’s prose, poetry, and stories offered an antidote to the social and economic injustices affecting Chile at the time . Mistral's prose and poetry was an antidote for Chile's social and political injustices .
 In 1922, Jose Vasconcelos, Mexico’s secretary of education, invited her to collaborate with him in a program of educational reform that he was about to embark upon in Mexico . She was invited to join him in Mexico's educational reform .
 There she became interested in the teaching of Indian Mexicans in rural areas . She introduced mobile libraries to rural areas, where she introduced mobile library .
 Her work in Mexico, Mexico, won her the title ‘Teacher of the Nation’ in Chile, Chile . Her reputation in Mexico was also established in her homeland .
 In 1922, she published the first volume of her collected poems called Desolacion . Her poems deal with love, passion, motherhood, justice, and the natural beauty of Chilean landscapes .

 The Heian period takes its name from the imperial capital at Heian-kyo, in the city now called Kyoto . The city is now known as Kyoto, Japan .
 Historical records date the beginning of a united Japanese state in the late fourth or early fifth century . A united state of Japan was formed in the early fifth and early tenth century .

 In early Japanese history, young and inexperienced Japanese emperors were most often controlled by a ruling aristocratic family . The spiritual center of Japanese life was still the spiritual and psychological center of life .
 Like other monarchical forms of government throughout the world, families maintained power through marriage alliances . Families maintained power by marriage alliances.
 He designed an impressive network of marriage ties to the imperial family, through which he became brother-in-law to two emperors, an uncle to one, uncle and father to another, and grandfather to two more . He also became the grandfather of two more emperors and grandfather of

 She kept a diary, in which she provided a vivid account of court life . However, she revealed little of her own life .
 She recorded her diary in Chinese, a language normally reserved for Japanese males . Knowledge of Chinese was seen as a sign of robust masculinity in Japan .

 Prince Genji represents the ideal Japanese male aristocrat of his time . Genji was the son of an emperor and was the first Japanese prince to be born in Japan .
 At court, contests were held in which courtiers competed with one another for prizes in poetry .
 Competition involved the ability to improvise a poem by replying to someone else’s poem using the same imagery, but in a different way .

 Madame Palatinate, wife of Philippe d’Orleans, was sister-in-law to King Louis XIV of France .
 She spent much of her life at the French court, witnessing one of France’s most glorious periods in history . She witnessed one of the most glorious period in history.
 As a foreigner, she wrote about 40 letters a week to friends and relatives in Germany, for at least 50 years of her life, for a total of approximately 100,000 letters . She wrote approximately 40 letters per week for about 50 years .
 Writing letters helped Madame Palatinate keep in touch with distant friends and relatives at home . Writing letters was an antidote for homesickness .

 Sappho understood her importance within the broad context of the literary world . Sappho was a lyric poet of the Greek lyric poet .
 Sappho's verses helped change the tone, context, and purpose of ancient Greek literature . Sappho’s verses helped to change the tones, purpose, and purposes of ancient literature .
 Homer’s Odyssey gave way to the shorter, intimate, and emotional lyric poetry composed by Sappho and her followers . Sappho's poetry was composed in the ninth and eighth centuries B.C.E. The grand epic style of poetry was popularized by Homer's Odyssey .
 Lyric poetry was sung and accompanied by a lyre . It described personal feelings of the poet toward herself and her lovers . The epic poems related tales of heroes and their exploits .
 Sappho’s poetry illuminates ancient Greek life and culture, but it reveals little about the poet herself . We do not even know whether she wrote her poems down herself, or others recorded them for her .
 Sappho was born into an aristocratic family at either Eresos or Mytilene on the island of Lesbos in the northern Aegean Sea . Sappho is one of the most famous men in Greek history . He is believed to have been born in the same place as
 She had two other brothers, including Charaxus, a merchant, and Eurygyus . She scolds her for buying the freedom of an Egyptian prostitute .
 Some scholars believe the tyrant Pittacus exiled her to the island of Syracuse for political reasons . Others believe she was exiled by Pittacus to Syracuse .
 She married a merchant from Andros named Cercolas and gave birth to a daughter, Cleis . Cleis was born in Andros and died in the same year of her birth .
 Legend has it that Sappho threw herself off the Leucadian cliffs on an island between Corfu and Ithaca . Sappho was overcome by her love for a ferryman named Phaon, according to legend .
 One of her poems, however, hints that she died at home, tended by Cleis .
 Sappho initiated a group of young girls into the rites of womanhood at Mytilene . Sappho was the first woman to be initiated by Sappho in the ancient Greek goddesses .
 She taught her girls how to sing, dance, compose poetry, and play the lyre . She also taught them how to compose poetry and compose poetry .
 The girls and their mistress formed a thiasos, or a religious association around the worship of Aphrodite, the Greek goddess of love . In addition to the girls' religious association, the girls formed a  religious association .
 Some of Sappho’s students came from long distances, such as Phocaea and Colophon, along the coast of Asia Minor, so it is assumed that Sappho's reputation as a teacher was far-reaching .
 Sappho wrote many poems detailing the nature of her erotic feelings toward some of the girls, including Anactoria, Atthis, Gongyla, Hero, and Timas . Sappho also wrote poems about the girls in her poems .
 In the late 19th century, the word lesbian, derived from the island of Lesbos on which Sappho lived, came to mean female homosexuality . The word lesbian was used to refer to female homosexuality in the early 20th century .
 In Greek culture, adolescent boys and girls spent considerable time with others of their own sex before reaching marriageable age . Intimate relationships between members of the same sex were not taboo . Sappho and her female pupils were compared to Socrates and his male students .
 fragments of her poetry were recovered in Egyptian papyrus, we assume that she and her poetry became widely known . Considering that fragments were found in Egypt papyrus we assume she was known .
 Her intimate and erotic style was considered obscene in the Middle Ages and again in the Victorian period, resulting in the loss of most of her poems . Unfortunately, most of the poems were lost .
 Sappho’s poetry is making a comeback in the late 20th century, and in our own time, Sappho's poetry is being made a comeback . Sappho was a poet of the Greek poetessessess .
 Sappho wrote in her native Aeolian dialect, using ordinary vocabulary that expressed her thoughts in a direct, unrhetorical style . Sappho used ordinary vocabulary to express her thoughts using ordinary words . Her work was published in the 18th century .

 Norwegian writer Sigrid Undset won the Nobel Prize in 1928 for her historical novel Kristin Lavransdatter . The 1,400-page book explores the spiritual and earthly lives of 13th-century Norwegians . Undset's historical novel is written in three volumes
 The author's characters compel the reader to continue reading . Her characters are tragic tragedies, joys, and foibles .
 Undset interweaves the complexities of family loyalty, the pitfalls of gossip in a small rural community, and the variety of religious beliefs and practices evident in 13th-century Norway . Undset is set in the 13th century Norway .
 Kristin Lavransdatterwzs made into a film in 1995, directed by Liv Ullmann . Liv is an actress and director of Norwegian actress .
 Undset’s childhood experiences with her archaeologist father clearly affected her decision to write a historical novel . The writing of Kristin Lavransdatter affected Undset's life perhaps more markedly . Undset was inspired by the writing of her father, an archaeologist .
 Biographers and literary critics look for ways in which an author’s life shaped the fiction she produced . Often biographers look for the ways an author's life shaped her fiction .
 Undset's life was shaped by the writing of her book, rather than the other way around, she says . Undset: "In the case of Undset, however, it seems that it was the writing that shaped her life"
 As faith overtakes fate in Kristin Lavransdatter, so faith intervened in Undset's own life . Undset’s own life was the inspiration for Undset, as was his own .
 Her Christian faith directed her toward Rome, Italy, in 1909, and led her to conversion to Catholicism in 1924 . The church became the bedrock of much of her work after Kristin Lavransdatter .
 Her choice of setting her novel in 13th-century Norway, before the Protestant Reformation of the I6th century, rests on her admiration for the steadfast Catholic faith .
 In 1882, the Undsets had lived in Rome, where Sigrid’s father, Ingvald Undset, studied archaeology . The Undsets' father was an archaeologist who studied in Rome .

 Undset wrote novels in evenings and weekends during her 10-year stint as a secretary . Undset was a secretary during her time as a writer .

 Anders Castus Svarstad, a Norwegian painter, was already married with three children in Norway . He was the father of three children .
 The two married after Svarstad’s divorce and left for London in 1912, where they stayed for six months . The two were married in 1912 .
 Undset’s life revolved around her husband and her growing family, including her own two children and those from her first marriage . During the next seven years, Undset lived with Svarstad and his family .
 She also became acquainted with the woman suffrage movement in England . She opposed the movement that she opposed .
 When the First World War broke out, Undset took her two children back to Norway . Norway remained a neutral country during the conflict, which was neutral during the war .
 Undset Undset gave birth to their third child alone in Lillehammer, Norway . Svarstad was to follow, but he did not, and Undset died in childbirth .
 The Great War had caused a breakdown in religious faiths for many people, for Undset the war had the opposite effect . Undset was the only survivor of the Great War .
 Undset, like her parents, had been a freethinker, tied to no particular faith . After the war she discovered a religious faith that would intensify with time, Undset .
 She joined the church in 1924, at a time when the dividing line between Protestant Norwegians and Catholic counterparts was securely drawn . Having received instruction in the Catholic faith, she joined in 1924 .
 Undset’s Christian faith is reflected in all the works she produced after 1920 . Undset's Christian faith reflects in all her works .
 In Gymnadenia and Den Braedende busk, Undset depicts her protagonists’ gradual conversion to Catholicism . Readers sense the autobiographical tone in both works .

 Her eldest son, Anders, was killed in battle in 1940; her daughter had died shortly before the war began . Anders died in battle .
 Undset and her youngest son went to the U.S. in 1940, returning to Norway when war ended in 1945 . Undset returned to Norway in 1945, when the war ended, and her son died there .
 Undset’s work is characterized by a brooding sense of the role that sexuality plays in human life, and the role . passion plays in dictating human destiny, Undset says .
 In her later works, there is a constant tension between the flesh and the spirit . If humans are to be good, she insists, the spirit must dominate . Her later works show a tension between flesh and spirit .

 First African American to publish a book and the first American female author to try to earn a living by her pen . Wheatley was born in West Africa and sold into slavery as a child .
 The woman who once had a reputation with General George Washington in 1776 died penniless and alone eight years later in a shack .
 19 of her 55 extant poems are funeral poems . She may have written from memories of her native West Africa .
 She was sold as a child of seven or eight to John and Susanna Wheatley of Boston in July 1761 . Her recollection of Gambia, however, must have been rather dim .
 The Wheatleys named their slave Phillis after the ship that delivered her, the Phillis . The Phillis was a slave who wore nothing but a rug wrapped around her bare torso . She was named Phillis by the Wheatleys .
 Wheatley learned to read and write under the tutelage of Susanna Wheatley . She learned to write and read under Susanna's guidance .
 In 1770, Wheatley published an elegy to George Whiteheld that fueled her career as a writer . Wheatley died in 1770 at the hands of her husband .
 Known as the Great Awakener, the famous Whiteheld spawned a religious revival in the American colonies . Known as 'The Great Awakeener', the Whiteheld was known for its religious revival .

 Phillis Phillis’s spirited prose, resplendendended with quotes from Whiteheld's most celebrated preachings, became a huge success and was frequently reprinted . Phillis's spirited prose became a hugely popular book and was often reprinted .
 Through the Whiteheld elegy, Wheatley earned the support of the countess of Huntingdon, who ensured that the poem was reproduced several times in London . Wheatley's poem was published in London in 1883 .

 Phillis Wheatley was to travel to court to meet the British royal family, but Susanna Wheatley fell ill and required Phillis’s return to Boston in August 1773 . Phillis returned to Boston, Massachusetts, in 1773.
 Wheatley was a staunch patriot in the conflict between the American colonies and Great Britain . John and Susanna Wheatley remained loyal to the Crown, while Susanna remained loyal .

 Wheatley's fame in the former colonies rivaled writer Philip Freneau’s claim of being the poet of the American Revolution . Wheatley was the son of William Wheatley, who died in 1777 .
 The letters and elegies Wheatley wrote during the last 10 years of her life betray the frustrations and difficulties she experienced in trying to continue her writing career in the face of racial prejudices . Wheatley died at the age of 81 at her home in London .

 French novelist, poet, and essayist Marguerite Yourcenar was born June 8, 1903, in Belgium . She spent most of her life in France and the United States .
 Yourcenar translated numerous European and American masterpieces into French . In addition to writing her own works of literature, she translated numerous works of art .
 In 1980, she became the first woman elected to the French Academy since its founding in 1635 . She was also the first female member of the Academy since it was founded .
 Marguerite Yourcenar’s father educated her in languages and literature by making her read aloud, in their original languages, the literary masterpieces of France, England, Greece, Greece and Rome .
 Yourcenar’s vast knowledge would become the bedrock of her prodigious literary output, including numerous novels, books of poems, short stories, plays, essays, and translations .
 Many of her characters rebel against the sexual, social, and moral limitations set by human societies . Many of the characters in the novel rebel against those limitations .
 Born Marguerite de Crayencour, she was the daughter of aristocratic parents . She was born in 18th Century France .
 Her mother, Fernande de Cartier de Marchienne, died a week after Marguerite was born in 1903 . Her mother is the heiress of a long line of wealthy Belgian landowners and industrialists .
 Her wild and unruly father, Michel de Crayencour, tried a variety of occupations, including enlisting in the French army . Her wild father was constant companions until his death in 1929 .
 He deserted soon after, traveling to England where he became the lover of his landlord’s wife . He proved his devotion to her by mutilating his left middle finger .
 Marguerite’s mother too, had flouted the moral standards of her aristocratic class by running off to Germany with her soon-to-be-husband . The Duchess of Cambridge's mother also ran off with her husband .
 Marguerite successfully passed her baccalaureate exams in Nice, France, at the age of 16 . She is now a mother-of-one .

 Marguerite liked the idea of creating an authorial persona, comparing it to a nun taking a new name when she joins an order . Marguerites said she wanted to create a new persona for herself .
 She legally adopted her literary persona in 1947 when she opted to become an American citizen . She adopted her American citizenship in 1947 .
